Elasticity.comment: Geometric discontinuities cause stress concentration amplifying local stress and promoting fracture.

Elasticity.question: The unit of modulus of resilience (energy per unit volume) is:
Elasticity.comment: Energy per unit volume has units of J/m^3 which equals Pa (N/m^2).

Elasticity.question: If a bar loaded and unloaded within elastic limit, the work done by load is:
Elasticity.a: Stored as recoverable elastic strain energy and returned on unloading
Elasticity.comment: Elastic work is stored and recoverable if within elastic range.

Elasticity.question: In a tensile test, necking begins when:
Elasticity.a: True stress reaches maximum (after which engineering stress falls)
Elasticity.comment: Necking initiates when material can no longer sustain increasing true stress with plastic strain (engineering stress falls after UTS).

Elasticity.question: Which material is typically more ductile?
Elasticity.comment: Mild steel exhibits significant plastic deformation before fracture — ductile; glass is brittle.

Elasticity.question: Fatigue failure occurs due to:
Elasticity.a: Repeated cyclic loading well below ultimate strength over time
Elasticity.b: Single application of large static load only
Elasticity.comment: Fatigue is caused by cyclic stresses causing crack initiation and growth even below UTS.

Elasticity.question: Toughness of a material is best described as:
Elasticity.a: Energy absorbed per unit volume up to fracture (area under full stress–strain curve)
Elasticity.comment: Toughness measures ability to absorb energy before fracturing (combines strength and ductility).

Elasticity.question: Which test is commonly used to measure impact toughness (resistance to impact)?
Elasticity.comment: Charpy and Izod tests measure energy absorbed in a high-strain-rate impact.

Elasticity.question: If a wire of spring constant k has equivalent stiffness as a rod with AE/L = k, doubling the length L (all else same) changes k to:
Elasticity.comment: k = AE/L so doubling L halves stiffness (inverse relation).

Elasticity.question: Which of the following statements about Young's modulus is TRUE?
Elasticity.a: It is a material property independent of object's shape and size
Elasticity.b: It depends strongly on object's dimensions
Elasticity.c: It is always the same for all materials
Elasticity.comment: E is intrinsic to material (for homogeneous isotropic solids) and independent of geometry.

Elasticity.question: A brittle material typically shows:
Elasticity.a: Little or no plastic deformation before fracture
Elasticity.comment: Brittle materials (e.g., glass, ceramics) fracture with little plastic strain.

Elasticity.question: Which of the following increases with increasing temperature for crystalline solids generally?
Elasticity.comment: Most solids soften with temperature; elastic moduli typically decrease with rising temperature.

Elasticity.question: When two identical rods of length L are fixed end-to-end and pulled by force F, the total extension compared to a single rod of length L is:
Elasticity.a: Twice the extension of single rod (since length doubled)
Elasticity.comment: Series connection doubles length so ΔL_total = 2×(FL/(AE)) for same cross-section and material.

Elasticity.question: The engineering stress at fracture and true stress at fracture differ because:
Elasticity.a: True stress uses instantaneous area which decreases during necking; engineering uses original area
Elasticity.b: Engineering stress accounts for dynamic changes
Elasticity.c: True stress uses original area always
Elasticity.comment: True stress = F / A_instantaneous and can be larger than engineering stress near necking.

Elasticity.question: Which of the following accurately describes 'plastic deformation'?
Elasticity.a: Permanent deformation remaining after load removal beyond elastic limit
Elasticity.comment: Plastic deformation is irreversible; occurs once elastic limit/yield is exceeded.

Elasticity.question: Which of the following affects Young's modulus most directly?
Elasticity.a: Atomic bonding and microstructure of the material
Elasticity.comment: E is determined by material's interatomic bonding and microstructure (crystal structure, defects).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Simple harmonic motion is characterized by which restoring force?
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: SHM: restoring force is linear in displacement and directed towards equilibrium (F = −k x).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Equation of motion for an ideal mass–spring SHM is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.d: m x¨ + b x˙ + k x = F(t)
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Free undamped SHM: mẍ + kx = 0 (no damping, no external force).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: General solution for displacement in SHM can be written as:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Standard form: x(t)=A cos(ωt+φ) with amplitude A and initial phase φ.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Angular frequency ω for a mass–spring system (mass m, spring constant k) is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Natural angular frequency ω₀ = √(k/m).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Frequency f and angular frequency ω are related by:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: f = ω/(2π), and period T = 1/f = 2π/ω.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Period T of mass–spring SHM is:
Maximum velocity vmax in SHM with amplitude A and angular frequency ω is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: v_max occurs at equilibrium: v_max = ω A.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Maximum acceleration amax in SHM is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: a(t) = −ω^2 x(t) → a_max = ω^2 A.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If x(t) = A cos(ω t + φ), the velocity v(t) equals:
Simple Harmonic Motion.b: v(t) = ω^2 A cos(ω t + φ)
Simple Harmonic Motion.c: v(t) = A cos(ω t + φ) / ω
Simple Harmonic Motion.d: v(t) = ω A cos(ω t + φ)
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Differentiate x(t): v = dx/dt = −ω A sin(ω t + φ).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Phase difference between displacement x and velocity v in SHM is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: v leads x by π/2 (for x = A cos ωt, v = −A ω sin ωt = A ω cos(ωt+π/2)).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Phase difference between displacement x and acceleration a is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: a = −ω^2 x → acceleration is 180° out of phase with displacement.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Total mechanical energy E of an undamped SHM (mass m, spring k, amplitude A) is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Total energy (constant) = maximum potential = ½ k A^2 = ½ m ω^2 A^2.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: At displacement x in SHM, the instantaneous kinetic energy K is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Since v^2 = ω^2 (A^2 − x^2), K = ½ m v^2 = ½ m ω^2 (A^2 − x^2).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Average kinetic energy ⟨K⟩ over one cycle of undamped SHM equals:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Average kinetic = average potential = E/2; with E = ½ k A^2 → ⟨K⟩ = ¼ k A^2.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Energy in ideal (undamped) SHM is conserved because:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: No damping or external work means mechanical energy remains constant.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: For a simple pendulum of length ℓ (small amplitude), angular frequency ω is approximately:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Small-angle linear approximation gives ω = √(g/ℓ) and T = 2π√(ℓ/g).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: For small oscillations, period T of a simple pendulum (length ℓ) is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Standard result for small-angle pendulum: T = 2π√(ℓ/g).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Period of small oscillations of a simple pendulum is independent of:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: T does not depend on bob mass; for small angles T ≈ 2π√(ℓ/g) (amplitude independence holds for small angles).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: A mass m attached to spring k has amplitude A = 0.05 m, m = 0.5 kg and k = 200 N/m. Its angular frequency ω equals:
For the same mass and spring as above (ω = 20 rad·s⁻¹), the period T is approximately:
Using the same data (m=0.5 kg, k=200 N/m, A=0.05 m), the maximum speed v_max is:
For the same example, total mechanical energy E is:
The projection of uniform circular motion on a diameter performs:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: SHM can be obtained as projection of uniform circular motion: x = A cos(ωt+φ).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If two SHMs of same frequency and phase are superposed, the resultant amplitude is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: In-phase SHMs add algebraically: resultant amplitude = A1 + A2.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Superposition of two SHMs of same frequency but opposite phase (180°) yields:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Out-of-phase SHMs subtract; if equal amplitudes, they cancel (resultant zero).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Beats occur when two oscillations of nearly equal frequency are superposed. Beat frequency equals:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Envelope varies at the beat frequency |f1 − f2| (perceived amplitude modulation).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: For a damped harmonic oscillator with equation m x¨ + c x˙ + k x = 0, critical damping coefficient c_crit is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Critical damping occurs at c = 2√(mk); dividing by 2m gives damping ratio ζ = 1.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Damped oscillation is underdamped when damping ratio ζ satisfies:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Underdamped: 0 < ζ < 1 → decaying oscillatory motion with ω_d = ω0 √(1 − ζ²).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: In underdamped motion, damped angular frequency ω_d equals:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: ω_d = ω0 √(1 − ζ²) where ω0 = √(k/m) and ζ = c/(2√(mk)).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: In critically damped motion (ζ = 1) the system returns to equilibrium:
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: As fast as possible without oscillation
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Critical damping gives fastest return to equilibrium with no overshoot.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Quality factor Q of a lightly damped oscillator is related to damping ratio ζ by:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: For small damping Q = 1/(2ζ); high Q ⇒ low damping, sharp resonance.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Forced oscillation with driving frequency ω has largest steady-state amplitude near:
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: Natural frequency ω0 (resonance) for small damping
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Resonance: maximum amplitude occurs close to ω0, exact peak slightly shifted if damping present.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: For a driven damped oscillator, at resonance the phase of steady-state oscillation relative to driving force is approximately:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: At resonance the oscillator's response lags the driving force by ≈ π/2.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Small oscillations about a stable equilibrium correspond to approximating potential energy as:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Near minimum, any smooth potential ≈ quadratic → motion approximately SHM.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Time period of small oscillation of a physical pendulum (moment of inertia I about pivot, distance d from pivot to center of mass) is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Small-angle period: T = 2π √(I/(m g d)).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Torsional pendulum angular frequency ω for moment of inertia I and torsion constant κ is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Torsional oscillations: equation I θ¨ + κ θ = 0 gives ω = √(κ/I).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: A mass–spring system oscillating vertically has the same period as the horizontal case if:
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: Amplitude is small and spring obeys Hooke's law (gravity only shifts equilibrium)
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Gravity changes equilibrium position but not small-oscillation frequency (T = 2π√(m/k)).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: The phase constant φ in x(t) = A cos(ω t + φ) is determined by:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: φ found from initial displacement and velocity at t = 0.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If an oscillator has displacement x = A sin(ω t), then at t = 0 displacement and velocity are:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: sin(0)=0, derivative v = A ω cos(ω t) → v(0)=A ω.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If initial conditions are x(0)=0 and v(0)=0 for an undriven oscillator, the motion is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Zero initial displacement and zero velocity => no motion for linear system with no forcing.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: For small oscillations, period of a liquid in U-tube of effective length ℓ is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: T = 2 π √(ℓ / (2 g)) for small amplitude
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: U-tube oscillation behaves like simple pendulum with effective restoring acceleration → T ≈ 2π√(ℓ/(2g)).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If period T of a simple pendulum on Earth is measured as 2.006 s for ℓ = 1.00 m, what value of g does this imply approximately?
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: T = 2π√(ℓ/g) → g = (4π² ℓ)/T² ≈ 9.80 m/s² for T ≈ 2.006 s, ℓ = 1 m.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Small oscillations of a bead on a frictionless circular hoop of radius R about bottom position have period:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Near bottom, restoring torque ≈ mg sinθ ≈ mg θ → ω = √(g/R).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If two SHMs of equal amplitude A and equal frequency ω but with phase difference π/2 are added, resultant motion is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: Circular if components are orthogonal (equal amplitude and 90° phase)
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Two perpendicular SHMs of equal amplitude and phase difference π/2 give uniform circular motion projection.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: For a driven oscillator with small damping, the amplitude at resonance is approximately proportional to:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Peak amplitude increases as damping decreases; for small damping amplitude ∝ 1/c.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE for SHM of small amplitude?
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: Period is independent of amplitude (isochronous) for ideal linear SHM
Simple Harmonic Motion.b: Period increases linearly with amplitude always
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Ideal linear SHM (x¨ + ω² x = 0) has period independent of amplitude; for pendulum that's approx true for small angles.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If x(t) = A cos(ω t + φ), the acceleration a(t) equals:
Simple Harmonic Motion.b: a(t) = ω A cos(ω t + φ)
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Second derivative gives a = −ω² x(t).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: In SHM, maximum potential energy equals:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: At turning points kinetic energy zero, potential energy = total energy E = ½ k A².

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If a spring–mass oscillator is compressed to 0.02 m with spring constant k = 100 N·m⁻¹ and released, total energy is:
Simple harmonic motion is the solution of the differential equation x¨ + ω² x = 0 because:
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: Second derivative of cos is −cos, giving required sign
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: d²/dt² [cos(ωt)] = −ω² cos(ωt), satisfying the equation.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: The restoring force in SHM is a conservative force. Therefore the work done over one complete cycle is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Conservative forces do zero net work over closed path → net work over cycle = 0.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Which is TRUE for small oscillations of a particle in a potential well near its minimum?
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: Motion is approximately SHM with ω² = U''(x0)/m
Simple Harmonic Motion.c: Motion independent of curvature of potential
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Quadratic approximation U(x) ≈ U(x0)+½ U''(x0)(x−x0) gives ω² = U''(x0)/m.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: A mass m attached to two identical springs (each k) in parallel has effective spring constant:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Parallel springs add: k_total = k1 + k2 = 2k.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: A mass attached to two springs in series (each k) has effective spring constant:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Series springs combine like resistors: 1/k_total = 1/k + 1/k → k_total = k/2.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If a block on a spring executes SHM and amplitude is doubled while all else same, the period:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Period is independent of amplitude for linear SHM: T = 2π√(m/k).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: In a lightly damped oscillator, successive peak amplitudes decrease approximately geometrically. The logarithmic decrement δ is defined as:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Log decrement measures exponential decay per cycle: δ = ln(A_n / A_{n+1}) for underdamped motion.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If two harmonic oscillators have frequencies f1 = 50 Hz and f2 = 51 Hz, the beat frequency is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Beat frequency = |f1 − f2| = 1 Hz.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: The velocity of a particle performing SHM is zero at:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: At extremes displacement ±A, v = 0 and acceleration maximal.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: The acceleration in SHM is proportional to displacement and points:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: a = −ω² x → direction is opposite to displacement, restoring towards equilibrium.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Which quantity does NOT affect the period of an ideal simple pendulum for small oscillations?
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: T = 2π√(ℓ/g) independent of bob mass; small amplitude assumption required for amplitude independence.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: A particle undergoes SHM with amplitude A. The fraction of time spent between x = 0 and x = A/2 compared to full period is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Particle moves fastest near equilibrium, so spends less time near center than near turning points.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If an oscillator's amplitude decays exponentially as A(t) = A0 e^{−λ t}, then the energy decays as:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Energy ∝ A^2 so E(t) ∝ e^{−2λ t}.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If the restoring force is F = −k x − α x^3 (nonlinear term), small oscillations about x=0 are approximately:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: For small x the linear term dominates, giving approx SHM; nonlinear term gives anharmonic corrections.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: In SHM the maximum kinetic energy equals:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: At equilibrium (x=0), potential is zero and kinetic is maximum, equal to total E = ½ k A².

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Which of the following systems can exhibit SHM for small displacements?
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: Mass–spring, simple pendulum (small angle), torsional pendulum
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Many systems near stable equilibrium behave like SHM for small perturbations.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: A mass on a spring completes 100 oscillations in 20 s. Its frequency f and period T are:
If a simple harmonic oscillator has displacement x(t) = A cos ωt, the node (zero displacement) times occur at:
In forced oscillation with driving force F(t) = F0 cos(ω t), steady-state amplitude is maximum when:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Resonance occurs near natural frequency ω0; damping shifts/limits the peak.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If damping is very large (overdamped), the system returns to equilibrium:
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: Without oscillation, slower than critically damped
Simple Harmonic Motion.c: Faster than critical damping with oscillations
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Overdamped (ζ > 1) → no oscillation, exponential return slower than critical damping.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: A spring–mass oscillator has m = 0.2 kg, k = 50 N·m⁻¹. Its natural frequency f (Hz) equals:
If two identical springs (k each) are fixed and a mass m attached to both in parallel, the period becomes:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: Parallel springs give k_eff = 2k → ω = √(2k/m) → T = 2π√(m/(2k)).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Acceleration of SHM is proportional to displacement with proportionality constant:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: a = −ω² x; also ω² = k/m.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: Which of the following is NOT a property of ideal SHM?
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: In ideal (undamped) SHM energy is conserved (does not decrease with time).

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: An oscillator with very high Q factor has:
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: Very small damping and sharp resonance peak
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: High Q ⇒ low energy loss per cycle; resonance is sharp.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If a mass–spring system is displaced and released, the maximum potential energy equals the initial:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: At turning point all energy is potential equal to total mechanical energy.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: A pendulum clock on a mountain (where g is slightly smaller) will run:
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: slightly slower (period increases with smaller g)
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: T ∝ 1/√g so smaller g → larger T → clock runs slow.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: If the mass of an oscillating system is quadrupled with same spring, the period becomes:
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: T = 2π√(m/k) → √(4m)/√m = 2 → period doubles.

Simple Harmonic Motion.question: For a driven oscillator, if driving frequency is much higher than natural frequency, steady-state amplitude is:
Simple Harmonic Motion.a: Small (amplitude decreases with increasing drive frequency above resonance)
Simple Harmonic Motion.comment: At ω ≫ ω0 the response amplitude falls off (approx ∝ 1/ω² for large ω).

Waves.question: A wave is a disturbance that transfers which of the following without transporting the substance?
Waves.comment: Waves transmit energy and momentum through a medium or space; the medium's particles may oscillate but aren't transported overall.

Waves.question: Which of the following is a transverse wave?
Waves.comment: Light (EM wave) is transverse: electric and magnetic fields oscillate perpendicular to propagation.

Waves.question: Which of the following is a longitudinal wave?
Waves.comment: Sound in gases and liquids is longitudinal: particle oscillations parallel to propagation direction.

Waves.question: Wave speed v, frequency ν and wavelength λ are related by:
Waves.comment: Fundamental relation: wave speed v = frequency ν × wavelength λ.

Waves.question: Angular frequency ω and wave number k relate to ν and λ by:
Waves.a: ω = 2 π ν and k = 2 π / λ
Waves.b: ω = ν / 2 π and k = λ / 2 π
Waves.c: ω = π ν and k = π / λ
Waves.comment: ω = 2πν (radians/sec) and k = 2π/λ (radians per unit length).

Waves.question: General form of a one-dimensional progressive wave travelling in +x direction is:
Waves.a: y(x,t) = A cos(k x − ω t + φ)
Waves.b: y(x,t) = A cos(k x + ω t)
Waves.comment: A cos(kx − ωt + φ) describes a wave of amplitude A traveling in +x. Sign convention: (kx − ωt) → +x direction.

Waves.question: Phase velocity v_p of a wave is given by:
Waves.comment: Phase speed v_p = ω / k = ν λ.

Waves.question: Group velocity v_g of a wave packet is:
Waves.comment: Group velocity v_g = dω/dk describes energy/information speed; in nondispersive media v_g = v_p.

Waves.question: A medium is dispersive if:
Waves.a: Phase velocity depends on frequency (ω/k varies with ω)
Waves.comment: Dispersion: ω = ω(k) non-linear → phase velocity and group velocity depend on frequency.

Waves.question: Superposition principle for linear waves states:
Waves.a: Resultant displacement is sum of individual displacements
Waves.d: Only one wave can exist at a time
Waves.comment: Linear wave equations permit addition of solutions (principle of superposition).

Waves.question: Constructive interference occurs when two waves meet with a phase difference of:
Waves.comment: When phase difference = 0 modulo 2π, peaks align → constructive interference (max amplitude).

Waves.question: Destructive interference (complete) occurs when two equal waves meet with phase difference:
Waves.comment: Phase difference (2n+1)π → opposite phases → cancellation for equal amplitudes.

Waves.question: Beats produced by superposition of two waves of frequencies ν1 and ν2 have beat frequency:
Waves.comment: Amplitude envelope oscillates at beat frequency equal to absolute difference of component frequencies.

Waves.question: Standing wave pattern arises from superposition of two identical waves travelling in opposite directions. Nodes are points where:
Waves.comment: Nodes are fixed points of zero displacement; antinodes are points of maximum oscillation.

Waves.question: For a string of length L fixed at both ends, fundamental wavelength λ1 is:
Waves.comment: String fixed at both ends: allowed wavelengths λ_n = 2L/n; fundamental n=1 → λ1 = 2L.

Waves.question: For the same string, nth harmonic frequency is:
Waves.comment: ν_n = n (v/(2L)) where v is wave speed on the string; harmonics are integer multiples of fundamental.

Waves.question: For an open-open pipe of length L, allowed wavelengths are λ_n = 2L/n. What about an open-closed pipe?
Waves.comment: Open-closed pipe supports odd harmonics: λ = 4L/(2n−1), frequencies ν = (2n−1) v/(4L).

Waves.question: Wave equation in one dimension for displacement y(x,t) is:
Waves.comment: Standard 1D wave equation: ∂²y/∂x² = (1/v²) ∂²y/∂t² with wave speed v.

Waves.question: If wave on a stretched string has tension T and linear mass density μ, its speed v is:
Waves.comment: Transverse wave speed on a string: v = √(tension/linear mass density).

Waves.question: Intensity I of a progressive wave is defined as:
Waves.comment: Intensity = average power transmitted per unit area perpendicular to propagation direction.

Waves.question: For a sinusoidal wave on a string with amplitude A, linear density μ, angular frequency ω and speed v, average power transmitted is proportional to:
Waves.comment: Average power ∝ μ ω² A² v (exact: P_avg = ½ μ ω² A² v).

Waves.question: Decibel level β related to intensity I and reference I₀ (10⁻¹² W·m⁻² for sound) is:
Waves.comment: Sound level in decibels: β(dB) = 10 log₁₀(I/I₀). (For amplitude ratios use 20 log₁₀.)

Waves.question: Doppler effect for sound refers to:
Waves.a: Change of observed frequency due to relative motion of source and observer
Waves.b: Change of wavelength only due to amplitude change
Waves.c: Change in speed of sound due to temperature only
Waves.comment: Relative velocity between source and observer shifts observed frequency (higher when approaching).

Waves.question: For small source speed u_s and observer at rest, observed frequency f' when source approaches is:
Waves.comment: Moving source formula: f' = f v/(v − v_s). If source approaches (v_s positive toward observer) frequency increases.

Waves.question: For moving observer with speed u_o toward stationary source, observed frequency is:
Waves.comment: Moving observer: frequency scales by (v ± v_o)/v depending on direction; toward source uses +.

Waves.question: If two waves of equal amplitude and frequency travel in opposite directions and superpose, the distance between adjacent nodes is:
Waves.comment: Standing wave nodes separated by half-wavelength: distance between successive nodes = λ/2.

Waves.question: In Young's double-slit experiment, fringe spacing Δy on screen at distance D is:
Waves.a: Δy = λ D / d (d = slit separation)
Waves.comment: Fringe spacing = λD/d for small-angle approximation (screen far compared to slit separation).

Waves.question: Phase difference between two waves arriving with path difference Δ is:
Waves.comment: Phase difference = (2π/λ) × path difference Δ.

Waves.question: Condition for constructive interference in double-slit (bright fringes) is path difference Δ =
Waves.comment: Bright fringes when path difference = mλ; dark when (m + ½)λ.

Waves.question: Single-slit diffraction central maximum width is approximately:
Waves.comment: Angular width of central maximum ≈ 2 λ / a → linear width on screen ≈ 2 λ D / a.

Waves.question: If wave amplitude doubles, intensity (power per unit area) changes by:
Waves.comment: Intensity ∝ (amplitude)² for linear waves: doubling amplitude → fourfold intensity.

Waves.question: Reflection of a wave from a fixed end introduces a phase change of:
Waves.comment: Reflection from a rigid/fixed boundary inverts displacement (phase shift π). Free end reflection has no phase change.

Waves.question: When a wave passes from a medium of speed v₁ to v₂ without dispersion, its frequency:
Waves.comment: Frequency is determined by source; crossing media changes wavelength λ = v/ν, but ν unchanged.

Waves.question: Refraction of waves at a boundary follows which rule?
Waves.a: sin θ₁ / sin θ₂ = v₁ / v₂ (Snell's law form)
Waves.c: sin θ₁ / sin θ₂ = μ1 / μ2 where μ are amplitudes
Waves.comment: Wave refraction: sinθ/v (or equivalently n sinθ) relation; for light v ∝ 1/n gives Snell's law n₁ sinθ₁ = n₂ sinθ₂.

Waves.question: Huygens' principle states that:
Waves.a: Every point on a wavefront acts as a source of secondary spherical wavelets and new wavefront is envelope
Waves.b: Waves travel in straight lines only
Waves.comment: Huygens constructs wave propagation by superposition of secondary wavelets from each point on wavefront.

Waves.question: For a fixed string with linear density μ = 0.01 kg/m and tension T = 100 N, wave speed v is:
A standing wave on a string has nodes at x = 0 and x = L. If next node is at x = L/3, wavelength is:
Waves.comment: Nodes separated by λ/2 → if node at 0 and next at L/3, then λ/2 = L/3 → λ = 2L/3.

Waves.question: Polarization is a property of which type of wave?
Waves.comment: Only transverse waves have polarization (direction of oscillation perpendicular to propagation).

Waves.question: Phase velocity v_p = 300 m/s and group velocity v_g = 200 m/s in a medium — which is true?
Waves.c: No wave can have v_g different from v_p
Waves.comment: Dispersion implies v_p ≠ v_g; energy travels at group velocity, phase at phase velocity.

Waves.question: If two waves y₁ = A cos(kx − ωt) and y₂ = A cos(kx − ωt + π), their superposition yields:
Waves.comment: Phase difference π ⇒ equal amplitude opposite phase → complete cancellation.

Waves.question: Impedance Z of a string (mechanical wave) is defined as:
Waves.a: Z = √(T μ) (ratio of transverse force to transverse velocity)
Waves.comment: Mechanical wave impedance Z = transverse force / transverse particle velocity = √(T μ).

Waves.question: If a wave reflects at boundary where impedance changes, amplitude of reflected wave depends on:
Waves.comment: Reflection coefficient for amplitude depends on impedances of the two media.

Waves.question: A transverse wave travelling in +x direction is given by y = 0.02 cos(π x − 200 π t) (SI units). Wavelength λ and frequency ν are:
If intensity of sound at 1 m is I₁ and at 2 m is I₂ from a point source in free space, then I₂ =
Waves.comment: For isotropic point source in 3D, intensity falls as 1/r² → doubling r reduces intensity by 4.

Waves.question: For small amplitude water waves in deep water, dispersion relation is ω² = g k. Which of the following is true?
Waves.a: Phase velocity v_p = ω/k = √(g/k) depends on k → dispersive
Waves.comment: Deep water gravity waves are dispersive: v_p and v_g depend on k.

Waves.question: In an organ pipe open at both ends, allowed harmonics are:
Waves.comment: Open–open supports all integer n: ν_n = n v/(2L).

Waves.question: If a string has linear density μ and tension T, fundamental frequency ν₁ for length L is:
Waves.comment: ν₁ = v/(2L) with v = √(T/μ).

Waves.question: Standing waves in a pipe closed at one end have pressure node at which end?
Waves.comment: Closed end is displacement node (pressure antinode); open end is displacement antinode (pressure node).

Waves.question: If two wave trains with slightly different k (k and k+Δk) and ω (ω and ω+Δω) superpose, the resulting envelope travels at speed:
Waves.comment: Group velocity given by slope dω/dk; approximate using finite differences Δω/Δk.

Waves.question: Which phenomenon demonstrates wave nature of particles (matter waves)?
Waves.comment: Electron diffraction and interference show wave properties of matter (de Broglie hypothesis).

Waves.question: For electromagnetic waves in vacuum, relation between energy density u and intensity I is:
Waves.a: I = c u (c speed of light)
Waves.comment: Intensity = energy flux = c × energy density for EM waves in vacuum (averaged).

Waves.question: If amplitude of wave on string is A and tension T increases, wave speed:
Waves.comment: v depends on T and μ; amplitude A does not change wave speed for linear waves on an ideal string.

Waves.question: If two waves of equal amplitude A and frequency are out of phase by π/3, resultant amplitude is:
Waves.comment: Resultant amplitude for equal amplitudes: 2A cos(Δφ/2). For Δφ=π/3 → cos(π/6)=√3/2 → A_res = A√3.

Waves.question: A wave packet constructed from a narrow band of frequencies has:
Waves.a: Large spatial extent (uncertainty principle between k and x)
Waves.comment: Narrow frequency bandwidth (Δk small) → wide spatial envelope (Δx large) — Fourier uncertainty.

Waves.question: Which quantity remains same for all harmonics in a given stretched string (fixed tension & density)?
Waves.comment: Wave speed determined by T and μ is same for all modes; frequencies and wavelengths differ by harmonic number.

Waves.question: If a progressive wave y = A cos(k x − ω t) is shifted in time by t₀, the effect on phase is:
Waves.a: Adds −ω t₀ to phase (y = A cos(k x − ω (t + t₀)))
Waves.comment: Time shift changes phase: cos(kx−ω(t+t₀)) = cos(kx−ωt − ω t₀).

Waves.question: In a medium where sound speed v ∝ √(temperature), increasing temperature will:
Waves.comment: For ideal gases v ≈ √(γ R T / M) so sound speed increases with √T.

Waves.question: An electromagnetic plane wave in vacuum satisfies which relation between E and B amplitudes?
Waves.comment: In EM plane wave, magnitudes related by E = c B (SI units).

Waves.question: In the far-field of a point source emitting spherical waves, wavefront area grows as:
Waves.comment: Spherical wavefront area increases as 4πr² so intensity decreases as inverse square of r.

Waves.question: If a string's tension is quadrupled (T → 4T) keeping μ same, fundamental frequency changes by:
Waves.comment: ν₁ ∝ √(T) → √4 = 2 → frequency doubles.

Waves.question: Rayleigh criterion for resolving two close wave sources relates to:
Waves.a: Angular separation where central maximum of one coincides with first minimum of other (diffraction limit)
Waves.comment: Rayleigh limit gives resolution ∼ 1.22 λ / D for circular apertures (optics).

Waves.question: If a periodic wave has displacement y(x,t) = A cos(k x − ω t), instant when phase = 0 corresponds to positions/times satisfying:
Waves.a: k x − ω t + φ = 0 modulo 2π
Waves.comment: Phase zero condition sets arguments of cosine to integer multiples of 2π.

Waves.question: A pulse travelling on a string and encountering a region of higher linear density μ2 > μ1 will:
Waves.a: Transmitted wave slower and reflected wave inverted (if fixed-like impedance mismatch)
Waves.comment: Higher μ reduces v = √(T/μ); reflection occurs; displacement reflection may invert depending on boundary impedance.

Waves.question: The energy density (per unit volume) in a mechanical wave is proportional to:
Waves.comment: Energy stored in oscillation ∝ A² (kinetic + potential contributions).

Waves.question: If a wave's amplitude decays as e^{−α x} while travelling in +x direction, the medium is said to be:
Waves.comment: Exponential spatial decay indicates absorption/attenuation in the medium.

Waves.question: In two-dimensional waves, a plane wavefront means:
Waves.a: Wave surfaces are planes — rays normal to wavefront are parallel
Waves.comment: Plane waves have flat (planar) wavefronts and constant phase across planes.

Waves.question: If a pulse reflects from a free end of a string, the reflected pulse is:
Waves.comment: Reflection at free end (displacement antinode) does not invert the pulse (no phase change).

Waves.question: Which of the following is TRUE about sound waves in air at room conditions?
Waves.a: They are longitudinal and require a medium for propagation
Waves.b: They are transverse and propagate in vacuum
Waves.comment: Sound in air is longitudinal mechanical wave requiring material medium; speed depends on temperature, composition.

Waves.question: If two coherent sources separated by distance d produce Young's fringes on screen at distance D, moving the screen farther away (increasing D) will:
Waves.comment: Fringe spacing proportional to D; farther screen gives wider fringe separation.

Waves.question: What is the physical meaning of wave number k?
Waves.a: Spatial angular frequency (radians per unit length), k = 2π/λ
Waves.comment: k measures number of radians of phase per unit distance along propagation direction.

Waves.question: If a transverse wave on a string has displacement y(x,t) = A cos(k x − ω t), particle velocity at position x is given by:
Waves.a: v_p = ∂y/∂t = A ω sin(k x − ω t) (with sign)
Waves.comment: Particle (transverse) velocity is time derivative: v = −A ω sin(kx − ωt) (sign depends on derivative).

Waves.question: Infrasound refers to sound with frequency:
Waves.comment: Infrasound <20 Hz, audible range roughly 20 Hz–20 kHz, ultrasound >20 kHz.

Waves.question: Which of the following best describes dispersion in optics?
Waves.a: Variation of refractive index with wavelength causing different colors to refract differently
Waves.c: No dependence of speed on wavelength
Waves.d: Change of amplitude with distance only
Waves.comment: Optical dispersion: n(λ) varies → phase velocity c/n varies with λ, causing e.g., prism separation of colors.

Waves.question: A wave packet comprising two frequency components ω and ω+Δω has beat envelope frequency:
Waves.comment: Beat frequency in cycles per second = |ν1 − ν2| = Δω/(2π).

Waves.question: Which experimental observation directly demonstrates interference of waves?
Waves.a: Bright and dark fringes in Young's double-slit experiment
Waves.comment: Interference produces spatial modulation of intensity: alternating maxima/minima fringes.

Waves.question: A wave traveling along a string has power proportional to A² v. If amplitude A halved and tension increased so v doubles, new power relative to original is:
Waves.comment: Power ∝ A² v: new P ∝ (A/2)² × (2 v) = (A²/4) × 2 v = (A² v)/2 → half original.

Waves.question: Which of the following describes evanescent waves?
Waves.a: Spatially decaying waves (exponential) occurring in total internal reflection region
Waves.comment: Evanescent waves decay exponentially away from interface; important in TIR and near-field optics.

Waves.question: If two coherent sources are out of phase by π/2 and equal amplitude, the resultant amplitude is:
Waves.comment: Resultant amplitude = 2A cos(Δφ/2)=2A cos(π/4)=2A×(√2/2)=A√2.

Waves.question: A plane progressive wave with displacement y = A cos(ω t − k x) reaches x = 0 at t = 0 with y(0,0) = A. Phase φ at that point is:
Waves.comment: Set argument ω t − k x = 0 → phase = 0 giving y = A cos 0 = A.

Waves.question: If the amplitude of sound doubles, the increase in sound level in decibels is approximately:
Waves.a: 6 dB (because intensity ∝ A², so 20 log₁₀(2) ≈ 6 dB)
Waves.comment: Doubling amplitude → intensity quadruples? Actually intensity ∝ A² → factor 4 → 10 log₁₀(4)=6.02 dB; amplitude doubling alone gives 6 dB increase in level.

Sound Waves.question: Sound is a mechanical wave that requires:
Sound Waves.comment: Sound is a mechanical disturbance in a medium (solid, liquid or gas); it cannot travel in vacuum.

Sound Waves.question: Sound waves in air are primarily:
Sound Waves.comment: In gases (and liquids) particles oscillate parallel to propagation → longitudinal pressure waves.

Sound Waves.question: Frequency ν, wavelength λ and speed v of a sound wave are related by:
Sound Waves.comment: Fundamental relation for any wave: speed = frequency × wavelength.

Sound Waves.question: Angular frequency ω and wave number k relate to ν and λ by:
Sound Waves.c: ω = π ν and k = π / λ
Sound Waves.comment: ω is temporal angular frequency, k is spatial angular frequency (radians per second/meter).

Sound Waves.question: Typical speed of sound in dry air at 20 °C is about:
Sound Waves.comment: Approximate value at 20 °C: v ≈ 343 m/s. (Water ~1500 m/s; light ~3×10^8 m/s.)

Sound Waves.question: Simple approximate formula for speed of sound in air as function of temperature T (°C) is:
Sound Waves.comment: Rule of thumb: v ≈ 331 + 0.6 T (T in °C).

Sound Waves.question: The speed of sound in an ideal gas can be written as v = √(γ R T / M). Here γ is:
Sound Waves.comment: γ = C_p/C_v; R is universal gas constant and M is molar mass of gas.

Sound Waves.question: In a longitudinal sound wave, nodes of displacement correspond to:
Sound Waves.comment: For longitudinal standing waves, displacement nodes (no particle motion) are pressure antinodes (max pressure fluctuation).

Sound Waves.question: Human audible frequency range is approximately:
Sound Waves.d: All frequencies as in electromagnetic waves
Sound Waves.comment: Typical human hearing: ~20 Hz to ~20 000 Hz (varies with age and individual).

Sound Waves.question: Infrasound refers to sound with frequency:
Sound Waves.comment: Infrasound (<20 Hz) is below human hearing; ultrasound (>20 kHz) is above hearing.

Sound Waves.question: Ultrasound is:
Sound Waves.comment: Ultrasound frequencies are above human hearing and used in imaging, cleaning, etc.

Sound Waves.question: Intensity I of a sound wave is defined as:
Sound Waves.comment: Intensity = average energy transmitted per unit area per unit time (power/area).

Sound Waves.question: Intensity I is proportional to which power of amplitude A of the wave (small amplitudes)?
Sound Waves.comment: For linear waves, energy and intensity scale with amplitude squared.

Sound Waves.question: Sound level in decibels β is given by:
Sound Waves.comment: Reference intensity I₀ commonly taken as 10⁻¹² W·m⁻² in air; use 10 log₁₀ for power quantities.

Sound Waves.question: Doubling the amplitude of a sound wave (all else same) changes sound level by approximately:
Sound Waves.comment: Amplitude ×2 ⇒ intensity ×4 ⇒ 10 log₁₀(4) ≈ 6.02 dB increase.

Sound Waves.question: For a point source radiating power P isotropically, intensity at distance r is:
Sound Waves.comment: Energy spreads over spherical surface area 4πr² → inverse-square law for intensity.

Sound Waves.question: Two sound waves of equal amplitude and frequency are out of phase by π (180°). Their superposition yields:
Sound Waves.comment: Equal amplitudes, opposite phase → cancellation.

Sound Waves.question: Beat frequency produced by superposition of two close frequencies ν₁ and ν₂ is:
Sound Waves.comment: Amplitude envelope oscillates at the difference frequency (beats).

Sound Waves.question: Doppler effect for sound: if source moves toward stationary observer with speed v_s (v_s < v), observed frequency f' is:
Sound Waves.comment: Moving source reduces effective wavelength; approaching source increases observed frequency.

Sound Waves.question: If observer moves toward stationary source with speed v_o, observed frequency is:
Sound Waves.comment: Moving observer encounters more wavefronts per second → frequency scales by (v±v_o)/v.

Sound Waves.question: Shock waves occur when a source moves through a medium:
Sound Waves.a: At speed greater than sound speed (supersonic), forming Mach cone
Sound Waves.comment: Supersonic sources produce conical shock waves; Mach number M > 1.

Sound Waves.question: Mach number M is defined as:
Sound Waves.comment: Mach number compares object's speed to local sound speed; M>1 supersonic, M<1 subsonic.

Sound Waves.question: In a pipe open at both ends of length L, fundamental frequency is:
Sound Waves.comment: Open–open pipe supports antinodes at ends → λ₁ = 2L → ν₁ = v/λ₁ = v/(2L).

Sound Waves.question: In a pipe closed at one end and open at the other of length L, allowed resonant frequencies are:
Sound Waves.comment: Closed–open pipe supports odd harmonics only (λ = 4L/(2n−1)).

Sound Waves.question: For a string fixed at both ends length L, nth harmonic wavelength λ_n is:
Sound Waves.comment: Standing waves on string have nodes at ends; allowed wavelengths are 2L/n.

Sound Waves.question: Nodes in a standing sound wave inside a pipe correspond to:
Sound Waves.a: Positions of zero displacement (for displacement standing wave)
Sound Waves.comment: Nodes are points of zero particle displacement; for pressure nodes/antinodes there is inverse relationship in longitudinal waves.

Sound Waves.question: Acoustic impedance Z of a medium is defined as:
Sound Waves.comment: Acoustic impedance relates pressure amplitude to particle velocity; mismatch causes reflection.

Sound Waves.question: Reflection coefficient for pressure amplitude at boundary between media with impedances Z₁ and Z₂ is:
Sound Waves.comment: Amplitude reflection depends on impedance mismatch; R=0 when Z₁=Z₂ (no reflection).

Sound Waves.question: Absorption of sound in a medium causes intensity to decrease approximately as:
Sound Waves.comment: Attenuation coefficient α describes exponential spatial decay of intensity.

Sound Waves.question: Reverberation time in a room is the time taken for:
Sound Waves.a: Sound level to decay by 60 dB after source stops
Sound Waves.comment: Reverberation time (T₆₀) commonly defined as time for sound to drop 60 dB.

Sound Waves.question: Echo occurs when:
Sound Waves.a: Reflected sound returns after a delay such that it is heard as distinct (typically >0.1 s)
Sound Waves.comment: Separation in time allows perceptible echo; for smaller delays reflections blend into reverberation.

Sound Waves.question: If frequency of a source is 343 Hz and speed of sound is 343 m·s⁻¹, wavelength is:
Sound Waves.comment: λ = v/ν = 343/343 = 1.0 m (nice numerical example).

Sound Waves.question: When a sound wave travels from warm to cold air layer (temperature gradient), it will typically:
Sound Waves.comment: Sound speed depends on temperature (v increases with T) → wavefronts bend toward slower medium (colder air).

Sound Waves.question: Phase velocity of sound in nondispersive medium equals:
Sound Waves.comment: In nondispersive media ω ∝ k linearly, so phase and group velocities are equal and constant.

Sound Waves.question: Resonance in a pipe or cavity occurs when:
Sound Waves.a: Driving frequency matches one of the natural modes → large amplitude standing wave
Sound Waves.b: Driving frequency far from natural modes
Sound Waves.comment: Resonance amplifies motion when driving frequency coincides with natural frequency of system.

Sound Waves.question: A flute (open–open) of length 0.34 m is played with speed of sound 340 m·s⁻¹. Fundamental frequency is about:
Sound Waves.comment: ν₁ ≈ 340/(2×0.34)=340/0.68≈500 Hz (approximate practical calculation).

Sound Waves.question: For sound waves, pressure amplitude and displacement amplitude are:
Sound Waves.a: Related; pressure amplitude ∝ displacement amplitude × frequency
Sound Waves.comment: Pressure variations relate to particle velocity and displacement; higher freq tends to increase pressure amplitude for same displacement.

Sound Waves.question: Fundamental mode in a closed–open pipe has a node at:
Sound Waves.a: Closed end (displacement node) and antinode at open end
Sound Waves.comment: Closed end cannot have particle displacement → node; open end approximates antinode for displacement.

Sound Waves.question: If two speakers emit sound coherently and in phase, at a point equidistant from both speakers the sound will be:
Sound Waves.comment: Equal distance → equal phase → constructive superposition if in phase.

Sound Waves.question: Harmonics of a closed–open pipe are:
Sound Waves.a: Odd integer multiples of fundamental only (1st, 3rd, 5th, ...)
Sound Waves.comment: Closed–open supports odd harmonics due to boundary condition asymmetry.

Sound Waves.question: A tuning fork of frequency 440 Hz is used to produce beats with an unknown tuning fork and beat rate observed is 3 beats/s. The unknown fork's frequency could be:
Sound Waves.comment: Beat frequency |f1 − f2| = 3 → f2 = 440 ± 3.

Sound Waves.question: Sound intensity level increases by 10 dB. That corresponds to what factor change in intensity?
Sound Waves.comment: 10 dB increase = 10^(10/10) = 10× intensity (decibel is logarithmic).

Sound Waves.question: A human perceives a sound as twice as loud when sound level increases by roughly:
Sound Waves.comment: Perception roughly doubles for ≈10 dB increase (subjective; depends on frequency and listener).

Sound Waves.question: Wavelength of a 256 Hz tone in air with v = 343 m·s⁻¹ is:
Sound Waves.comment: Simple calculation: λ ≈ 1.3398 m (≈1.34 m).

Sound Waves.question: The phenomenon where two waves traveling in opposite directions form a stationary pattern is called:
Sound Waves.comment: Superposition of equal amplitude opposite-traveling waves gives standing (stationary) waves with nodes and antinodes.

Sound Waves.question: When sound reflects from a hard rigid surface, the reflected wave is:
Sound Waves.a: Approximately inverted in pressure phase? (pressure reflection has phase change depending on boundary)
Sound Waves.comment: Reflection phase depends on boundary conditions; displacement may invert at rigid boundary while pressure may have antinode there.

Sound Waves.question: Diffraction of sound is more pronounced when:
Sound Waves.a: Wavelength is comparable to or larger than obstacle size or aperture
Sound Waves.b: Wavelength is much smaller than obstacle
Sound Waves.comment: Longer wavelengths bend around obstacles more effectively → audible sound diffracts around obstacles easily.

Sound Waves.question: The relation between RMS sound pressure p_rms and intensity I in air (plane progressive wave) is approximately:
Sound Waves.a: I = p_rms² / (ρ v) (ρ = density, v = sound speed)
Sound Waves.comment: Intensity relates pressure amplitude to medium impedance ρv: I = p_rms²/(ρ v) for plane waves.

Sound Waves.question: If a sound source radiates 1 W uniformly, intensity at 2 m is roughly:
A musical instrument producing a tone with many partials has a property called:
Sound Waves.comment: Timbre distinguishes sounds with same pitch/loudness due to harmonic content and envelope.

Sound Waves.question: For a closed–open organ pipe of length L, the distance between a node and the nearest antinode is:
Sound Waves.comment: Node–antinode separation is λ/4; closed–open fundamental has quarter-wavelength pattern.

Sound Waves.question: In medical ultrasound imaging, higher frequency waves give:
Sound Waves.a: Better resolution but lower penetration depth
Sound Waves.b: Better depth penetration and worse resolution
Sound Waves.comment: Higher frequencies resolve smaller features but attenuate more → less penetration.

Sound Waves.question: The minimum audible intensity (reference) I₀ often used is:
Sound Waves.comment: Reference threshold of hearing at 1 kHz often taken as 10⁻¹² W/m².

Sound Waves.question: A sound of intensity 10⁻⁶ W·m⁻² corresponds to sound level β =
Sound Waves.comment: 10 log₁₀(10⁶) = 60 dB.

Sound Waves.question: Ambient noise that masks weak sounds is called:
Sound Waves.comment: Background/environmental noise reduces audibility of faint signals (masking effect).

Sound Waves.question: If two coherent sources are separated by path difference Δ = λ/2 at a point, interference will be:
Sound Waves.comment: Path difference λ/2 corresponds to phase difference π → destructive interference.

Sound Waves.question: Acoustic resonance in a closed cavity occurs when wavelength λ fits an integer number of half-wavelengths between boundaries suitable for standing waves. For a two-sided rigid cavity, allowed λ satisfy:
Sound Waves.comment: Standing patterns in resonators depend on boundary conditions; simple cavities often have λ = 2L/n modes.

Sound Waves.question: Threshold of pain in sound level is roughly:
Sound Waves.comment: Sound levels above ~120–130 dB are painful and can cause immediate hearing damage.

Sound Waves.question: Acoustic diffraction by an aperture is significant when the aperture size a is:
Sound Waves.a: Comparable to the wavelength λ (a ≈ λ)
Sound Waves.comment: Diffraction effects strongest when obstacle/aperture size is on order of λ.

Sound Waves.question: If a person hears a 1-second delayed echo, the reflecting surface is approximately how far away (assume v ≈ 343 m·s⁻¹ and round trip)?
Sound Waves.a: ≈ 171.5 m (one-way ≈ 171.5 m because round-trip 343 m in 1 s, half is ~171.5 m)
Sound Waves.comment: Round-trip distance = v × time = 343 × 1 = 343 m → reflector one-way ≈ 171.5 m.

Sound Waves.question: A closed tube and an open tube of the same length have different fundamental frequencies. Which is higher?
Sound Waves.a: Open–open has higher fundamental than closed–open of same length (closed–open fundamental is lower)
Sound Waves.comment: Open–open λ₁ = 2L → ν₁ = v/(2L). Closed–open λ₁ = 4L → ν₁ = v/(4L) → open–open fundamental is twice closed–open fundamental.

Sound Waves.question: Human voice pitch is mainly determined by:
Sound Waves.a: Fundamental frequency produced by vocal cord vibration
Sound Waves.comment: Pitch corresponds to fundamental frequency; timbre/loudness influenced by harmonics and amplitude.

Sound Waves.question: Which of the following is not a factor in sound attenuation in air?
Sound Waves.comment: Wind may affect propagation but attenuation primarily due to absorption (molecular relaxation), viscosity, and scattering; wind alone isn't main absorption mechanism.

Sound Waves.question: Resonance frequency of a Helmholtz resonator depends mainly on:
Sound Waves.a: Neck area, neck length and cavity volume
Sound Waves.comment: Helmholtz resonance is like mass–spring: mass of air in neck and compliance of cavity set resonance.

Sound Waves.question: If sound from two coherent sources interferes destructively at a point, small movement of listener may change intensity due to:
Sound Waves.a: Spatial interference fringes (phase change with position)
Sound Waves.comment: Interference pattern causes position-dependent maxima/minima; moving changes relative phase and intensity.

Sound Waves.question: The group velocity of a sound pulse in a dispersive medium indicates:
Sound Waves.a: Speed at which energy or envelope of pulse propagates
Sound Waves.comment: Group velocity dω/dk is relevant for energy and information transport in dispersive media.

Sound Waves.question: A whisper voice usually has much less high-frequency content than shouted voice because:
Sound Waves.a: Whispering excites fewer harmonics (less energy at high frequencies)
Sound Waves.comment: Timbre and spectral content differ with vocal technique; whispers lack strong harmonic excitation.

Sound Waves.question: Acoustic cavitation and bubble noise are most relevant in:
Sound Waves.comment: Rapid bubble formation/ collapse produces strong local pressure pulses (noise) in liquids under intense ultrasound.

Sound Waves.question: When sound passes from one medium to another, its frequency:
Sound Waves.comment: Frequency is set by source; wavelength and speed adjust according to medium properties.

Sound Waves.question: If intensity at point A is 10⁻⁴ W·m⁻² and at point B is 10⁻¹ W·m⁻², difference in dB levels is:
Sound Waves.comment: Ratio = 10³ → 10 log₁₀(1000) ≈ 30 dB.

Sound Waves.question: Spherical spreading loss results in intensity falling as:
Sound Waves.comment: For isotropic point source, energy spreads over sphere area 4πr² → intensity ∝ 1/r².

Sound Waves.question: A sonar ping returns after 2 seconds from a target. Assuming sound speed 1500 m·s⁻¹ in water, target distance is approximately:
Sound Waves.comment: Round-trip distance = v × time = 1500 × 2 = 3000 m → target one-way distance = 1500 m.

Sound Waves.question: Which of the following gives the best transmission (least reflection) of sound across an interface?
Sound Waves.comment: Minimizing impedance mismatch reduces reflection and maximizes transmission.

Sound Waves.question: The term 'sound intensity level' is measured in:
Sound Waves.comment: Decibel scale used for logarithmic measurement of intensity ratios; intensity itself is in W·m⁻².

Sound Waves.question: Frequency of a string fixed at both ends depends on tension T, linear density μ and length L as:
Sound Waves.comment: Transverse wave speed v = √(T/μ) → ν_n = n v/(2L).

Sound Waves.question: A sound wave's phase is advanced by π/2 relative to another wave. The amplitude of their sum (equal amplitudes A) is:
Sound Waves.comment: General formula for resultant of two equal amplitudes with phase Δφ: 2A cos(Δφ/2).

Sound Waves.question: Which of the following statements about musical pitch is true?
Sound Waves.a: Pitch is primarily related to fundamental frequency
Sound Waves.comment: Pitch correlates with perceived fundamental frequency; loudness and timbre also influence perception.

Sound Waves.question: Noise control strategies in rooms include:
Sound Waves.a: Adding absorption material to reduce reverberation and using barriers to block transmission
Sound Waves.comment: Absorption lowers reverberation time; barriers reduce direct and transmitted sound.

Sound Waves.question: Which of the following is NOT a typical characteristic of sound waves used in musical instruments?
Sound Waves.a: Presence of harmonics or overtones shaping timbre
Sound Waves.b: Single pure sine tone only (most instruments have complex spectra)
Sound Waves.comment: Most real instruments produce complex tones with harmonics, not single pure sine waves.

Heat.question: Temperature is a measure of:
Heat.a: Total internal energy of a body
Heat.b: Average kinetic energy of particles in a body
Heat.comment: Thermal temperature reflects mean kinetic energy per degree of freedom of particles (microscopic).

Heat.question: The zeroth law of thermodynamics states:
Heat.b: If A is in thermal equilibrium with B, and B with C, then A is in equilibrium with C
Heat.comment: Zeroth law defines empirical temperature via transitive thermal equilibrium.

Heat.question: Heat and temperature differ because:
Heat.a: Heat is a form of temperature
Heat.b: Heat is energy transferred due to temperature difference; temperature is an intensive property
Heat.c: Temperature is transferred; heat is not
Heat.comment: Heat (Q) is energy transfer; temperature (T) describes thermal state of system.

Heat.question: SI unit of heat (and energy) is:
Heat.comment: Heat is energy; SI unit is joule (J). 1 calorie ≈ 4.186 J.

Heat.question: Specific heat capacity c (of a substance) is defined as:
Heat.a: Heat required per unit mass to raise temperature by 1 K (J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹)
Heat.b: Heat required per mole to change phase
Heat.comment: c = (1/m) (dQ/dT) for small changes; units J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹.

Heat.question: Molar specific heat at constant volume C_V (ideal gas) has units:
Heat.comment: Molar heat capacities are per mole: J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹.

Heat.question: For an ideal monatomic gas, molar heat capacity at constant volume is:
Heat.comment: Equipartition: 3 translational degrees → C_V = 3/2 R.

Heat.question: Mayer's relation between molar heat capacities for an ideal gas is:
Heat.comment: At ideal gas: difference between molar Cp and Cv equals the gas constant R (≈ 8.314 J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹).

Heat.question: Ratio of heat capacities γ is defined as:
Heat.comment: γ (gamma) is important for adiabatic processes; for diatomic at room T γ ≈ 1.4.

Heat.question: For a diatomic ideal gas (at ordinary temperatures), γ is approximately:
Heat.comment: Diatomic (translational + rotational) gives C_V ≈ 5/2 R → γ = (7/2 R)/(5/2 R)=7/5=1.4.

Heat.question: First law of thermodynamics (energy conservation) for a closed system reads:
Heat.comment: Change in internal energy ΔU equals heat added Q minus work done by system W (sign convention common).

Heat.question: In an isothermal process for an ideal gas:
Heat.comment: For ideal gas internal energy depends only on temperature; isothermal ⇒ ΔU = 0.

Heat.question: Work done by an ideal gas during a quasi-static isothermal expansion from V_i to V_f at temperature T is:
Heat.a: W = n R T ln(V_f / V_i)
Heat.c: W = P ΔV only for irreversible
Heat.comment: Isothermal reversible work: W = ∫ P dV = nRT ln(Vf/Vi).

Heat.question: For an adiabatic reversible process of an ideal gas, PV^γ = constant. This relation comes from:
Heat.a: First law with Q = 0 and ideal gas law
Heat.comment: Adiabatic (no heat) + ideal gas + work relations yield PV^γ = const for reversible adiabatic.

Heat.question: Specific latent heat of fusion (ice → water) L_f ≈
Heat.comment: Latent heat of fusion of ice ≈ 3.34×10^5 J/kg; vaporization is ≈ 2.26×10^6 J/kg.

Heat.question: Specific latent heat of vaporization of water at 100 °C is approximately:
Heat.comment: Latent heat of vaporization L_v ≈ 2.26×10^6 J/kg for water at 100 °C.

Heat.question: Calorimetry principle (neglecting losses) states that:
Heat.a: Heat lost by hot bodies = Heat gained by cold bodies
Heat.c: Heat gained is greater than heat lost
Heat.comment: Conservation of energy in calorimetry: sum of heat exchanges in isolated system = 0.

Heat.question: A caloric (old) unit 'calorie' is defined as amount of heat to raise 1 g of water by 1 °C. In SI units 1 cal ≈
Heat.comment: 1 small calorie ≈ 4.186 J (approx. value depending on temperature range).

Heat.question: Thermal expansion coefficient α (linear) relates change in length ΔL to temperature change ΔT by:
Heat.comment: Linear thermal expansion: length increases proportionally to original length and temperature change.

Heat.question: Area expansion coefficient β is approximately related to linear α by:
Heat.comment: For isotropic solids area expansion ≈ 2α and volume expansion ≈ 3α (for small α).

Heat.question: Volume expansion coefficient γ_v (not heat ratio) for isotropic solid is approximately:
Heat.comment: Volume expansion for isotropic: ΔV = 3α V ΔT for small temperature changes.

Heat.question: A bimetallic strip bends with temperature because:
Heat.a: Two metals have different linear expansion coefficients α
Heat.comment: Different thermal expansions produce curvature when bonded — used in thermostats.

Heat.question: Fourier's law of heat conduction in 1D in differential form is:
Heat.comment: Heat flux density (W·m⁻2) is proportional to negative temperature gradient; κ is thermal conductivity.

Heat.question: Thermal conductivity κ has SI units:
Heat.comment: Thermal conductivity: W per metre per kelvin (W·m⁻¹·K⁻¹).

Heat.question: Steady heat conduction through a plane slab (area A, thickness L, κ) with temperature difference ΔT gives rate Q̇ =
Heat.comment: One-dimensional steady conduction: Q/t = κ A (T1−T2)/L.

Heat.question: Thermal resistance R_th of a slab (analogy to electrical resistance) is:
Heat.comment: Temperature difference ΔT = Q̇ R_th where R_th = L/(κA).

Heat.question: If two slabs in series (thicknesses L₁, L₂; same area and κ), total thermal resistance equals:
Heat.comment: Resistances in series add: R_total = L1/(κA) + L2/(κA) = (L1+L2)/(κA).

Heat.question: Newton's law of cooling for convective heat loss states:
Heat.comment: Convective heat transfer proportional to temperature difference; h is convective heat-transfer coefficient.

Heat.question: Stefan–Boltzmann law for thermal radiation from a blackbody: power radiated per unit area is:
Heat.comment: σ ≈ 5.67×10⁻8 W·m⁻2·K⁻4; for real surfaces include emissivity ε: P/A = ε σ T⁴.

Heat.question: Emissivity ε of a real surface lies between:
Heat.comment: ε=1 for ideal blackbody, ε<1 for real materials.

Heat.question: Kirchhoff's law of thermal radiation states that at thermal equilibrium:
Heat.a: Emissivity equals absorptivity for a given wavelength and temperature
Heat.comment: Good absorbers are good emitters at each wavelength in thermal equilibrium.

Heat.question: Thermal diffusivity α (not to be confused with linear expansion α) is defined as:
Heat.comment: Thermal diffusivity measures rate of temperature diffusion; units m²/s.

Heat.question: A material with high thermal conductivity κ and low heat capacity ρ c will have:
Heat.a: High thermal diffusivity (responds quickly to temperature changes)
Heat.comment: High κ speeds conduction; small ρc reduces thermal inertia → fast temperature response.

Heat.question: Specific heat of water (liquid) is approximately:
Heat.comment: Specific heat of water ≈ 4186 J/kg·K (≈4.186 kJ/kg·K).

Heat.question: If 2.0 kg of water is heated from 20 °C to 80 °C, the heat required (ignore losses) Q = m c ΔT is approximately (use c = 4186 J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹):
For a process at constant pressure, heat added equals change in enthalpy ΔH = n C_P ΔT. Enthalpy H is defined as:
Heat.comment: Enthalpy H = internal energy U plus PV term; useful for constant-pressure heating.

Heat.question: In a Joule expansion (free expansion) of an ideal gas into vacuum (insulated container), the temperature of the ideal gas:
Heat.a: Remains unchanged (ΔU = 0 for ideal gas, no work, no heat)
Heat.comment: For ideal gas internal energy depends only on T; free expansion does no work and no heat exchange → T unchanged.

Heat.question: Joule–Thomson effect describes temperature change of a real gas during:
Heat.comment: Joule–Thomson coefficient μ_JT = (∂T/∂P)_H; sign depends on gas and temperature (inversion temperature).

Heat.question: Entropy S in simplest thermodynamic form is defined (for reversible heat transfer) as:
Heat.comment: Entropy differential for reversible process = heat exchange divided by temperature.

Heat.question: Second law of thermodynamics in Kelvin–Planck form states:
Heat.a: No heat engine can convert all heat from a reservoir into work in a cyclic process (no 100% efficiency)
Heat.d: Perpetual motion of first kind exists
Heat.comment: Second law forbids perfect conversion of heat to work in cyclic engines; requires reject heat to sink.

Heat.question: Carnot engine operating between temperatures T_H and T_C has maximum possible efficiency η_Carnot equal to:
Heat.comment: Carnot sets upper bound on efficiency; relies on reversible cycle between two thermal reservoirs.

Heat.question: Clausius statement of second law says:
Heat.a: Heat cannot spontaneously flow from a colder body to a hotter body without external work
Heat.b: Heat always flows from cold to hot spontaneously
Heat.d: Perpetual machines of second kind exist
Heat.comment: Equivalent statement forbids spontaneous heat flow from cold to hot without work input.

Heat.question: A reversible process is one that:
Heat.a: Can be reversed leaving both system and surroundings unchanged (idealized limit)
Heat.comment: Reversible is idealization with infinitesimal gradients; real processes are irreversible and increase total entropy.

Heat.question: In heat conduction through a composite cylindrical wall (pipes), heat flow is analogous to:
Heat.a: Ohm's law (thermal resistances in series or parallel)
Heat.comment: Thermal resistances add like electrical resistances: ΔT = Q̇ R_th.

Heat.question: The blackbody is an idealized object that:
Heat.a: Absorbs all incident radiation and emits with spectrum given by Planck's law
Heat.comment: Blackbody is perfect absorber/emitter; Stefan–Boltzmann and Planck describe its emission.

Heat.question: Wien's displacement law gives peak wavelength λ_max of blackbody at temperature T as:
Heat.comment: Wien constant b ≈ 2.898×10⁻3 m·K; hotter objects peak at shorter λ.

Heat.question: Stefan–Boltzmann law for net radiative heat exchange between two gray surfaces with emissivities ε₁ and ε₂ facing each other can be approximated using which factor?
Heat.a: Effective emissivity including view factors and surface ε reduces net exchange from σ(T₁⁴ − T₂⁴)
Heat.comment: Real surfaces exchange with factor including emissivities and geometry; blackbody case uses ε=1.

Heat.question: Thermocouple generates voltage due to:
Heat.comment: Seebeck effect: junctions at different temperatures produce emf proportional to ΔT.

Heat.question: A Carnot refrigerator requires work W to move heat Q_C from cold to hot reservoir. Coefficient of performance (COP) is defined as:
Heat.comment: COP measures effectiveness (heat removed per unit work input) for refrigerators.

Heat.question: Equipartition theorem states that each quadratic degree of freedom contributes (1/2) k_B T to average energy per particle. Here k_B is:
Heat.comment: k_B relates microscopic energy per particle to temperature.

Heat.question: Root-mean-square speed v_rms of molecules in ideal gas is:
Heat.a: v_rms = √(3 k_B T / m) or √(3 R T / M) for molar mass M
Heat.comment: v_rms = √(3RT/M) (R per mole) or √(3k_BT/m) (per molecule mass m).

Heat.question: Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution describes:
Heat.a: Speed distribution of particles in an ideal gas at equilibrium temperature T
Heat.comment: M-B distribution gives statistical probability of molecular speeds at temperature T.

Heat.question: A heat engine receives Q_H = 5000 J from hot reservoir, rejects Q_C = 3000 J to cold reservoir. Work done W and efficiency η are:
Heat.comment: W = Q_H − Q_C = 2000 J; efficiency η = 2000 / 5000 = 0.4.

Heat.question: If a refrigerator transfers 300 J from cold and expels 400 J to hot reservoir, work input W is:
Heat.comment: Energy conservation: W = Q_H − Q_C = 400 − 300 = 100 J.

Heat.question: In an isobaric process of an ideal gas, heat added equals:
Heat.comment: At constant pressure, heat changes internal energy plus does work; use Cp.

Heat.question: If a gas does work W on surroundings and receives heat Q, change in internal energy ΔU is:
Heat.comment: Careful sign convention: W is work done by system, so subtracted.

Heat.question: For an ideal gas undergoing adiabatic reversible expansion, temperature and volume relation is:
Heat.comment: Derived from PV^γ = const and ideal gas; T V^(γ−1) = const.

Heat.question: When two objects at different temperatures are placed in contact in an isolated system, final equilibrium temperature is found from:
Heat.a: Conservation of energy (sum of heat changes = 0): Σ m c ΔT = 0
Heat.b: Arithmetic mean of initial temperatures always
Heat.comment: Use m c (T_final − T_initial) for each body and set sum zero.

Heat.question: Thermal contact resistance arises due to:
Heat.a: Imperfect contact surfaces and microscopic gaps causing additional resistance to conduction
Heat.comment: Air gaps and surface roughness increase thermal resistance at interfaces.

Heat.question: A perfectly insulating material ideally has thermal conductivity κ equal to:
Heat.comment: Zero κ implies no conductive heat transfer in steady state (ideal insulator).

Heat.question: Radiative heat transfer between two surfaces depends strongly on:
Heat.comment: Net radiative exchange involves T⁴ difference (Stefan–Boltzmann law).

Heat.question: Convection heat transfer coefficient h depends on:
Heat.a: Fluid properties, flow conditions (laminar/turbulent), and geometry
Heat.comment: h is complicated — depends on viscosity, thermal conductivity, flow velocity, etc.

Heat.question: In free (natural) convection, the driving force is:
Heat.a: Buoyancy due to density differences from temperature gradients
Heat.comment: Temperature differences change density → buoyant forces induce flow without external pumping.

Heat.question: In forced convection, heat transfer is enhanced primarily by:
Heat.a: External means (fan, pump) producing fluid motion
Heat.comment: Forced flow increases convective coefficient and mixing → higher heat transfer rates.

Heat.question: Latent heat is the energy required to:
Heat.a: Change phase at constant temperature (e.g., melt, vaporize)
Heat.comment: Latent heat involves phase-change energy with no temperature change during process.

Heat.question: Boiling occurs when:
Heat.a: Vapor pressure equals ambient pressure (bubbles form in bulk)
Heat.comment: Boiling point depends on ambient pressure (lower pressure → lower boiling temperature).

Heat.question: Evaporation differs from boiling because:
Heat.a: Evaporation occurs at surface below boiling point and at all temperatures, while boiling occurs throughout liquid at boiling T
Heat.b: Evaporation requires higher temperature than boiling
Heat.c: Evaporation is always faster than boiling
Heat.comment: Evaporation is surface phenomenon and can occur at any T; boiling is bulk phenomenon at specific T for given pressure.

Heat.question: Thermal camera (infrared) measures:
Heat.a: Infrared radiation emitted by objects related to their surface temperature
Heat.comment: IR cameras detect thermal emission and infer temperature using emissivity models.

Heat.question: If the emissivity ε of a surface is 0.5 and its absolute temperature is T, power emitted per unit area is:
Heat.a: P/A = ε σ T⁴ = 0.5 σ T⁴
Heat.b: P/A = σ T⁴ regardless of ε
Heat.comment: Real surfaces emit ε times blackbody power.

Heat.question: Thermal contact conductance increases when:
Heat.a: Contact pressure increases and surface roughness decreases (better contact)
Heat.b: Contact surfaces are rougher and pressure lower
Heat.d: Surfaces are separated by vacuum only
Heat.comment: Better mechanical contact reduces interface resistance; fillers can also improve conductance.

Heat.question: If the thermal conductivity of steel κ_steel ≈ 50 W·m⁻¹·K⁻¹ and of copper κ_cu ≈ 400 W·m⁻¹·K⁻¹, which statement is correct?
Heat.a: Copper conducts heat much better than steel (≈8× higher κ)
Heat.comment: Higher κ means more heat conduction for given gradient; copper is a very good conductor.

Heat.question: If two lumps of identical material but different masses m₁ and m₂ (same initial temperature) are placed in thermal contact and isolated, equilibrium temperature will be:
Heat.a: Same as initial (if identical and same T — trivial) or found by energy conservation using m c ΔT = 0
Heat.b: Always higher than both initial temperatures
Heat.comment: If initial temperatures equal, equilibrium temperature unchanged; otherwise use Σ m c (T_f − T_i)=0 to find T_f.

Heat.question: A black painted surface compared to a shiny metallic surface usually has:
Heat.a: Higher emissivity and absorbs/emit radiation more effectively
Heat.comment: Black/rough surfaces tend to be good emitters/absorbers; shiny polished metals are poor emitters.

Heat.question: If heat flows from A to B spontaneously, then in a reversible cyclic process the net entropy change of universe is:
Heat.a: Greater than or equal to 0; for irreversible processes > 0
Heat.comment: Second law: total entropy of isolated system increases for irreversible processes, constant for reversible.

Heat.question: Boltzmann's entropy formula S = k_B ln Ω relates entropy S to:
Heat.a: Number of accessible microstates Ω of the system
Heat.comment: Statistical interpretation: entropy measures logarithm of microstate count (k_B is Boltzmann constant).

Heat.question: When ideal gas is compressed quasi-statically and adiabatically, temperature:
Heat.a: Increases (work done on gas raises internal energy)
Heat.comment: Adiabatic compression raises T because W increases internal energy (Q=0).

Heat.question: In practice, best thermal insulation is achieved by:
Heat.a: Materials with low thermal conductivity and containing trapped air pockets (foam)
Heat.comment: Foams and fibrous insulators trap air (low κ) inhibiting conduction and convection (vacuum also good but requires structure).

Heat.question: If two bodies exchange heat reversibly between temperatures T_H and T_C, entropy change of universe is zero only if:
Heat.comment: Reversible exchange yields no net entropy generation; real processes produce positive entropy.

Heat.question: In molecular terms, thermal conductivity in solids is primarily due to:
Heat.a: Phonon (lattice vibration) transport and, in metals, also electron transport
Heat.comment: Heat conduction in solids comes from lattice vibrations (phonons) and free electrons in metals.

Heat.question: If a gas is heated at constant volume, the pressure will:
Heat.a: Increase proportionally to temperature (Gay-Lussac law: P ∝ T at fixed V)
Heat.comment: Ideal gas law: P V = n R T → at constant V, P ∝ T.

Heat.question: Specific heat of solids at low temperatures (T ≪ Θ_D Debye temp) varies approximately as:
Heat.comment: Debye model: heat capacity of solids at low T scales as T³ due to phonon population.

Heat.question: If an ideal gas undergoes isochoric heating, the work done by the gas is:
Heat.comment: No volume change → no PV work; heat increases internal energy only.

Heat.question: The specific heat at constant pressure of air (approx) is about:
Heat.comment: Air (diatomic) Cp ≈ 1005 J/kg·K; water much larger (~4186 J/kg·K).

Heat.question: Latent heat of sublimation is:
Heat.a: Energy required to convert a substance from solid directly to vapor per unit mass
Heat.b: Same as latent heat of fusion always
Heat.comment: Sublimation is solid → gas directly; latent heat of sublimation typically equals sum of fusion + vaporization heats.

Heat.question: Thermal equilibrium between objects means:
Heat.a: They have same temperature (no net heat flow between them)
Heat.comment: Thermal equilibrium implies no net heat transfer between the bodies.

Heat.question: In a heat exchanger, counterflow arrangement is generally more effective than parallel flow because:
Heat.a: It can achieve a greater temperature change of the cold fluid (larger ∆T over length)
Heat.comment: Counterflow maintains larger driving ΔT along exchanger → higher effectiveness.

Heat.question: If the pressure of an ideal gas is doubled isothermally, the volume:
Heat.comment: Boyle's law for isothermal ideal gas: P V = const → V ∝ 1/P.

Heat.question: An engine draws heat from a 600 K reservoir and rejects to a 300 K reservoir. Maximum (Carnot) efficiency is:
A thermal reservoir is a body that can exchange heat without:
Heat.comment: Reservoir has large heat capacity so its temperature is effectively constant during heat exchange.

Heat.question: The Dulong–Petit law approximates molar heat capacity of many crystalline solids at high T as:
Heat.comment: Classical equipartition gives molar Cp ≈ 3R ≈ 24.9 J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹ for many solids at room/high T.

Heat.question: Why does metal feel colder than wood at same temperature to the touch?
Heat.a: Metal has higher thermal conductivity and draws heat away from skin faster
Heat.comment: Faster heat transfer from skin to metal gives sensation of colder despite same actual temperature.

Heat.question: Thermal expansion can cause buckling/thermal stresses if:
Heat.a: Expansion is constrained (not allowed to expand freely)
Heat.comment: Constraint of thermal expansion generates internal stresses (thermal stress σ = E α ΔT for fully constrained).

Heat.question: If a rod of steel (E ≈ 2×10¹¹ Pa, α ≈ 12×10⁻6 K⁻1) of length L is rigidly fixed and heated by ΔT, the thermal stress developed is approximately:
Heat.comment: If no expansion allowed, strain would be αΔT but actual strain 0 → stress σ = E (α ΔT).

Heat.question: If heat conduction across a wall is steady and one-dimensional, the temperature profile is:
Heat.a: Linear between faces (for constant κ and no internal generation)
Heat.comment: With constant thermal conductivity and no sources, 2nd derivative of T = 0 → linear T(x).

Heat.question: Which of the three modes of heat transfer can operate in vacuum?
Heat.comment: Radiation requires no medium; conduction and convection need matter.

Heat.question: The process of heat transfer by moving mass of fluid carrying energy with it is called:
Heat.comment: Convection includes energy transfer via bulk fluid motion; can be natural or forced.
