Magnetism.question: Magnetic susceptibility χ_m of a material relates M and H as:
Magnetism.a: M = χ_m H
Magnetism.comment: χ_m is dimensionless; sign indicates paramagnetic (χ_m > 0), diamagnetic (χ_m < 0), ferromagnetic (large positive).

Magnetism.question: Relative permeability μ_r of a linear material is related to susceptibility by:
Magnetism.a: μ_r = 1 + χ_m
Magnetism.comment: Absolute permeability μ = μ₀ μ_r; μ_r > 1 for paramagnets and ferromagnets (in approximation).

Magnetism.question: Diamagnetic materials are characterized by:
Magnetism.a: Small negative susceptibility (χ_m < 0) and weak repulsion by external B
Magnetism.b: Large positive susceptibility causing strong attraction
Magnetism.comment: Diamagnetism arises from induced currents opposing applied field (Lenz's law); effect is weak and temperature independent.

Magnetism.question: Paramagnetic materials show:
Magnetism.a: Small positive susceptibility (χ_m > 0), weak attraction to B and alignment of atomic moments with field
Magnetism.comment: Paramagnetism due to unpaired electrons; thermal agitation competes with alignment so effect weak and temperature dependent.

Magnetism.question: Ferromagnetic materials are distinguished by:
Magnetism.a: Spontaneous magnetization, strong positive susceptibility and hysteresis
Magnetism.comment: Ferromagnets have domains and exhibit strong magnetization, remanence, coercivity and Curie temperature.

Magnetism.question: Curie temperature T_C is:
Magnetism.a: Temperature above which a ferromagnetic material becomes paramagnetic (spontaneous magnetization vanishes)
Magnetism.comment: Above T_C thermal agitation destroys domain alignment; material loses long-range order.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic hysteresis loop (B vs H) shows:
Magnetism.a: History-dependent magnetization with remanent B and coercive H
Magnetism.b: Single-valued linear relation between B and H
Magnetism.comment: Hysteresis area corresponds to energy loss per cycle (important in transformers and magnetic cores).

Magnetism.question: Coercivity is defined as:
Magnetism.a: Magnitude of reverse H field required to reduce net magnetization (or B) to zero after saturation
Magnetism.comment: High-coercivity materials are used for permanent magnets; low-coercivity for soft magnetic cores.

Magnetism.question: Remanence (residual magnetization) refers to:
Magnetism.a: Magnetization (or B) remaining when external H is reduced to zero after saturation
Magnetism.b: Magnetization at zero field always zero
Magnetism.comment: Remanent magnetization is useful in permanent magnets and indicates memory of previous magnetizing field.

Magnetism.question: Soft magnetic materials are characterized by:
Magnetism.a: Low coercivity and low hysteresis loss (easy to magnetize and demagnetize)
Magnetism.comment: Soft materials (e.g., silicon steel) used in transformer cores to minimize losses.

Magnetism.question: Hard magnetic materials are characterized by:
Magnetism.a: High coercivity and used for permanent magnets
Magnetism.comment: Hard magnets retain magnetization and resist demagnetization (e.g., Alnico, NdFeB).

Magnetism.question: Magnetic field just outside a long straight current-carrying wire at distance r is given by:
Magnetism.a: B = μ₀ I / (2 π r)
Magnetism.comment: Ampère's law for infinite straight wire yields azimuthal field decaying as 1/r.

Magnetism.question: If a conductor carries current I along +x and a second conductor carrying current I along +y intersects in space, the force on a moving positive charge in overlap depends on:
Magnetism.a: Magnetic fields from both currents and particle velocity via v × B
Magnetism.comment: Superposition of magnetic fields and Lorentz force determine resultant force on charge.

Magnetism.question: Hall effect measures:
Magnetism.a: Transverse voltage developed across current-carrying conductor in magnetic field (useful to find sign and density of carriers)
Magnetism.comment: Hall voltage V_H = (B I)/(n q t) gives carrier density n and sign of charge.

Magnetism.question: Hall coefficient R_H for a material with carrier density n and charge q is:
Magnetism.a: R_H = 1/(n q)
Magnetism.comment: Sign of R_H indicates sign of dominant carriers (negative for electrons).

Magnetism.question: If the Hall voltage across a slab of thickness t carrying current I in magnetic field B is V_H, then carrier density n equals:
Magnetism.a: n = B I / (q t V_H)
Magnetism.comment: Rearrange V_H = (B I)/(n q t) to solve for n.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic vector potential A⃗ is related to B by:
Magnetism.comment: Vector potential defined so that its curl gives B; gauge freedom exists (e.g., Coulomb, Lorenz gauges).

Magnetism.question: Boundary condition for B at a surface with surface current K⃗ (sheet current) parallel to surface is:
Magnetism.a: n̂ × (B₂ − B₁) = μ₀ K⃗
Magnetism.c: B continuous always in normal component only
Magnetism.comment: Tangential discontinuity in B across sheet current equals μ₀ times sheet current density (from Ampère's law).

Magnetism.question: Magnetic field of a current loop at distances much larger than loop size resembles:
Magnetism.a: Magnetic dipole field (like electric dipole but different symmetry)
Magnetism.comment: Far-field of loop approximates dipole with moment μ = I A; B falls off as 1/r³ in far zone.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic shielding is commonly achieved by using:
Magnetism.a: High-permeability materials (μ_r ≫ 1) to redirect magnetic flux
Magnetism.comment: Materials like mu-metal concentrate flux and guide it away, reducing field in shielded region.

Magnetism.question: A magnetic circuit analogy maps magnetomotive force (mmf) to:
Magnetism.a: Current in electrical circuit; mmf = N I (turns×current)
Magnetism.comment: Magnetic reluctance ℛ analogous to electrical resistance; Φ = mmf/ℛ where Φ is flux.

Magnetism.question: Reluctance ℛ of a magnetic path of length ℓ, cross-sectional area A and permeability μ is:
Magnetism.a: ℛ = ℓ / (μ A)
Magnetism.comment: Reluctance resists magnetic flux like resistance resists current; μ includes μ₀ μ_r.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic flux linkage λ for a coil with N turns is:
Magnetism.a: λ = N Φ_B (N times flux through one turn)
Magnetism.comment: Flux linkage used in inductance and Faraday's law contexts; λ = NΦ for N-turn coil.

Magnetism.question: Self-inductance L of a coil is defined by:
Magnetism.a: λ = L I (flux linkage proportional to current)
Magnetism.comment: Inductance depends on geometry and medium; energy stored U = ½ L I².

Magnetism.question: Energy stored in magnetic field of inductor with inductance L and current I is:
Magnetism.a: U = ½ L I²
Magnetism.comment: Magnetic energy analogous to capacitor's stored electric energy ½ C V².

Magnetism.question: Mutual inductance M between two coils is defined so that flux linkage in coil 2 due to current I₁ in coil 1 is:
Magnetism.a: λ₂ = M I₁
Magnetism.comment: Reciprocity: M_12 = M_21; depends on geometry and relative orientation.

Magnetism.question: If two identical coils are perfectly coupled, mutual inductance M equals:
Magnetism.a: L (self-inductance) for each coil
Magnetism.comment: Perfect coupling means all flux links other coil → M = L (for identical coils).

Magnetism.question: For a loop carrying current I, magnetic field on axis at distance x from center (for a single circular loop of radius R) decreases approximately as:
Magnetism.comment: Axial field formula B = (μ₀ I R²)/(2 (R² + x²)^(3/2)).

Magnetism.question: Magnetic field inside an infinitely long straight solenoid with permeability μ is:
Magnetism.a: B = μ n I (n = turns per unit length)
Magnetism.comment: Core material increases B by factor μ = μ₀ μ_r; n is turns per unit length.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic force on a straight wire of length ℓ carrying current I in uniform B at angle θ between ℓ and B is:
Magnetism.a: F = I ℓ B sin θ (direction from right-hand rule)
Magnetism.b: F = I ℓ B cos θ
Magnetism.c: F = I B ℓ / sin θ
Magnetism.comment: Force per unit length f = I (dl × B); magnitude uses sin of angle between current direction and B.

Magnetism.question: If two magnetic dipoles μ₁ and μ₂ are placed coaxially a distance r apart, the dipole–dipole interaction potential scales as:
Magnetism.a: ∝ 1 / r³
Magnetism.comment: Dipole fields fall as 1/r³; interaction energy between dipoles scales accordingly.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic field lines inside a bar magnet run from:
Magnetism.a: South pole to North pole (outside) and North to South inside (closed loops)
Magnetism.comment: Field lines form continuous loops: outside from N→S; inside from S→N to close the loop.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic moment of electron due to spin is:
Magnetism.a: Approximately one Bohr magneton μ_B = e ħ /(2 m_e)
Magnetism.comment: Electron spin magnetic moment ≈ μ_B ≈ 9.274×10⁻24 A·m².

Magnetism.question: Bohr magneton μ_B numerical value (approx) is:
Magnetism.comment: μ_B = e ħ /(2 m_e) ≈ 9.274×10⁻24 A·m²; used as scale for atomic magnetic moments.

Magnetism.question: If electron with speed v = 10⁶ m·s⁻¹ moves perpendicular to B = 0.01 T, gyroradius r is (use m_e = 9.11×10⁻31 kg, e = 1.602×10⁻19 C):
Magnetism.comment: Calculation: numerator ≈9.11×10⁻25, denominator ≈1.602×10⁻21 → r ≈5.68×10⁻4? Wait careful: 9.11e-31*1e6 = 9.11e-25; eB = 1.602e-19*0.01 = 1.602e-21; divide ≈ 568 ≈ 5.68×10²? This seems off — the correct value is ≈0.568 m? To avoid confusion, prefer approximate value ~5.7×10⁻4 m. (Note: numeric example is illustrative.)
Magnetism.comment_extra: Numeric examples require careful arithmetic; here r ≈ 5.7×10⁻4 m (0.57 mm) — check calculations when using in exam.

Magnetism.question: Magneto-optical Kerr effect involves:
Magnetism.a: Rotation of polarization of reflected light from magnetized surface (used in magnetic imaging)
Magnetism.comment: Kerr effect used to probe surface magnetization via polarization rotation of reflected beam.

Magnetism.question: Shielding of low-frequency magnetic fields is difficult because:
Magnetism.a: Magnetic fields penetrate easily unless high-permeability materials or superconductors are used
Magnetism.b: Electric shielding methods work for magnetism too
Magnetism.comment: Static magnetic shielding requires materials with high μ or using superconductors (Meissner effect) for perfect expulsion.

Magnetism.question: Earth's magnetic field at surface is approximately:
Magnetism.a: 25–65 μT (microtesla) depending on location
Magnetism.comment: Typical geomagnetic field is tens of microtesla (~0.25–0.65 Gauss).

Magnetism.question: Magnetic declination refers to:
Magnetism.a: Angle between geographic north and magnetic north at a location
Magnetism.b: Angle between field and horizontal plane only
Magnetism.comment: Declination varies by position and time; important for compass corrections.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic inclination (dip) is:
Magnetism.a: Angle between Earth's magnetic field and horizontal plane
Magnetism.comment: Inclination positive when field points downward into Earth (northern hemisphere).

Magnetism.question: Superconductors exhibit which magnetic property below critical temperature?
Magnetism.a: Meissner effect: expulsion of magnetic field (perfect diamagnetism)
Magnetism.comment: Meissner effect distinguishes superconductors from perfect conductors; field expelled from bulk.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic recording (hard drives) stores information by:
Magnetism.a: Orienting small ferromagnetic domains to represent bits (magnetization patterns)
Magnetism.comment: Write heads flip domain orientation locally; read heads detect magnetization using magnetoresistance/GMR/TMR.

Magnetism.question: Giant magnetoresistance (GMR) effect is used in read heads and arises from:
Magnetism.a: Spin-dependent scattering in multilayer magnetic structures leading to large resistance change with applied field
Magnetism.comment: GMR discovery enabled modern high-density magnetic storage; depends on relative magnetization alignment.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic domains in ferromagnets exist to:
Magnetism.a: Reduce overall magnetostatic energy by forming regions of differing magnetization
Magnetism.comment: Domain walls separate regions; external field moves walls to change net magnetization.

Magnetism.question: Domain wall motion contributes to hysteresis because:
Magnetism.a: Pinning sites and energy barriers require additional field to move walls leading to irreversibility
Magnetism.b: Walls move freely without energy cost
Magnetism.comment: Material defects and impurities pin walls; overcoming pinning causes hysteresis and energy loss.

Magnetism.question: Magnetocrystalline anisotropy refers to:
Magnetism.a: Energy dependence of magnetization direction relative to crystal axes (preferred easy axes)
Magnetism.comment: Anisotropy influences coercivity and magnetic behavior; important in permanent magnet design.

Magnetism.question: If a rectangular loop of width w and height h carrying current I is placed in uniform B perpendicular to plane, the net force on the loop is:
Magnetism.a: Zero (opposite forces on opposite sides cancel), but torque may be nonzero
Magnetism.comment: Net force cancels for symmetric loops in uniform B; torque τ = μ × B may rotate the loop.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic field of dipole on axis at distance z (for small dipole) scales as:
Magnetism.a: B ∝ μ / z³
Magnetism.comment: Dipole term dominates at far field and decays as inverse cube of distance.

Magnetism.question: If current in a circular loop is reversed, the direction of its magnetic dipole moment μ is:
Magnetism.a: Reversed (μ changes sign)
Magnetism.comment: μ = I A n̂; reversing I flips μ orientation.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic scalar potential φ_m can be defined in regions where:
Magnetism.a: ∇ × B = 0 (i.e., current-free regions), so B = −∇ φ_m
Magnetism.comment: Scalar potential useful in current-free regions since B is curl-free there; otherwise vector potential used.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic circuit analogy: magnetomotive force mmf equals:
Magnetism.a: N I (turns × current)
Magnetism.comment: Analogous to voltage; mmf drives magnetic flux through reluctance ℛ: Φ = mmf/ℛ.

Magnetism.question: In the presence of nonlinear ferromagnetic core, relative permeability μ_r:
Magnetism.a: Depends on H (nonlinear B–H curve) and exhibits saturation
Magnetism.comment: Ferromagnetic cores saturate at high H; μ_r large near low H but decreases near saturation.

Magnetism.question: If a current I flows in a loop of area A, magnetic moment μ is I A. If loop area doubles keeping I same, μ:
Magnetism.a: Doubles
Magnetism.comment: Magnetic moment proportional to area and current.

Magnetism.question: Which of the following devices uses magnetic fields to accelerate charged particles in circular trajectory?
Magnetism.a: Cyclotron
Magnetism.comment: Cyclotron uses perpendicular B and alternating electric field to accelerate particles in spiraling orbits.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic field inside a current-carrying wire with uniform current distribution at radius r (< R) is:
Magnetism.a: B(r) = μ₀ I r /(2 π R²) (increases linearly with r inside)
Magnetism.b: B(r) = μ₀ I /(2 π r) (same as outside)
Magnetism.comment: Use Ampère's law with enclosed current I_enclosed = I (π r²)/(π R²). Outside (r>R) field ∝ 1/r.

Magnetism.question: If a material has very large μ_r and is used as core in a solenoid, the inductance L typically:
Magnetism.a: Increases proportionally to μ_r
Magnetism.comment: Inductance ∝ μ of core; large μ increases flux linkage and L.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic force between two magnetic dipoles is generally:
Magnetism.a: Much weaker and shorter-ranged than force between charges (falls as 1/r⁴ or 1/r⁵ depending on configuration), effectively 1/r⁴ to 1/r⁵ for forces
Magnetism.comment: Dipole–dipole force decays rapidly with distance (common to see 1/r⁴ or 1/r⁵ depending on geometry).

Magnetism.question: Magnetic field lines are closed loops because:
Magnetism.a: There are no isolated magnetic charges (monopoles) in classical electromagnetism
Magnetism.c: Field lines always start at infinity
Magnetism.comment: Gauss's law for magnetism ∇·B = 0 enforces closed-loop nature of B-lines.

Magnetism.question: If a conductor is moved into a region of nonuniform magnetic field, induced currents (eddy currents) tend to:
Magnetism.a: Oppose the change of flux (Lenz's law) and cause magnetic braking
Magnetism.comment: Eddy currents dissipate energy causing retarding forces useful in magnetic braking.

Magnetism.question: If a coil is wound on a ferromagnetic core and current is ramped up slowly, the flux inside the core may:
Magnetism.a: Saturate at high current producing diminished incremental permeability
Magnetism.comment: Saturation limits flux; beyond saturation increasing current yields smaller increases in B (nonlinear).

Magnetism.question: Magnetostriction is the effect where:
Magnetism.a: Material changes its dimensions when magnetized (used in actuators)
Magnetism.b: Material changes color in a field
Magnetism.c: Magnetic field depends on temperature only
Magnetism.comment: Magnetostrictive materials change length slightly on magnetization — used in sensors and transducers.

Magnetism.question: Which equation is Maxwell–Ampère law in magnetostatics (neglecting displacement current)?
Magnetism.a: ∇ × B = μ₀ J (for steady currents)
Magnetism.comment: In magnetostatics (time-independent), curl of B equals μ₀ times current density J.

Magnetism.question: Which experimental observation supports that magnetic field lines form closed loops?
Magnetism.a: Field lines measured with iron filings reveal closed loop patterns around magnets
Magnetism.b: Magnetic poles can be isolated at will
Magnetism.c: Magnetic fields diverge from a point like charges
Magnetism.comment: Iron filings align tangent to B and reveal closed loops; cutting a magnet yields two smaller dipoles, not monopoles.

Magnetism.question: A magnetic compass needle aligns approximately with:
Magnetism.a: Local direction of Earth's magnetic field (points toward magnetic north with slight declination)
Magnetism.comment: Compasses align with Earth's B field; declination difference from true north varies by location.

Magnetism.question: Magnetic refrigeration exploits which property of materials?
Magnetism.a: Magnetocaloric effect (temperature change on magnetization/demagnetization)
Magnetism.comment: Magnetocaloric materials heat up when magnetized and cool on removal of field — used in emerging refrigeration tech.

Magnetism.question: If you wrap a ferromagnetic core with many turns N and pass current I, the magnetomotive force (mmf) is:
Magnetism.a: mmf = N I
Magnetism.comment: mmf drives magnetic flux through core analogous to voltage driving current.

Magnetism.question: Which phenomenon demonstrates quantum origin of magnetism in materials?
Magnetism.a: Exchange interaction aligning electron spins in ferromagnets (quantum mechanical effect)
Magnetism.comment: Exchange interaction arises from Pauli exclusion and Coulomb correlation leading to spontaneous spin alignment in ferromagnets.

Magnetism.question: In magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), nuclei precess at Larmor frequency ω₀ = γ B where γ is gyromagnetic ratio. Precession is due to:
Magnetism.a: Torque on nuclear magnetic moment in magnetic field
Magnetism.comment: Magnetic moment μ experiences torque μ × B causing precession around B with angular frequency γ B.

Magnetism.question: Spintronics uses electron spin in addition to charge to create devices. One advantage is:
Magnetism.a: Possibility of nonvolatile memory and lower energy switching using magnetic states
Magnetism.comment: Spin-based devices (MRAM, spin valves) exploit magnetic properties for storage and sensing.

Magnetism.question: If a metal plate moves into a static nonuniform magnetic field, induced eddy currents are produced that oppose the change (Lenz's law). These eddy currents cause:
Magnetism.a: Magnetic damping/braking and heating of plate
Magnetism.b: Increase in plate speed without energy input
Magnetism.comment: Eddy current dissipation converts kinetic energy to heat and provides resistive force.

Magnetism.question: Which statement is TRUE about magnetic monopoles in classical electromagnetism?
Magnetism.a: No experimental evidence for isolated magnetic monopoles; Gauss's law for magnetism states ∇·B = 0
Magnetism.b: Monopoles are common in everyday magnets
Magnetism.d: Monopoles are the primary source of B in vacuum
Magnetism.comment: Searches for monopoles continue in high-energy physics, but classical magnetostatics assumes none.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: The Bohr model of the hydrogen atom quantizes which physical quantity?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Angular momentum L = n ħ
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Bohr postulated L = nħ (n = 1,2,...) leading to discrete energy levels E_n = −(13.6 eV)/n².

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Energy of the nᵗʰ level in hydrogen (non-relativistic Bohr) is:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: E_n = −13.6 eV / n²
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Ground-state E₁ = −13.6 eV; energy becomes less negative as n increases.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: The frequency ν of photon emitted in transition n_i → n_f is given by:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: h ν = E_{n_i} − E_{n_f}
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Energy conservation: photon energy equals difference between initial and final atomic energy levels.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Rydberg constant R_∞ (for hydrogen) appears in formula 1/λ = R_∞ (1/n_f² − 1/n_i²). Numerically R_∞ ≈
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Rydberg constant sets spectral line positions (visible Balmer, etc.).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: de Broglie wavelength λ of a particle of momentum p is:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: λ = h / p
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Wave–particle duality: matter waves with λ = h/p; used in electron diffraction.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Photoelectric effect demonstrates the particle nature of light. The kinetic energy K_max of emitted electron is:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: K_max = h ν − φ (φ = work function)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Einstein explained that each photon of energy hν gives an electron at most K_max after overcoming work function φ.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which experiment established the nuclear model of atom (tiny massive nucleus)?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Rutherford α–scattering
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Rutherford observed some α particles scattered at large angles indicating concentrated positive charge (nucleus).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Isotopes of an element differ in:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Number of neutrons (same Z, different A)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.c: Number of electrons in neutral atom
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Isotopes have same atomic number Z but different mass number A (Z + N). Chemical behavior mostly similar.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Atomic mass unit u is defined approximately as:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: 1 u = 1/12 mass of ¹²C ≈ 1.6605×10⁻²⁷ kg
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: 1 u ≈ 1.66053906660×10⁻²⁷ kg; in energy units 1 u ≈ 931.494 MeV/c².

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Mass defect Δm of a nucleus is defined as:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Δm = Z m_p + N m_n − m_nucleus
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.b: Δm = m_nucleus − Z m_p − N m_n
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Mass defect arises because binding energy reduces mass; binding energy E_b = Δm c².

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Binding energy per nucleon is a measure of nuclear stability. Which nucleus has one of the highest binding energy per nucleon?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Iron-56 (Fe-56)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Mid-mass nuclei (around Fe–Ni region) are most tightly bound per nucleon.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Radioactive decay law: number N(t) of nuclei after time t is:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: N(t) = N₀ e^{−λ t}
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Exponential decay with decay constant λ; half-life T₁/₂ = ln2 / λ.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Half-life T₁/₂ is related to decay constant λ by:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: T₁/₂ = ln 2 / λ
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Half-life is time for N to drop to N₀/2.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Activity A of a radioactive sample is defined as:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: A = λ N (decays per second)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: SI unit of activity is becquerel (Bq) = s⁻¹; 1 Curie ≈ 3.7×10¹⁰ Bq.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: α-decay emits:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: A helium nucleus (²⁺He, i.e., ⁴₂He) reducing A by 4 and Z by 2
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: α particles are ⁴₂He nuclei; common in heavy unstable nuclei.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: β⁻-decay converts:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: A neutron → proton + e⁻ + ν̄_e (electron antineutrino)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: β⁻ increases Z by 1; neutrino required for conservation of energy, momentum and angular momentum.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: β⁺-decay (positron emission) occurs when nucleus:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Has excess protons; p → n + e⁺ + ν_e
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.c: Always occurs in heavy nuclei only
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Positron emission reduces Z by 1; energetically allowed only if mass-energy conditions permit (Q>2 m_e c²).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Electron capture by nucleus is:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Inner-shell electron captured by proton → neutron + ν_e (competes with β⁺ if Q small)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Electron capture decreases Z by 1 without emitting positron; often followed by X-ray from atomic rearrangement.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: γ-decay of nucleus typically occurs:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: After α or β decay when daughter nucleus is in excited state; γ photon carries away excess energy
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: γ-rays are high-energy photons; they change nuclear energy state but not A or Z.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Q-value of a nuclear reaction is:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Energy released (Q>0) or absorbed (Q<0) equal to mass difference × c²
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.b: Sum of all kinetic energies always zero
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Q = (mass_initial − mass_final) c²; positive Q means exothermic.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of the following is TRUE about binding energy per nucleon vs A curve?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: It rises quickly for small A, peaks near Fe–Ni (≈8–9 MeV/nucleon), then slowly decreases for heavier nuclei
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Explains why light nuclei can fuse (release energy) and heavy nuclei can fission (release energy).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Nuclear fission (spontaneous or induced) generally releases energy because:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Products have higher binding energy per nucleon (mass defect larger) than heavy parent
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Fission of heavy nuclei into medium-mass fragments releases binding energy → kinetic energy of fragments and neutrons.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Chain reaction in fission reactors requires that:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: At least one of the emitted neutrons per fission causes another fission (multiplication factor k ≥ 1 for criticality)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.d: Reaction stops always after one generation
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Control rods, moderators, and geometry manage k to keep reactor critical (k=1) or subcritical/supercritical.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Thermonuclear fusion releases energy when light nuclei combine because:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Combined nucleus has higher binding energy per nucleon (e.g., ²H + ³H → ⁴He + n releases ≈17.6 MeV)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Fusion of light elements (up to Fe) is exothermic; requires overcoming Coulomb barrier via high temperature/pressure.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Rutherford scattering cross-section experiment showed that α particles scatter at large angles due to:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Coulomb scattering from concentrated positive nuclear charge
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Rutherford formula explained by point-like nucleus producing strong electric field at small impact parameter.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Moseley's law relates the square root of X-ray frequency to:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Atomic number Z (√ν ∝ Z − σ) explaining periodic table ordering
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Moseley found ν ∝ (Z − b)² explaining chemical periodicity and leading to correct Z assignments.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Franck–Hertz experiment provided evidence for:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Quantized energy levels of atoms (inelastic electron collisions excite discrete levels)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Discrete drops in current correspond to electrons losing definite energy quanta equal to excitation energy.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: The unit 'becquerel' (Bq) measures:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Activity (1 Bq = 1 decay s⁻¹)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Curie (Ci) is older unit: 1 Ci ≈ 3.7×10¹⁰ Bq.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Geiger–Müller counter primarily detects radiation by:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Ionization of gas and avalanche multiplication producing measurable pulses
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.b: Direct absorption of photons into semiconductor only
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: G–M tubes produce large pulses for ionizing events; cannot easily discriminate energy of radiation.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Scintillation detectors detect radiation by:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Conversion of ionizing radiation into flashes of light, then photomultiplier amplifies signal
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Scintillators (organic/inorganic) used for photons and particles; pulse height relates to energy.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: A cloud chamber visualizes radiation tracks because:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Ionization by charged particles seeds condensation trails in supersaturated vapor
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Tracks indicate particle type (α: short thick; β: long thin).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Beta decay requires inclusion of neutrino in theory because:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Neutrino carries away missing energy and angular momentum ensuring conservation laws
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.c: Neutrino was predicted to explain α decay
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.d: Beta decay does not emit neutrinos
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Pauli proposed neutrino to conserve energy/momentum; observed in β spectra as continuous without neutrino would violate conservation.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Neutron has approximate mass m_n ≈
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Neutron mass ≈ 1.008665 u ≈ 1.6749×10⁻²⁷ kg; proton mass ≈ 1.007276 u.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which is true about nuclear force (strong force) between nucleons?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Strong, short-range (≈1–2 fm), attractive at intermediate distances and repulsive at very short range
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Nuclear (residual strong) force binds protons and neutrons; extremely short-range and saturating.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Magic numbers in nuclear shell model (numbers of protons or neutrons giving extra stability) include:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Shell closures at these numbers correspond to filled nuclear shells with enhanced binding/stability.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Semi-empirical mass formula (Weizsäcker) includes terms for:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Volume, surface, Coulomb, asymmetry, and pairing energies
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Each term accounts for different contributions to nuclear binding energy; useful to estimate masses and Q-values.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Spontaneous fission is most probable in:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Very heavy nuclei (e.g., some isotopes of U, Pu) where Coulomb repulsion overcomes surface tension
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Spontaneous fission is rare but more likely in very heavy, neutron-rich nuclei.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Radiocarbon dating uses decay of ¹⁴C (half-life ≈ 5730 yr) to estimate age by measuring:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Remaining ¹⁴C activity relative to living organisms
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Assumes initial ¹⁴C/¹²C ratio constant; useful up to ~50,000 years with calibration.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which interaction is responsible for β-decay?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Weak interaction
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Weak force mediates flavor change (neutron ↔ proton) enabling β processes and neutrino emission.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which radiation is stopped most easily (shortest penetration in matter)?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: α-particles (stopped by paper or few cm of air)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: α have high ionization but low range; β penetrates further; γ needs dense shielding (Pb).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Pair production (γ → e⁺ + e⁻) requires photon energy at least:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: 2 m_e c² ≈ 1.022 MeV
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Photon must have energy ≥ 2 m_e c² in presence of nucleus to conserve momentum.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Muon is similar to electron but heavier. Muon decay (μ⁻ → e⁻ + ν̄_e + ν_μ) occurs via:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Weak interaction
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Leptonic weak decay with lifetime ~2.2 μs for muon at rest.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which instrument is best suited to measure γ-ray energy (spectroscopy)?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Scintillation detector with photomultiplier or semiconductor HPGe detector
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: High-purity germanium (HPGe) detectors give excellent energy resolution for γ spectroscopy.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Positron emission tomography (PET) imaging uses radionuclide that undergoes β⁺ decay; the emitted positron annihilates producing:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Two 511 keV γ photons emitted nearly 180° apart
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Coincidence detection of the two 511 keV photons enables localization of annihilation events.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of the following is a common medical radioisotope used for diagnostics (γ emitter)?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Technetium-99m (⁹⁹ᵐTc)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: ⁹⁹ᵐTc emits convenient-energy γ (≈140 keV) and has short half-life (~6 h), widely used in nuclear medicine.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Neutron activation analysis determines element concentrations by:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Irradiating sample with neutrons to produce radioactive isotopes, then measuring emitted radiation
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: NAA is sensitive and non-destructive for trace element analysis.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which process increases mass number A of nucleus by 1 without changing Z?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Neutron capture (n,γ)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Neutron capture adds neutron → A increases by 1; often followed by γ emission.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of the following is true for neutron-rich unstable nuclei far from stability?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: They tend to undergo β⁻-decay converting neutrons to protons
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.d: They always undergo spontaneous fission only
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: β⁻ moves nucleus toward valley of stability by increasing Z.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: In nuclear notation ²³₁₁Na, the subscript 11 denotes:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Atomic number Z (number of protons)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Standard notation: A_Z X where A = Z + N (mass number), Z = proton number.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of the following best describes a neutrino?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: A neutral, very light (nearly massless), weakly interacting particle emitted in β-decay
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Neutrinos rarely interact, making them difficult to detect; types: ν_e, ν_μ, ν_τ and their antiparticles.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which detector can measure charged-particle tracks in a high-energy physics experiment with fine resolution?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Bubble chamber (or modern silicon trackers)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Bubble chambers and modern solid-state trackers visualize or record particle trajectories for analysis.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of following statements about nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) is TRUE?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: NMR exploits precession of nuclear spins in magnetic field and resonance at ω = γ B
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.c: NMR and PET are identical techniques
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: NMR used in chemistry and MRI in medicine; γ is gyromagnetic ratio specific to nucleus.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which quantity remains conserved in all types of radioactive decay (α, β, γ)?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Total energy, linear momentum, angular momentum, electric charge (with neutrino accounting where needed)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.b: Mass separately (mass not strictly conserved due to E=mc²)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Conservation laws (energy, momentum, angular momentum, charge, baryon number) govern decay processes; lepton number also conserved in many interactions.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of the following processes produces neutrons used in research reactors?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Nuclear fission of heavy nuclides (e.g., ²³⁵U splitting releases neutrons)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Fission fragments and prompt neutrons from fission provide neutron source for reactors.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: The mean lifetime τ_mean of an unstable nucleus is related to half-life by:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: τ_mean = 1/λ = T₁/₂ / ln 2
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Mean lifetime is reciprocal of decay constant; longer mean life than half-life by factor 1/ln2 ≈ 1.443.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which reaction is an example of induced radioactivity (activation)?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: ¹⁴N (n,p) ¹⁴C produced when nitrogen captures neutron
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Activation by neutron capture transforms stable nuclei to radioactive isotopes used in many applications.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which phenomenon demonstrates wave nature of electrons?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Electron diffraction by crystal (Davisson–Germer experiment)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Diffraction patterns confirm de Broglie wavelength for electrons.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which is the correct relation between energy (in eV) and wavelength (in nm) for photons approximately?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Useful quick conversion: E(eV) = 1240 / λ(nm).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which process can change one chemical element into another?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Nuclear reaction or radioactive decay (change in Z)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Transmutation requires changing nucleus (Z); chemical reactions rearrange electrons only.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which nuclear reaction notation (a,b) denotes incoming particle a and outgoing b? Example (n,α) means:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Incident neutron causes emission of α-particle (daughter nucleus accordingly changed)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: General (a,b) notation succinctly indicates incoming/outgoing particles in nuclear reactions.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of the following is used as control material in thermal reactors to absorb excess neutrons?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Control rods made of materials with high neutron absorption cross-section (e.g., cadmium, boron, hafnium)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Control rods adjust reactivity by absorbing neutrons; moderators (e.g., water, graphite) slow neutrons but do not primarily absorb them.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which cross-section for nuclear reactions depends strongly on neutron energy and target nucleus?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Microscopic cross-section σ (units barns, 1 b = 10⁻²⁸ m²)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Cross-sections vary with energy (resonances) and target; unit barn widely used.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of the following is a signature of α-particle emission in a radiation detector?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Short, densely ionizing track with large pulse amplitude in detectors
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: α particles deposit energy over a short range, producing strong ionization.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which nuclear process powers the Sun and stars?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Nuclear fusion (proton–proton chain and CNO cycle)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Fusion of H into He releases enormous energy sustaining stellar radiation.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which statement about spontaneous radioactive decay is correct?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: It is a random process with a constant probability per nucleus per unit time
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.b: It occurs at predictable times for individual nuclei
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.c: External environment (except extreme conditions) determines exact decay moment
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.d: It is deterministic for each nucleus
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Decay is probabilistic; only statistical behaviour of large ensembles is predictable.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of the following is an example of induced fission?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Absorption of thermal neutron by ²³⁵U producing fission fragments and neutrons
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.b: Spontaneous emission of α from ²³⁸U
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Thermal-neutron induced fission is basis of nuclear reactors.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of the following is commonly used as a neutron moderator in reactors to slow down fast neutrons?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Light water (H₂O), heavy water (D₂O) or graphite (carbon)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Moderators reduce neutron energy to thermal range increasing fission probability in fissile fuels.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Beta spectrum from β-decay is continuous because:
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Energy is shared between electron and neutrino (three-body decay)
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.b: Electron is emitted with fixed energy always
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Continuous kinetic energy distribution led to postulation of neutrino to conserve energy and momentum.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which constant gives relation E = m c² (mass–energy equivalence)?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: c (speed of light) with c ≈ 3.00×10⁸ m·s⁻¹
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Mass can be converted to energy; used to compute binding energy from mass defect.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of these is NOT a common application of nuclear physics?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Chemical bond determination by ordinary titration
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.b: Medical imaging (PET, SPECT), radiotherapy, power generation, radiocarbon dating
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Titration is classical chemistry and not a nuclear technique.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which particle mediates strong interaction between quarks (in quantum chromodynamics)?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Gluon
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Gluons carry color charge and bind quarks into nucleons; outside basic syllabus but relevant to nuclear forces.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of following is true for electron binding energies in atoms?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Inner-shell (K) electrons have larger binding (higher |E|) than outer-shell electrons
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.b: Outer electrons always more tightly bound
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.c: All electrons have same binding energy
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: K-shell binding energies scale roughly as Z² and produce characteristic X-rays when vacancies filled.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which effect describes shift in atomic spectral lines due to change in nuclear charge Z among isotopes (used in Moseley's law)?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Isotope shift relates to nuclear mass and volume effects; Moseley related frequency to Z
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.b: No shift occurs with Z change
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Isotope shift small but measurable; Moseley showed strong dependence of X-ray lines on Z.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.question: Which of the following best describes 'magic numbers' effect experimentally?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.a: Nuclei with magic proton or neutron numbers show extra stability, large binding, and low reaction cross-sections
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.comment: Magic numbers correspond to closed shells in nuclear shell model.

Electronics.question: Ohm's law relates voltage V, current I and resistance R as:
Electronics.a: V = I R
Electronics.comment: Basic circuit law for linear resistors: voltage drop equals current times resistance.

Electronics.question: Unit of electrical resistance is:
Electronics.a: Ohm (Ω)

Electronics.question: Capacitance C of a parallel-plate capacitor (area A, separation d, dielectric permittivity ε) is:
Electronics.a: C = ε A / d
Electronics.comment: Capacitance increases with area and dielectric permittivity, decreases with plate separation.

Electronics.question: Reactance of a capacitor X_C at frequency f is:
Electronics.a: X_C = 1 / (2 π f C)
Electronics.comment: Capacitive reactance decreases with frequency and capacitance.

Electronics.question: Reactance of an inductor X_L at frequency f is:
Electronics.a: X_L = 2 π f L
Electronics.comment: Inductive reactance increases with frequency and inductance.

Electronics.question: Impedance Z of series R and X_L (inductive) is:
Electronics.a: Z = R + j X_L
Electronics.comment: Impedance is complex: real part R, imaginary part jX (j = √(−1)).

Electronics.question: Resonant frequency f₀ of an LC circuit (ideal) is:
Electronics.comment: Series or parallel resonance frequency defined by ω₀ = 1/√(LC), f₀ = ω₀/2π.

Electronics.question: Quality factor Q of a resonant circuit is:
Electronics.a: Q = (ω₀ L) / R (for series R-L-C)
Electronics.comment: Q measures sharpness; higher Q → narrower bandwidth.

Electronics.question: Cutoff frequency f_c of an RC low-pass filter (R series, C to ground) is:
Electronics.a: f_c = 1 / (2 π R C)
Electronics.comment: At f_c output is 1/√2 (≈0.707) of low-frequency value (−3 dB point).

Electronics.question: Decibel (dB) for voltage ratio V₂/V₁ (same impedance) is defined as:
Electronics.a: dB = 20 log₁₀ (V₂ / V₁)
Electronics.comment: For power ratio use 10 log₁₀(P₂/P₁); voltage uses 20 log because power ∝ V².

Electronics.question: In a voltage divider with R₁ and R₂ in series across V_in, output V_out at node between R₁ and R₂ (to ground) is:
Electronics.a: V_out = V_in × (R₂ / (R₁ + R₂))
Electronics.comment: Standard divider; ensure loading by next stage is negligible.

Electronics.question: A diode conducts significantly when forward bias exceeds approximately (for a silicon diode):
Electronics.comment: Silicon diode forward turn-on ≈ 0.6–0.7 V; germanium ≈ 0.2–0.3 V, Schottky lower.

Electronics.question: Zener diode is typically used as:
Electronics.a: Voltage regulator in reverse breakdown region
Electronics.comment: Zener operates in reverse avalanche at specified Vz to clamp/regulate voltage.

Electronics.question: Full-wave bridge rectifier (ideal diodes) with sinusoidal input gives DC output average (V_dc) approximately equal to:
Electronics.a: V_dc ≈ (2 V_m) / π where V_m is peak of input? (Actually average of rectified sine is 2 V_m/π).
Electronics.comment: Average of full-wave rectified sine = 2 V_m / π; DC after filtering differs (≈V_m − V_drops).

Electronics.question: Ripple factor r for a full-wave rectifier with large smoothing capacitor approximates:
Electronics.a: r ≈ 1 / (4 √3 f R C) (approx for heavy load) — but commonly r ≈ 1/(4√3 f R C)
Electronics.comment: Ripple depends on load resistance R, smoothing capacitance C and ripple frequency (2f for full-wave). Exact forms vary by approximation.

Electronics.question: A transformer with turns ratio N_p:N_s gives ideal voltage ratio V_s/V_p as:
Electronics.a: V_s / V_p = N_s / N_p
Electronics.comment: Ideal transformer: voltage scales with turns; current scales inversely.

Electronics.question: For an ideal transformer, currents in primary and secondary relate as:
Electronics.a: I_p / I_s = N_s / N_p (or I_s / I_p = N_p / N_s)
Electronics.comment: Power (ignoring losses) conserved: V_p I_p ≈ V_s I_s.

Electronics.question: A transistor operated in active region (BJT) is used as:
Electronics.a: Amplifier (collector–base reverse biased, base–emitter forward biased)
Electronics.comment: In active mode BJT provides current gain; in saturation used as switch ON, in cutoff as OFF.

Electronics.question: Which terminal is common to emitter-follower (BJT) configuration providing voltage buffering with unity gain?
Electronics.a: Emitter is output, configuration is common-collector
Electronics.comment: Emitter-follower (common-collector) gives ~unity voltage gain, high input impedance and low output impedance.

Electronics.question: MOSFET gate controls channel by:
Electronics.a: Electric field (voltage) across gate oxide — virtually no DC gate current
Electronics.b: Injection of current into gate always
Electronics.comment: MOSFET is voltage-controlled device; input gate is insulated (thin oxide) and negligible DC gate current (except leakage).

Electronics.question: Enhancement-mode n-channel MOSFET conducts when V_GS is:
Electronics.a: Greater than threshold V_TH (V_GS > V_TH)
Electronics.comment: Enhancement MOSFET needs gate voltage to induce channel; depletion-mode is normally-on.

Electronics.question: Junction Field Effect Transistor (JFET) controls current by:
Electronics.a: Reverse-biasing gate–channel PN junction to pinch off channel (voltage-controlled)
Electronics.comment: JFET gate is reverse biased and there is very small gate DC current; pinch-off voltage defines channel control.

Electronics.question: In an op-amp ideal assumptions include:
Electronics.a: Infinite open-loop gain, infinite input impedance, zero output impedance, infinite bandwidth
Electronics.comment: Real op-amps approximate these idealizations; practical parameters include finite gain, offset, CMRR, slew rate.

Electronics.question: Open-loop configuration of op-amp is usually used for:
Electronics.a: Comparator (saturates to rails); for linear amplification feedback is used
Electronics.comment: Open-loop gain is very high so tiny differential input drives output to saturation; feedback stabilizes gain.

Electronics.question: Inverting op-amp configuration has closed-loop gain − R_f / R_in. The sign indicates:
Electronics.a: Inversion (180° phase shift) between input and output
Electronics.comment: Magnitude set by resistor ratio; negative sign indicates phase inversion.

Electronics.question: Non-inverting op-amp closed-loop gain is:
Electronics.comment: Non-inverting input sets positive gain with unity or greater depending on feedback network.

Electronics.question: Slew rate of an op-amp is:
Electronics.a: Maximum rate of change of output voltage (V/s), limits large-signal bandwidth and high-frequency distortion
Electronics.comment: Slew rate (e.g., V/μs) constrains how fast output can change; fast pulses require high slew rate to avoid distortion.

Electronics.question: Common-mode rejection ratio (CMRR) of an amplifier measures:
Electronics.a: Ability to reject signals common to both inputs: CMRR = A_d / A_cm (large is better)
Electronics.comment: High CMRR means amplifier amplifies difference signal but rejects common-mode noise.

Electronics.question: An instrumentation amplifier is typically used for:
Electronics.a: Accurate amplification of small differential signals with high CMRR and adjustable gain
Electronics.comment: Used in sensor interfaces because of input buffering and precise gain control.

Electronics.question: Schmitt trigger provides:
Electronics.a: Hysteresis (two different threshold voltages) to clean noisy digital signals
Electronics.comment: Schmitt removes chatter by requiring input to cross different thresholds for rising vs falling transitions.

Electronics.question: 555 timer in astable mode functions as:
Electronics.a: Oscillator (free-running multivibrator) producing square wave; frequency set by R and C
Electronics.comment: Frequency f ≈ 1.44 / ((R_A + 2 R_B) C) for standard astable configuration.

Electronics.question: Phase-Locked Loop (PLL) basic functions include:
Electronics.a: Frequency synthesis, frequency tracking, clock recovery and demodulation
Electronics.comment: PLL locks VCO phase to reference via phase detector and loop filter; widely used in comms and synthesizers.

Electronics.question: A push–pull Class AB amplifier is chosen because:
Electronics.a: It offers better efficiency than Class A and lower crossover distortion than Class B (with slight bias)
Electronics.c: It is only used for digital logic
Electronics.comment: Class AB uses complementary devices with small bias to reduce crossover distortion while keeping decent efficiency.

Electronics.question: Differential amplifier amplifies:
Electronics.a: Difference between two inputs (V_out ∝ V₁ − V₂), rejecting common-mode
Electronics.comment: Differential pair is core of op-amp input stage; high common-mode rejection desirable.

Electronics.question: A current mirror is used to:
Electronics.a: Copy a reference current to other branches—used for biasing and active loads
Electronics.comment: Basic current mirror uses matched transistors to replicate currents with proportional scaling.

Electronics.question: Saturation region of MOSFET (for V_DS large) is used for:
Electronics.a: Analog amplification (constant-current region) in long-channel devices approximated as I_D ∝ (V_GS − V_TH)²
Electronics.comment: Saturation here means channel pinch-off with current relatively independent of V_DS (over a range).

Electronics.question: Body diode in power MOSFET refers to:
Electronics.a: Intrinsic diode from body/drain structure conducting when V_DS reverses; affects switching behavior
Electronics.comment: Body diode provides free-wheeling path; designers account for its conduction during switching.

Electronics.question: Comparator differs from op-amp used as comparator because:
Electronics.a: Comparator is optimized for fast saturation switching and may lack internal compensation; op-amp is for linear feedback
Electronics.c: Comparator amplifies analog signals with feedback
Electronics.comment: Using op-amp as comparator can be undesirable due to slow response and potential latch-up.

Electronics.question: A Schottky diode is preferred in high-speed rectification because:
Electronics.a: It has lower forward voltage drop and very fast switching (no minority-carrier storage)
Electronics.d: It has higher forward voltage than silicon diode
Electronics.comment: Schottky uses metal–semiconductor junction; good for low-loss, fast switching applications.

Electronics.question: A microcontroller differs from microprocessor because:
Electronics.a: MCU integrates CPU, memory and peripherals (I/O, timers, ADC) on one chip for embedded control
Electronics.comment: Microcontrollers are self-contained computers for embedded systems; microprocessors need external peripherals.

Electronics.question: ADC resolution N bits with full-scale range V_fs has quantization step ΔV =:
Electronics.a: ΔV = V_fs / (2^N)
Electronics.comment: Each additional bit halves ΔV (improves resolution); effective number of levels = 2^N.

Electronics.question: Nyquist sampling theorem states sampling frequency f_s must be at least:
Electronics.a: f_s ≥ 2 f_max (twice highest frequency component) to avoid aliasing
Electronics.comment: Sampling at or above Nyquist rate avoids aliasing; in practice use guard bands and anti-alias filters.

Electronics.question: R-2R ladder DAC advantage is:
Electronics.a: Uses only two resistor values (R and 2R) simplifying matching and scaling
Electronics.comment: R-2R ladder is simple and scalable for binary-weighted DACs.

Electronics.question: Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) controls average output by:
Electronics.a: Varying duty cycle of fixed-amplitude pulses to change average power
Electronics.b: Changing amplitude of sine wave only
Electronics.comment: PWM is widely used in motor control and power delivery; filtered PWM approximates analog voltage.

Electronics.question: Logic family CMOS stands for:
Electronics.a: Complementary Metal–Oxide–Semiconductor
Electronics.comment: CMOS uses complementary p- and n-MOSFETs; low static power consumption.

Electronics.question: TTL logic family stands for:
Electronics.a: Transistor–Transistor Logic
Electronics.comment: TTL is bipolar logic family known for speed and moderate power; CMOS replaced TTL in many areas.

Electronics.question: Propagation delay of a digital gate is:
Electronics.a: Time between input transition and output response (affects maximum clock frequency)
Electronics.comment: Delays accumulate in logic paths, determining timing constraints and setup/hold times for flip-flops.

Electronics.question: A flip-flop is used to store:
Electronics.a: One bit of digital information (bistable circuit)
Electronics.comment: Flip-flops form registers, counters and memory elements in digital systems.

Electronics.question: SR latch has inputs S and R. To avoid forbidden state, when both S=1 and R=1 in NOR SR latch:
Electronics.a: State is invalid/indeterminate (should be avoided)
Electronics.comment: Cross-coupled NOR SR latch has undefined output for S=R=1; gated versions or JK flip-flop avoid this.

Electronics.question: Edge-triggered D flip-flop captures input on:
Electronics.a: Specified clock edge (rising or falling) and holds until next triggering edge
Electronics.comment: D flip-flops used as synchronous storage elements in sequential logic.

Electronics.question: Multiplexer (MUX) performs which operation?
Electronics.a: Selects one of many inputs to appear at single output under control of select lines
Electronics.comment: DEMUX does reverse: single input to one of many outputs.

Electronics.question: Encoder circuit converts:
Electronics.a: One-of-n active input to binary-coded output
Electronics.c: Serial data to parallel without control
Electronics.comment: Priority encoders handle multiple active inputs with defined priorities.

Electronics.question: A ripple counter is an example of which kind of counter?
Electronics.a: Asynchronous counter (flip-flops triggered by output of preceding stage)
Electronics.comment: Ripple counters are simpler but have propagation delay accumulation; synchronous counters avoid ripple.

Electronics.question: Phase margin in a feedback amplifier refers to:
Electronics.a: Additional phase before reaching −180° at unity loop gain; positive margin indicates stability
Electronics.b: Difference between input and output amplitude
Electronics.comment: Phase margin and gain margin are used in control/feedback design to ensure stable response without oscillation.

Electronics.question: Negative feedback applied to amplifier generally:
Electronics.a: Reduces gain but improves bandwidth, linearity and stability
Electronics.comment: Trade-offs: lower gain but benefits in performance; feedback topology matters (series/shunt, voltage/current).

Electronics.question: Positive feedback is used to create:
Electronics.a: Oscillators and regenerative (latching) circuits such as Schmitt triggers
Electronics.comment: Positive feedback can sustain oscillation if Barkhausen criteria (loop gain = 1 and phase shift = 0/360°) met.

Electronics.question: Wien-bridge oscillator uses which components to set frequency?
Electronics.a: RC network in bridge; frequency f ≈ 1 / (2 π R C)
Electronics.comment: Wien-bridge offers low-distortion sine generation; amplitude stabilization required (lamp or AGC).

Electronics.question: Crystal oscillator frequency stability is high because:
Electronics.a: Quartz crystal has very high Q and stable mechanical resonance
Electronics.comment: Crystals require temperature compensation for best stability but still outperform LC oscillators.

Electronics.question: Bootstrap circuit is often used to:
Electronics.a: Increase input impedance of buffer stages (e.g., emitter follower with bootstrapped bias network)
Electronics.comment: Bootstrapping uses feedback to raise input impedance by returning a portion of output to input bias node.

Electronics.question: Thermal runaway in BJT occurs because:
Electronics.a: Increase in temperature increases collector current which further increases power dissipation, raising temperature (positive feedback)
Electronics.b: Temperature decreases drive current up always
Electronics.comment: Proper heat sinking and negative feedback bias stabilize operating point to avoid runaway.

Electronics.question: A photo-diode operated in photoconductive mode (reverse-biased) provides:
Electronics.a: Faster response and linearity, with dark current and need for bias
Electronics.comment: Photodiodes used in reverse bias for speed and improved linearity; phototransistors are slower but higher gain.

Electronics.question: LED (Light-Emitting Diode) emits light when:
Electronics.a: Forward-biased electrons and holes recombine in semiconductor bandgap releasing photons of energy ≈ E_g
Electronics.comment: LED wavelength determined by semiconductor bandgap energy.

Electronics.question: A phototransistor differs from a photodiode in that:
Electronics.a: Phototransistor provides internal gain (current amplification) but is slower and less linear than photodiode
Electronics.comment: Phototransistors amplify photocurrent; useful for simple light sensing but not for precision/high-speed photometry.

Electronics.question: Hysteresis in comparator via positive feedback prevents:
Electronics.a: Chattering near threshold due to noise (provides clean transitions)
Electronics.comment: Hysteresis defines upper and lower thresholds to avoid oscillation from input noise.

Electronics.question: A digital-to-analog converter (DAC) that uses binary-weighted resistors must ensure:
Electronics.a: Precise resistor matching for accurate weights; R-2R ladder reduces resistor variety needed
Electronics.d: It always produces perfect sine waves
Electronics.comment: Resistor tolerances limit linearity and accuracy; R-2R architecture simplifies matching.

Electronics.question: Sallen–Key topology is commonly used for:
Electronics.a: Second-order active filters (low-pass / high-pass) using op-amps
Electronics.comment: Sallen–Key provides easy implementation of Butterworth, Bessel and other 2nd-order responses with unity gain or gain stage.

Electronics.question: Common-Emitter BJT amplifier provides:
Electronics.a: Voltage gain and phase inversion (approx −), moderate input impedance and moderate output impedance
Electronics.comment: CE is popular amplifier topology; emitter resistor provides feedback and stability.

Electronics.question: Emitter follower (common-collector) is primarily used as:
Electronics.a: Voltage buffer with high input and low output impedance (no voltage inversion)
Electronics.comment: Useful for impedance matching and driving low-impedance loads.

Electronics.question: Darlington pair offers:
Electronics.a: Very high current gain (product of individual transistor gains) but higher V_BE and slower switching
Electronics.comment: Darlington uses two transistors cascaded so overall β ≈ β₁ × β₂; V_BE ≈ 2×0.7 V for silicon pair.

Electronics.question: Emitter bias with negative feedback stabilizes operating point by:
Electronics.a: Providing temperature and β-insensitivity via emitter degeneration (emitter resistor)
Electronics.comment: Emitter resistor adds negative feedback: increase in I increases V_E lowering V_BE and limiting current.

Electronics.question: In a switch-mode power supply (SMPS), PWM is used to:
Electronics.a: Control duty cycle of switching device to regulate output with high efficiency
Electronics.d: To operate only at low frequencies
Electronics.comment: SMPS efficiency high because switching elements operate near saturation or cutoff, minimizing conduction and switching losses when designed properly.

Electronics.question: A band-pass filter passes frequencies:
Electronics.a: Within a specified range between f_low and f_high while attenuating others
Electronics.comment: Band-pass can be formed by series RLC or active filter designs.

Electronics.question: Transmission line characteristic impedance Z₀ depends on:
Electronics.a: Geometry and dielectric: Z₀ = √(L'/C') per unit length
Electronics.comment: L' and C' are inductance and capacitance per unit length; matching Z₀ prevents reflections.

Electronics.question: Reflection coefficient Γ at load for transmission line is:
Electronics.a: Γ = (Z_L − Z₀) / (Z_L + Z₀)
Electronics.comment: Γ magnitude 0 for matched load (Z_L = Z₀); 1 for open- or short-circuit depending on sign.

Electronics.question: Matching a source to transmission line minimizes:
Electronics.a: Reflections and maximizes power transfer (impedance matching)
Electronics.comment: Use transformers, quarter-wave transformers, resistive pads or L-matching networks for matching.

Electronics.question: AC coupling between amplifier stages uses capacitor to:
Electronics.a: Block DC while passing AC signals (sets low-frequency cutoff with input impedance)
Electronics.comment: Coupling capacitor and input resistance form high-pass corner f_c = 1/(2π R_in C).

Electronics.question: Peak detector circuit often uses diode and capacitor to:
Electronics.a: Capture and hold peak value of an input waveform (with discharge through resistor defining hold time)
Electronics.comment: Diode charges cap to peak minus diode drop; leakage and load determine hold decay.

Electronics.question: An RC integrator approximates integration when input frequency is:
Electronics.a: Much higher than 1/(R C) (signal period ≪ RC), so capacitor voltage ~ integral of input
Electronics.comment: At high frequency the capacitor impedance is small and the output approximates scaled time integral of input.

Electronics.question: A transimpedance amplifier (current-to-voltage) commonly uses:
Electronics.a: An op-amp with feedback resistor R_f where V_out = − I_in × R_f
Electronics.comment: Transimpedance amps are used with photodiodes to convert photocurrent to voltage with low noise and good bandwidth.

Electronics.question: Protection diodes across inductive loads (flyback diodes) prevent:
Electronics.a: High voltage spikes when current is interrupted (by providing safe current path)
Electronics.comment: Flyback diode clamps voltage to diode drop preventing device damage; for switches use fast recovery diodes or snubbers as needed.

Electronics.question: Bridge rectifier with a smoothing capacitor provides DC close to:
Electronics.a: V_DC ≈ V_peak − 2 V_d (diode drops) where V_peak is AC peak
Electronics.comment: Bridge uses two diode drops in conduction path; with large capacitor V_DC approaches V_peak minus drops and ripple.

Electronics.question: ESR (Equivalent Series Resistance) of a capacitor affects:
Electronics.a: Ripple, heating and high-frequency performance; lower ESR is better for power applications
Electronics.comment: ESR causes dissipation at ripple currents and raises temperature; important in switching supplies.

Electronics.question: An op-amp integrator circuit will saturate if input DC offset present because:
Electronics.a: Integrator accumulates DC error over time producing ramp to supply limit
Electronics.b: Integrator filters DC to zero always
Electronics.comment: Practical integrators include reset paths or bias compensation to prevent saturation from offsets.

Electronics.question: Analog multiplexer sample-and-hold circuits require:
Electronics.a: Low on-resistance switch and low leakage capacitor to hold sampled voltage accurately
Electronics.comment: Analog switches (CMOS) and hold capacitor form S/H; switch charge injection and aperture time affect accuracy.

Electronics.question: Which is true about pull-up and pull-down resistors in digital inputs?
Electronics.a: They define default logic level when input left open; values must balance speed and power consumption
Electronics.d: They short input to ground always
Electronics.comment: Strong pull-ups give fast edges but more power; weak values save power but slower transitions.

Electronics.question: Open-drain (or open-collector) outputs require:
Electronics.a: External pull-up resistor to define high level (device only actively pulls low)
Electronics.comment: Open-drain outputs allow wired-AND connections and level shifting with pull-up to required voltage.

Electronics.question: A Bistable multivibrator has:
Electronics.a: Two stable states and acts as memory element (flip-flop)
Electronics.comment: Monostable has one stable and one quasi-stable; astable has no stable states (oscillator).

Electronics.question: Which statement about bootstrap LED driver is true?
Electronics.a: Bootstrapping can raise effective gate voltage in high-side MOSFET drivers enabling V_GS above supply
Electronics.c: Bootstrap only used in audio amps
Electronics.comment: Bootstrap capacitors provide gate charge for high-side switching in half-bridge/topologies.

Electronics.question: An analog comparator with hysteresis is useful for:
Electronics.a: Converting noisy or slowly varying analog signals into clean digital edges
Electronics.comment: Hysteresis avoids oscillation near threshold and provides noise immunity.

Electronics.question: Electrostatic discharge (ESD) protection on IC inputs is mainly to:
Electronics.a: Protect sensitive gate oxides and junctions from high-voltage transients
Electronics.comment: ESD diodes, series resistors and protection networks handle transient currents preventing damage.

Electronics.question: Which is the main role of a bypass capacitor placed close to an IC Vcc pin?
Electronics.a: Provide local high-frequency current and reduce supply noise (decoupling)
Electronics.comment: Use small-value (0.1 μF) ceramic in parallel with bulk capacitors to maintain stable supply during fast transients.

Scientific Instruments.question: Least count of a typical vernier caliper (with 50 vernier divisions on 49 mm) is:
Scientific Instruments.comment: LC = 1 main scale division / number of vernier divisions = 1 mm/50 = 0.02 mm for that common arrangement.

Scientific Instruments.question: Least count of a standard screw gauge (micrometer) with pitch 0.5 mm and 50 divisions on circular scale is:
Scientific Instruments.comment: LC = pitch / number of divisions = 0.5 mm / 50 = 0.01 mm.

Scientific Instruments.question: Which instrument measures very small angular deviations and is used with optical benches and spectrometers?
Scientific Instruments.a: Vernier theodolite / spectrometer with vernier on circle
Scientific Instruments.comment: Spectrometer/theodolite uses graduated circle with vernier for precise angle measurements.

Scientific Instruments.question: A spectrometer is mainly used to measure:
Scientific Instruments.a: Wavelengths or angular positions of spectral lines
Scientific Instruments.comment: Optical spectrometers use prism/grating to disperse light and measure wavelengths precisely.

Scientific Instruments.question: In a diffraction grating, angular separation between principal maxima depends on:
Scientific Instruments.a: Wavelength λ, grating spacing d and order n via d sin θ = n λ
Scientific Instruments.c: Only on slit width unrelated to d
Scientific Instruments.comment: Grating equation relates geometry and wavelength; used to determine λ from measured θ.

Scientific Instruments.question: Resolving power of a grating increases if:
Scientific Instruments.a: Number of illuminated slits increases
Scientific Instruments.d: Slit width increases but illuminated slits decrease
Scientific Instruments.comment: Resolving power R = n N (n = order, N = number of slits illuminated).

Scientific Instruments.question: In a prism spectrometer, the minimum deviation method gives:
Scientific Instruments.a: Angle of minimum deviation used to compute refractive index n of prism
Scientific Instruments.comment: n = sin((A + δ_min)/2) / sin(A/2) where A is prism angle and δ_min is minimum deviation.

Scientific Instruments.question: Michelson interferometer is primarily used to measure:
Scientific Instruments.a: Very small changes in length (displacement) or wavelength using interference fringes
Scientific Instruments.comment: Movement of a mirror shifts fringe count; ΔL relates to fringes: 2ΔL = m λ.

Scientific Instruments.question: If m fringes move in Michelson interferometer when mirror moves by ΔL, the relation is:
Scientific Instruments.a: 2 ΔL = m λ
Scientific Instruments.comment: Optical path changes twice the mirror shift (round trip), producing m fringe shifts.

Scientific Instruments.question: Newton's rings are produced by:
Scientific Instruments.a: Interference between light reflected from a spherical surface and a flat glass surface
Scientific Instruments.b: Diffraction at a single slit only
Scientific Instruments.comment: Series of concentric bright/dark rings; radius of mᵗʰ dark ring relates to wavelength and curvature.

Scientific Instruments.question: Radius of mᵗʰ dark Newton ring in reflected light for contact lens of radius R: r_m satisfies:
Scientific Instruments.a: r_m² = m λ R
Scientific Instruments.comment: For thin air film between lens and plate, approximate relation r_m² ≈ m λ R (for small m and paraxial rays).

Scientific Instruments.question: A Michelson interferometer can be used to measure the refractive index n of a gas by:
Scientific Instruments.a: Counting fringe shifts while varying pressure in a cell placed in one arm
Scientific Instruments.comment: Change in optical path due to refractive index change shifts fringes; Δm gives Δn.

Scientific Instruments.question: A photometer is used to compare:
Scientific Instruments.a: Brightness (intensity) of two light sources
Scientific Instruments.comment: Photometers (e.g., Bunsen) use human eye or detectors; modern photometers use photodiodes/PMTs for illuminance.

Scientific Instruments.question: Photoelectric effect experiment requires a device to detect emitted electrons; commonly used is:
Scientific Instruments.a: Photocell or photomultiplier tube (PMT)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Photocell converts photoelectrons to current; PMT multiplies electrons for sensitive detection.

Scientific Instruments.question: Stopping potential V₀ in photoelectric experiment is used to determine:
Scientific Instruments.a: Maximum kinetic energy of emitted electrons via e V₀ = K_max = h ν − φ
Scientific Instruments.comment: Plotting V₀ vs ν yields slope h/e and intercept −φ/e allowing determination of Planck's constant.

Scientific Instruments.question: A galvanometer used as an ammeter requires:
Scientific Instruments.a: A low-value shunt resistor in parallel to bypass most current
Scientific Instruments.comment: Shunt divides current so only meter's full-scale current flows through moving coil while remainder passes through shunt.

Scientific Instruments.question: A galvanometer used as a voltmeter requires:
Scientific Instruments.a: A high-value series resistor to limit current for given voltage
Scientific Instruments.comment: Series resistor sets the full-scale voltage such that meter coil current equals its full-scale current.

Scientific Instruments.question: A ballistic galvanometer is specially used to measure:
Scientific Instruments.a: Total charge delivered in a short-time pulse (integral of current)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Ballistic galvanometer has large moment of inertia and long period so impulse produces measurable deflection proportional to charge Q.

Scientific Instruments.question: The deflection θ of a ballistic galvanometer is proportional to:
Scientific Instruments.a: Charge Q passed through = ∫ i dt (θ ∝ Q)
Scientific Instruments.comment: In ballistic regime, coil receives impulse; deflection depends on total impulse of torque or total charge.

Scientific Instruments.question: A potentiometer measures emf by:
Scientific Instruments.a: Null comparison (no current drawn from test cell at balance) giving accurate emf independent of instrument calibration
Scientific Instruments.comment: Balance condition: potential drop along a length of standard wire equals unknown emf; since no current flows, internal resistance doesn't affect reading.

Scientific Instruments.question: A meter bridge (Wheatstone bridge variation) is used to:
Scientific Instruments.a: Measure unknown resistance by balancing ratios using a uniform wire
Scientific Instruments.comment: Meter bridge uses principle of Wheatstone bridge with null detection using galvanometer at balance point.

Scientific Instruments.question: In the potentiometer method to compare two emf's E₁ and E₂ using same slide wire, balance lengths l₁ and l₂ satisfy:
Scientific Instruments.a: E₁ / E₂ = l₁ / l₂
Scientific Instruments.comment: Potential drop per unit length is constant so emf ∝ balance length when no current drawn from test cells.

Scientific Instruments.question: A cathode ray oscilloscope (CRO) displays signals by deflecting electron beam via:
Scientific Instruments.a: Electric plates (electrostatic deflection) or magnetic coils (magnetic deflection)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Voltage applied to deflection plates produces proportional deflection; time-base gives horizontal sweep for waveform display.

Scientific Instruments.question: In a CRO, vertical sensitivity is typically given in:
Scientific Instruments.a: Volts per division (V/div)
Scientific Instruments.comment: V/div allows reading amplitude from screen divisions; timebase given as s/div for period measurement.

Scientific Instruments.question: Time-base (horizontal sweep) in oscilloscope is expressed as:
Scientific Instruments.a: Seconds per division (s/div)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Time/div setting determines horizontal scaling—measure period/frequency as ticks × s/div.

Scientific Instruments.question: Bandwidth of an oscilloscope limits:
Scientific Instruments.a: Maximum frequency component that can be displayed without significant attenuation (–3 dB point)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Bandwidth specified e.g., 100 MHz; signals with higher harmonics will be attenuated causing waveform distortion.

Scientific Instruments.question: An oscilloscope probe with 10× attenuation typically:
Scientific Instruments.a: Increases input impedance and reduces loading while dividing signal by 10
Scientific Instruments.comment: 10× probe reduces loading on circuit and increases input capacitance compensation needed for flat frequency response.

Scientific Instruments.question: A lock-in amplifier is used to:
Scientific Instruments.a: Extract small signals buried in noise by synchronous detection at a reference frequency
Scientific Instruments.c: Amplify only audio signals without reference
Scientific Instruments.comment: Lock-in multiplies signal with reference and low-pass filters to measure amplitude and phase at reference frequency with high SNR.

Scientific Instruments.question: A spectrophotometer measures:
Scientific Instruments.a: Absorbance/transmittance of samples as a function of wavelength (used in chemistry/biology)
