Classification of Plantae.comment: Insect-pollinated flowers often have bright petals, scent and nectar as attractants.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which term denotes leaf arrangement in which leaves arise in two opposite ranks?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Distichous arrangement means leaves are arranged in two ranks (two vertical rows).

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a correct statement about pollen tube growth?
Classification of Plantae.a: Pollen tube grows from female gametophyte to anther
Classification of Plantae.b: Pollen tube germinates from pollen grain on stigma and grows through style to ovule
Classification of Plantae.c: Pollen tube is not involved in fertilization
Classification of Plantae.d: Pollen tubes only occur in bryophytes
Classification of Plantae.comment: Pollen tube carries male gametes from pollen grain on stigma through style to the ovule.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is NOT true about endosperm in angiosperms?
Classification of Plantae.c: It forms as a result of fusion involving polar nuclei
Classification of Plantae.d: Can be absorbed or persistent depending on seed type
Classification of Plantae.comment: Endosperm is usually triploid (fusion of sperm with two polar nuclei), not diploid.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following group includes organisms that are sometimes placed outside Plantae (in Protista) in modern classifications?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Many algal groups are treated in Protista or separate kingdoms in modern systems, though some green algae are included within Plantae.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a key feature of the life cycle of bryophytes?
Classification of Plantae.b: Gametophyte dominant and sporophyte dependent on gametophyte
Classification of Plantae.comment: Bryophyte sporophyte is usually attached to and dependent on gametophyte.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is used to classify angiosperms in classical systems like Bentham and Hooker?
Classification of Plantae.b: Morphological characters like floral structure, ovary position, etc.
Classification of Plantae.comment: Classical systems (Bentham & Hooker) relied on morphological characters (flowers, ovary, stamens) rather than molecular data.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is TRUE about cotyledons in dicots?
Classification of Plantae.b: There are two cotyledons often storing food or becoming photosynthetic
Classification of Plantae.c: Cotyledons are part of the root system
Classification of Plantae.comment: Dicots typically have two cotyledons that may store food or become photosynthetic.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following plant groups includes the largest number of described species?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Angiosperms (flowering plants) are the largest group with the most described species.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following statements about spores is correct?
Classification of Plantae.b: Spores are produced by meiosis and are haploid
Classification of Plantae.d: Spores are only found in angiosperms
Classification of Plantae.comment: Spores result from meiosis in the sporophyte and are haploid.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is an example of a cryptogamic plant?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Moss is a cryptogam (reproduces by spores, hidden reproductive organs).

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following best describes cambium activity?
Classification of Plantae.a: Cambium contributes to primary growth only
Classification of Plantae.b: Vascular cambium is involved in secondary growth producing wood and secondary phloem
Classification of Plantae.c: Cambium is present only in monocots
Classification of Plantae.comment: Vascular cambium is a lateral meristem responsible for secondary growth (wood and secondary phloem).

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a distinguishing feature of angiosperm seeds compared to gymnosperm seeds?
Classification of Plantae.b: Angiosperm seeds are enclosed within fruit
Classification of Plantae.c: Gymnosperm seeds are enclosed in an ovary
Classification of Plantae.d: Gymnosperm seeds have endosperm always triploid
Classification of Plantae.comment: Angiosperm seeds develop within an ovary that becomes a fruit; gymnosperm seeds are exposed on cone scales.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of these is an example of a cryptogamic plant?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Moss is a cryptogam (reproduces by spores, hidden reproductive organs).

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following best describes cambium activity?
Classification of Plantae.a: Cambium contributes to primary growth only
Classification of Plantae.b: Vascular cambium is involved in secondary growth producing wood and secondary phloem
Classification of Plantae.c: Cambium is present only in monocots
Classification of Plantae.comment: Vascular cambium is a lateral meristem responsible for secondary growth (wood and secondary phloem).

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a distinguishing feature of angiosperm seeds compared to gymnosperm seeds?
Classification of Plantae.b: Angiosperm seeds are enclosed within fruit
Classification of Plantae.c: Gymnosperm seeds are enclosed in an ovary
Classification of Plantae.d: Gymnosperm seeds have endosperm always triploid
Classification of Plantae.comment: Angiosperm seeds develop within an ovary that becomes a fruit; gymnosperm seeds are exposed on cone scales.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a key dispersal adaptation in many angiosperms?
Classification of Plantae.b: Development of fruits to aid dispersal of seeds
Classification of Plantae.comment: Fruits, often adapted to wind, water or animal dispersal, help spread angiosperm seeds.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a common feature of bryophyte habitat preferences?
Classification of Plantae.b: Often moist, shaded habitats due to need for water in reproduction
Classification of Plantae.comment: Bryophytes require moist environments for motile sperm and desiccation tolerance varies.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a structure for vegetative propagation found in Marchantia?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Marchantia produces gemmae in gemma cups for asexual vegetative propagation.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is TRUE about lycophytes (club mosses)?
Classification of Plantae.b: They have microphylls (small leaves with a single vein)
Classification of Plantae.comment: Lycophytes have small leaves called microphylls with a single vein and are vascular but seedless.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following best describes archegonium and antheridium?
Classification of Plantae.b: Female and male sex organs respectively in many lower plants
Classification of Plantae.comment: Archegonium is the female gametangium and antheridium is the male gametangium in many non-seed plants.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a major difference between moss and liverwort?
Classification of Plantae.b: Liverworts often have thalloid or leafy forms and may bear gemma cups; mosses usually leafy
Classification of Plantae.comment: Liverworts can be thalloid or leafy and often reproduce vegetatively via gemmae; mosses are typically leafy.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following describes the function of integuments in an ovule?
Classification of Plantae.b: They develop into seed coat after fertilization
Classification of Plantae.comment: Integuments enclose the ovule and after fertilization they develop into the seed coat (testa).

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is an important economic product from gymnosperms?
Classification of Plantae.b: Timber and turpentine (from conifers such as Pinus)
Classification of Plantae.comment: Conifers (gymnosperms) provide timber, resins and turpentine; many important timber species are gymnosperms.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which type of venation is typical of dicot leaves?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Dicot leaves typically show reticulate (net-like) venation; monocots often have parallel venation.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following terms refers to plants that live submerged in water?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Hydrophytes are plants adapted to living in aquatic environments.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following best describes prothallus in ferns?
Classification of Plantae.b: Haploid gametophyte that bears antheridia and archegonia
Classification of Plantae.comment: Prothallus is the small, usually heart-shaped gametophyte of ferns bearing sex organs.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a hallmark of angiosperm evolution that increased reproductive efficiency?
Classification of Plantae.b: Development of flowers and enclosed ovules
Classification of Plantae.d: Constant dependence on water for fertilization
Classification of Plantae.comment: Flowers and enclosed ovules (seeds in fruits) allowed more efficient pollination and protection of offspring.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is true about secondary metabolites in plants?
Classification of Plantae.a: They are directly involved in growth and primary metabolism only
Classification of Plantae.b: They often serve ecological roles such as defense, attraction of pollinators or allelopathy
Classification of Plantae.c: They are always toxic to humans
Classification of Plantae.d: They are only produced by bryophytes
Classification of Plantae.comment: Secondary metabolites (alkaloids, terpenoids, flavonoids) have ecological roles like defense and attraction.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a specialized stem modification used for food storage?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Tubers (e.g., potato) are modified stems storing food; rhizomes are horizontal underground stems.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following correctly pairs a plant group and its dominant generation?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Angiosperms have a dominant sporophyte; bryophytes have dominant gametophyte.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is an example of an insectivorous plant among angiosperms?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Drosera is an angiosperm that traps insects to supplement nutrients in poor soils.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following describes a botanical 'simple fruit'?
Classification of Plantae.a: Derived from many carpels of different flowers
Classification of Plantae.b: Derived from a single ovary of a single flower
Classification of Plantae.comment: A simple fruit develops from a single ovary of one flower (e.g., mango, pea).

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a mechanism to prevent self-fertilization in many flowering plants?
Classification of Plantae.a: Simultaneous maturation of anther and stigma in same flower
Classification of Plantae.comment: Self-incompatibility and temporal separation of male/female maturity help prevent selfing.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a feature of gymnosperm female cone?
Classification of Plantae.a: Contains ovules on scales which after fertilization becomes seed
Classification of Plantae.comment: Female cones bear ovules on scales; after fertilization seeds develop on these scales.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following best explains why ferns are common in moist shaded forests?
Classification of Plantae.b: Their motile sperm require a film of water for fertilization
Classification of Plantae.comment: Ferns have flagellated sperm that need water to swim to archegonia for fertilization.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is true about floral symmetry?
Classification of Plantae.c: Actinomorphic flowers have radial symmetry while zygomorphic have bilateral symmetry
Classification of Plantae.comment: Actinomorphic = radial symmetry (multiple planes); zygomorphic = bilateral symmetry (one plane).

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a plant adaptation to saline environments?
Classification of Plantae.a: Extensive cuticle and succulent leaves (some halophytes)
Classification of Plantae.comment: Halophytes show adaptations like succulence, salt excretion and specialized roots to tolerate salinity.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the role of pollen grains?
Classification of Plantae.c: They contain male gametophyte cells and germinate to form pollen tubes
Classification of Plantae.d: They are always motile and swim to the ovule
Classification of Plantae.comment: Pollen grains contain male gametophytic cells and germinate on stigma to form pollen tubes delivering sperm.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a spore-producing structure in ferns?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Sori contain sporangia which produce spores in ferns.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following correctly pairs a plant group with its common mode of nutrition?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Algae are photosynthetic; fungi are heterotrophic; some angiosperms are parasitic.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is true about monocot stems compared to dicot stems?
Classification of Plantae.a: Vascular bundles arranged in a ring in monocots
Classification of Plantae.b: Monocots generally have scattered vascular bundles and lack a continuous vascular cambium
Classification of Plantae.c: Monocots always show secondary growth like woody dicots
Classification of Plantae.comment: Monocot stems usually have scattered vascular bundles and typically lack secondary growth from cambium.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a correct statement about pollen dispersal?
Classification of Plantae.a: All plants use insects for pollination
Classification of Plantae.b: Wind-pollinated plants produce small, inconspicuous flowers with abundant light pollen
Classification of Plantae.c: Animal pollinated plants never produce nectar
Classification of Plantae.d: Water pollination is the most common worldwide
Classification of Plantae.comment: Wind pollinated plants (anemophilous) produce large quantities of light pollen and usually have inconspicuous flowers.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is used in the Bentham and Hooker classification primarily?
Classification of Plantae.a: Floral characters such as symmetry, ovary position and number of stamens
Classification of Plantae.comment: Bentham & Hooker used morphological floral characters for classification in their system.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following structures is the male gametangium in bryophytes?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Antheridium is the male gametangium producing sperm in bryophytes and pteridophytes.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following demonstrates heterospory in seed plants?
Classification of Plantae.c: Seed plants producing microspores (male) and megaspores (female)
Classification of Plantae.d: Algae producing only one type of spore
Classification of Plantae.comment: Seed plants are heterosporous: microspores develop into pollen (male gametophyte), megaspores into embryo sac.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a gymnosperm with motile sperm?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Cycads have flagellated sperm; Pinus and most conifers have non-motile sperm delivered via pollen tube.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following statements about angiosperm diversification is correct?
Classification of Plantae.a: Angiosperms diversified extensively due to coevolution with pollinators and fruit dispersers
Classification of Plantae.b: Angiosperms have fewer species than gymnosperms
Classification of Plantae.d: Angiosperms are limited to aquatic habitats
Classification of Plantae.comment: Coevolution with animals (pollinators and dispersers) helped angiosperms radiate into diverse forms and habitats.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a common vegetative propagation method in plants?
Classification of Plantae.c: Use of runners, tubers, bulbs and cuttings
Classification of Plantae.comment: Vegetative propagation includes runners (stolons), tubers, bulbs, suckers and cuttings for asexual reproduction.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is TRUE about floral nectaries?
Classification of Plantae.b: They secrete nectar to attract pollinators
Classification of Plantae.c: They are absent in all insect-pollinated flowers
Classification of Plantae.d: They are a type of root
Classification of Plantae.comment: Nectaries secrete nectar which acts as a reward to attract pollinators like insects and birds.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is an example of a seed that is endospermic at maturity?
Classification of Plantae.a: Pea (where endosperm is absorbed and cotyledons store food)
Classification of Plantae.b: Wheat or maize (where endosperm persists as storage tissue at maturity)
Classification of Plantae.c: Many dicots with no endosperm at maturity
Classification of Plantae.comment: In cereals like wheat and maize the endosperm persists as the main storage tissue in the mature seed.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a morphological adaptation commonly seen in climbing plants?
Classification of Plantae.b: Tendrils, twining stems, hooks and adventitious roots
Classification of Plantae.comment: Climbers use tendrils, twining stems, hooks, or adventitious roots to attach and climb on supports.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following best describes a compound leaf?
Classification of Plantae.b: Leaf blade divided into multiple leaflets attached to one petiole
Classification of Plantae.comment: Compound leaves have several leaflets attached to a single petiole (e.g., neem, rose).

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following plant groups contains species used as model organisms for studying photosynthesis and basic plant biology?
Classification of Plantae.b: Green algae and angiosperms (e.g., Chlamydomonas, Arabidopsis)
Classification of Plantae.comment: Green algae (Chlamydomonas) and angiosperms like Arabidopsis are common model organisms in plant science.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following best describes saprophytic plants?
Classification of Plantae.b: Obtain nutrients from dead organic matter or via fungal associations (some orchids and monotropes)
Classification of Plantae.comment: Some plants are saprophytic or myco-heterotrophic, obtaining nutrients from decaying matter or fungal partners.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is an angiosperm family with bilaterally symmetrical zygomorphic flowers typical of many ornamentals?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Fabaceae and Orchidaceae include many zygomorphic flowers used as ornamentals and crops.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is an evolutionary advantage of seeds over spores?
Classification of Plantae.a: Seeds are always smaller than spores
Classification of Plantae.b: Seeds contain a multicellular embryo and stored food and have protective seed coats improving survival
Classification of Plantae.c: Spores can remain dormant longer than seeds always
Classification of Plantae.comment: Seeds protect and nourish the embryo and aid dispersal and dormancy — advantages over single-celled spores.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a vascular tissue specialized for mechanical support and protection?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Sclerenchyma cells are thick-walled supportive cells (fibers and sclereids) providing mechanical support.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which group of plants is commonly used to study alternation of generations due to a clearly visible independent gametophyte and sporophyte?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Bryophytes and pteridophytes display pronounced alternation with recognizable gametophyte and sporophyte stages.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following best describes a dioecious species?
Classification of Plantae.a: Both male and female flowers occur on same plant
Classification of Plantae.b: Male and female flowers occur on separate plants
Classification of Plantae.comment: Dioecious species (e.g., date palm) have male and female flowers on different individual plants.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is commonly used to identify major angiosperm families?
Classification of Plantae.b: Floral structure, symmetry, ovary position, number of stamens and carpels
Classification of Plantae.comment: Morphological floral characters are key features for identifying angiosperm families in classical botany.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is true about parasitic angiosperms like Cuscuta?
Classification of Plantae.a: They have fully developed leaves and produce abundant chlorophyll
Classification of Plantae.b: They often lack chlorophyll and form haustoria to draw nutrients from host plants
Classification of Plantae.comment: Cuscuta lacks significant chlorophyll and uses haustoria to extract water and nutrients from hosts.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is the male reproductive cell in angiosperms that fuses with egg?
Classification of Plantae.a: Sperm nucleus from pollen's generative cell
Classification of Plantae.comment: The sperm nucleus derived from the generative cell in pollen fertilizes the egg; the other sperm fuses with polar nuclei to form endosperm.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following correctly describes the role of stomata?
Classification of Plantae.a: They are involved in seed dispersal
Classification of Plantae.b: They regulate gas exchange and transpiration in aerial plant parts
Classification of Plantae.comment: Stomata are pores in leaf epidermis that regulate CO2 uptake and water loss (transpiration).

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is TRUE about fruit types?
Classification of Plantae.a: Aggregate fruits develop from a single ovary of one flower
Classification of Plantae.b: Multiple fruits develop from many ovaries of many separate flowers (inflorescence)
Classification of Plantae.c: Simple fruits always develop from more than one flower
Classification of Plantae.d: Accessory fruits never include non-ovarian tissues
Classification of Plantae.comment: Multiple fruits (e.g., pineapple) develop from an inflorescence; aggregate fruits from many carpels of one flower.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a key role of mycorrhizal associations for many plants?
Classification of Plantae.b: Improve nutrient uptake (especially phosphorus) and sometimes protect roots
Classification of Plantae.comment: Mycorrhizae are symbiotic associations between fungi and plant roots enhancing nutrient and water uptake.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a common character used to distinguish monocots from dicots in seeds?
Classification of Plantae.b: Dicots have parallel venation in cotyledons
Classification of Plantae.c: Monocots have one cotyledon while dicots have two
Classification of Plantae.comment: Monocots typically have one cotyledon; dicots have two cotyledons.

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is a typical feature of wind-dispersed fruits/seeds?
Classification of Plantae.b: Light, winged or hairy structures aiding buoyancy in air
Classification of Plantae.c: Sticky surfaces for animal attachment only
Classification of Plantae.comment: Wind-dispersed seeds/fruits are often lightweight with wings or hairs (e.g., samaras, dandelion pappus).

Classification of Plantae.question: Which of the following is TRUE about the root and shoot apical meristems?
Classification of Plantae.a: They are regions of differentiated cells only
Classification of Plantae.b: They contain active dividing cells responsible for primary growth
Classification of Plantae.d: They are only found in fungi
Classification of Plantae.comment: Apical meristems at root and shoot tips contain dividing cells responsible for primary (length) growth.

Classification of Plantae.question: Cycads (e.g., Cycas) belong to which group of plants?
Classification of Plantae.comment: Cycads are gymnosperms — seed-bearing plants with exposed seeds, often palm-like in appearance.

Plant Morphology.question: Which part of the root protects the root apex and helps in gravity perception?
Plant Morphology.comment: Root cap protects the apical meristem and contains statoliths for gravity perception.

Plant Morphology.question: Which tissue in root is primarily responsible for absorption of water?
Plant Morphology.comment: Root hairs, extensions of epidermal cells, increase surface area for water absorption.

Plant Morphology.question: Casparian strip is found in which of the following root regions?
Plant Morphology.comment: Casparian strip is a band of suberin in endodermal cell walls that blocks apoplastic flow.

Plant Morphology.question: Which is a modified root used for aeration in mangroves?
Plant Morphology.comment: Pneumatophores are upward-growing roots that help gas exchange in waterlogged soils.

Plant Morphology.question: Which root modification stores food and is seen in radish?
Plant Morphology.comment: Tuberous roots (e.g., radish) are swollen for food storage.

Plant Morphology.question: Which type of root system is characteristic of monocots like grasses?
Plant Morphology.comment: Monocots typically have a fibrous/ adventitious root system with many similar roots.

Plant Morphology.question: Which stem modification is horizontal and underground and helps in vegetative propagation (e.g., ginger)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Rhizomes are horizontal underground stems storing food and helping vegetative propagation.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a modified stem for storage seen in potato?
Plant Morphology.comment: Potato tubers are swollen stem tips that store food and have 'eyes' (axillary buds).

Plant Morphology.question: Which stem modification is a shortened, fleshy underground stem with tunic-like leaves, seen in onion?
Plant Morphology.comment: Bulbs (onion) have a short stem with fleshy storage leaves (scales).

Plant Morphology.question: Which stem modification is vertical, swollen and has tunic-like scale leaves, e.g., Colocasia?
Plant Morphology.comment: Corms are short, vertical, swollen underground stems (e.g., Colocasia, Crocus).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an aerial stem modification for support in climbers?
Plant Morphology.comment: Tendrils are modified stems or leaves that cling to supports, aiding climbing.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of stem?
Plant Morphology.comment: While green stems can photosynthesize, photosynthesis is primarily a leaf function.

Plant Morphology.question: Nodes and internodes are features of which plant part?
Plant Morphology.comment: Nodes (points of leaf attachment) and internodes (regions between nodes) are stem features.

Plant Morphology.question: Which leaf arrangement has leaves in a spiral along the stem?
Plant Morphology.comment: Alternate (spiral) phyllotaxy places single leaves at each node in a spiral pattern.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an example of opposite leaf arrangement?
Plant Morphology.comment: Guava exhibits opposite leaves (two leaves per node opposite each other).

Plant Morphology.question: A leaf that is not divided into leaflets is called:
Plant Morphology.comment: A simple leaf has a single undivided blade.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an example of pinnately compound leaf?
Plant Morphology.comment: Neem has pinnately compound leaves with leaflets arranged along a central rachis.

Plant Morphology.question: Which leaf venation is typical of dicots?
Plant Morphology.comment: Dicots typically show reticulate venation; monocots often show parallel venation.

Plant Morphology.question: Which type of stomatal distribution is common in hydrophytes (aquatic plants)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Many floating leaves of hydrophytes have stomata on the upper surface to access air.

Plant Morphology.question: Which leaf modification is flattened and leaf-like but actually a stem (e.g., Opuntia)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Phylloclades (cladodes) are flattened photosynthetic stems; phyllodes are modified petioles.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following are leaf modifications for protection as found in Bougainvillea?
Plant Morphology.comment: Spines are modified leaves or parts of leaves that protect the plant; in Bougainvillea they are modified branches but in many plants leaves become spines.

Plant Morphology.question: What is the botanical term for the stalk that attaches the leaf blade to the stem?
Plant Morphology.comment: Petiole attaches the leaf blade (lamina) to the stem.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following are small leaf-like appendages at the base of petiole in many dicots?
Plant Morphology.comment: Stipules are paired appendages at the base of the petiole; they may be leaf-like or scale-like.

Plant Morphology.question: Which type of leaf margin has rounded indentations like waves?
Plant Morphology.comment: Crenate margins have rounded teeth; serrate have sharp saw-like teeth; entire is smooth.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following terms describes leaves that are arranged in a whorl at a node?
Plant Morphology.comment: Whorled phyllotaxy has three or more leaves arising from a single node forming a whorl.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an example of a tendril derived from a leaf?
Plant Morphology.comment: In pea, tendrils are modified leaflets; in some species tendrils may be modified stems or stipules.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is NOT a modification of stem?
Plant Morphology.comment: Adventitious root is a root modification; tuber, bulb, corm are stem modifications.

Plant Morphology.question: Which structure is responsible for secondary growth producing secondary xylem and secondary phloem?
Plant Morphology.comment: Vascular cambium is a lateral meristem producing secondary xylem (wood) and secondary phloem.

Plant Morphology.question: Lenticels on stems are involved in:
Plant Morphology.comment: Lenticels are porous structures in periderm that facilitate gas exchange in woody stems.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an aerial root that provides support to tall trees like banyan?
Plant Morphology.comment: Prop roots (stilt roots) support branches and trunks in species like banyan and maize.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following structures in stem is involved in cork formation?
Plant Morphology.comment: Cork cambium (phellogen) produces phellem (cork) outward and phelloderm inward forming the periderm.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an example of a stem that bears leaves reduced to scales and stores food (e.g., Gladiolus)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Corms are swollen stem bases often with scale leaves; Gladiolus is an example.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a leaf-like structure associated with inflorescence or flower and may be showy?
Plant Morphology.comment: Bracts are modified leaves associated with flowers or inflorescences; often colorful (e.g., Bougainvillea).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following describes pinnate venation?
Plant Morphology.a: Many equal parallel veins from base
Plant Morphology.b: One main midrib with lateral veins branching off
Plant Morphology.comment: Pinnate venation has a single main midrib with lateral veins (e.g., mango).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following leaf shapes is described as heart-shaped with the petiole attached at the notch?
Plant Morphology.comment: Cordate leaves are heart-shaped with a sinus at the base where petiole attaches.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a consequence of secondary thickening in dicot stems?
Plant Morphology.b: Formation of wood (secondary xylem) and increased girth
Plant Morphology.comment: Secondary thickening produces secondary xylem (wood) and secondary phloem, increasing stem girth.

Plant Morphology.question: A leaflet is attached to the rachis by a small stalk called:
Plant Morphology.comment: Petiolule is the stalk that attaches a leaflet to the rachis in a compound leaf.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a concentric arrangement of vascular tissues in stems where phloem lies outside xylem?
Plant Morphology.comment: Collateral bundle has phloem on the outer side and xylem on the inner side (common in stems).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following describes bicollateral vascular bundle?
Plant Morphology.b: Phloem on both sides of xylem
Plant Morphology.comment: Bicollateral bundles have internal phloem (inner) and external phloem (outer) with xylem in between (e.g., Cucurbita).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a phenomenon where nodes develop roots and shoots and a new individual forms (common in vegetative propagation)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Layering induces roots at nodes of an attached branch, producing a new plant upon separation.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is NOT a type of leaf apex?
Plant Morphology.comment: Cuneate describes leaf base shape; apex terms include acuminate, acute, obtuse, emarginate.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following describes a peltate leaf?
Plant Morphology.b: Petiole attached to the center of the lamina
Plant Morphology.comment: Peltate leaves have the petiole attached centrally on the lamina (e.g., lotus).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following represents a modified leaf used for storage, e.g., onion scales?
Plant Morphology.b: Scales or fleshy leaves in bulb
Plant Morphology.comment: In bulbs, fleshy scales are modified leaves that store food (e.g., onion).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of these is a specialized stem which grows above ground and bears adventitious roots at nodes (e.g., strawberry)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Runners (stolons) are horizontal above-ground stems that form new plantlets at nodes.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is the outermost layer of cells in young roots and stems?
Plant Morphology.comment: Epidermis is the protective outermost tissue in young roots and stems.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is characteristic of xerophytes?
Plant Morphology.b: Succulent leaves, thick cuticle, reduced stomata
Plant Morphology.c: Floating leaves with large air spaces
Plant Morphology.comment: Xerophytes have adaptations like succulence, thick cuticle, sunken stomata to reduce water loss.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a leaf modification for water storage seen in succulents?
Plant Morphology.comment: Succulent leaves are thickened to store water (e.g., Aloe, Portulaca).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a spine derived from stem (e.g., Bougainvillea)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Thorns are modified stems; spines are modified leaves; prickles are outgrowths of epidermis (e.g., rose).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a sharp outgrowth of epidermis and cortex, as seen in rose?
Plant Morphology.comment: Prickles are epidermal outgrowths (e.g., rose) and unlike thorns are not modified stems.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an underground storage shoot with a terminal bud and numerous fleshy scale leaves (e.g., tulip)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Bulbs have a short stem and fleshy storage leaves; tulip and onion are examples.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following best defines a node?
Plant Morphology.b: Point on stem where leaf, branch or bud arises
Plant Morphology.comment: Node is the point on stem bearing leaves, buds or branches; internode is the region between nodes.

Plant Morphology.question: Which structure produces lateral roots in plant root anatomy?
Plant Morphology.comment: Pericycle cells (just inside endodermis) give rise to lateral (branch) roots.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following terms describes leaves that emerge in a basal rosette at ground level?
Plant Morphology.comment: Rosulate leaves form a rosette at the base (e.g., dandelion).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an example of a modified stipule forming tendrils (e.g., Clematis)?
Plant Morphology.comment: In some species, stipules or leaf parts can be modified into tendrils to aid climbing.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following terms refers to the mouth-like opening formed by two guard cells on leaves?
Plant Morphology.comment: Stomata are pores on leaf surfaces formed by two guard cells, regulating gas exchange.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a leaf modification for climbing where the entire leaf becomes a tendril (e.g., Smilax)?
Plant Morphology.comment: In some plants whole leaves or leaf parts are modified into tendrils for climbing.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a function of root cap mucilage?
Plant Morphology.b: Lubricate root through soil and aid in soil penetration
Plant Morphology.comment: Mucilage secreted by root cap lubricates passage through soil and can help microbial interactions.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an example of a stem modified into a flattened, photosynthetic organ mistaken for a leaf (e.g., Ruscus)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Phylloclade/cladode is a modified stem performing photosynthesis and resembling a leaf.

Plant Morphology.question: Which part of leaf surrounds vascular bundles and functions as a selective barrier to water and solutes in roots but not typically in leaves?
Plant Morphology.comment: Bundle sheath surrounds vascular bundles in leaves and is important in C4 photosynthesis; endodermis is root-specific.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a leaf modification for catching insects in carnivorous plants like Nepenthes?
Plant Morphology.comment: Pitchers are modified leaves forming pitfall traps that capture and digest insects.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is the region where cell division occurs in the apical meristem?
Plant Morphology.comment: Apical meristem contains actively dividing cells at shoot and root tips responsible for primary growth.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following describes amphistomatic leaves?
Plant Morphology.b: Stomata on both upper and lower surfaces
Plant Morphology.comment: Amphistomatic leaves have stomata on both surfaces (often in many sun-exposed leaves).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a floral leaf or a modified leaf that subtends a flower?
Plant Morphology.comment: Bracts subtend flowers or inflorescences and may be showy or reduced.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following structures arises from the axil of leaf and can develop into branch or flower?
Plant Morphology.comment: Axillary buds in the leaf axil can develop into branches, flowers, or remain dormant.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an example of a stipule that becomes a spiny structure as a defense?
Plant Morphology.comment: In some species, stipules or modified leaf parts become spines for protection.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following describes the arrangement where several leaflets arise from a single point (e.g., horse-chestnut)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Palmate leaves have leaflets radiating from a single point like fingers from a palm.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following stem modifications is specialized for twining around supports (e.g., Ipomoea)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Twining stems coil around supports for climbing (e.g., morning glory).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following terms describes a leaf base that clasps the stem?
Plant Morphology.comment: An amplexicaul leaf base clasps or wraps around the stem.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of hydrophytic leaves?
Plant Morphology.comment: Hydrophyte leaves have reduced palisade and thin cuticle; palisade is well-developed in terrestrial leaves.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is the primary function of root hairs?
Plant Morphology.comment: Root hairs increase the absorptive surface area of roots for water and minerals.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a leaf type where the lamina is divided into many fine segments, like in some ferns?
Plant Morphology.comment: Pinnatifid leaves have deeply lobed or divided lamina into segments.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an example of an underground specialized stem meant for vegetative propagation and is eaten as a vegetable (e.g., potato)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Stem tubers (potato) are swollen stems storing food and bearing buds ('eyes').

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following best describes adventitious roots?
Plant Morphology.a: Roots developing only from the radicle
Plant Morphology.b: Roots arising from non-root tissues like stems or leaves
Plant Morphology.d: Roots with root hairs absent always
Plant Morphology.comment: Adventitious roots arise from stems, leaves, or nodes—not from the primary root.

Plant Morphology.question: Which structure on stem stores nutrients and is covered by tunicate scales in onion?
Plant Morphology.comment: Bulb scales are modified leaves storing food; corm is stem tissue without fleshy scales.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a leaf arrangement in which two or more leaves arise at the same node forming a ring around stem?
Plant Morphology.comment: Whorled phyllotaxy has three or more leaves per node arranged in a circle.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a specialized underground stem with buds and internodes that acts as a storage organ and propagates vegetatively (e.g., turmeric)?
Plant Morphology.comment: Turmeric (Curcuma) has rhizomes—underground horizontal stems with nodes and buds.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is TRUE about phyllotaxy?
Plant Morphology.b: It describes leaf arrangement on stem
Plant Morphology.d: It refers to root branching patterns
Plant Morphology.comment: Phyllotaxy is the arrangement of leaves on the stem (alternate, opposite, whorled).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is an example of a leaf structure that carries out folding movement (sleep movements) due to specialized motor cells?
Plant Morphology.comment: Pulvini are motor swellings at bases of leaflets that facilitate nyctinastic movements (sleep movements).

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is a defensive leaf modification in cacti?
Plant Morphology.comment: Cacti have spines (often modified leaves or shoots) to reduce herbivory and water loss.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following is TRUE for the epidermis of leaves?
Plant Morphology.a: Contains chloroplasts in most dicot leaves
Plant Morphology.b: Has a cuticle that reduces water loss
Plant Morphology.d: Is the primary site of sugar storage
Plant Morphology.comment: Leaf epidermis is typically covered by a waxy cuticle to reduce water loss; guard cells have chloroplasts in many species.

Plant Morphology.question: Which of the following describes a sessile leaf?
Plant Morphology.b: Leaf without a petiole and directly attached to stem
Plant Morphology.comment: Sessile leaves are directly attached to the stem without a petiole.

Plant Tissue.question: Which among the following is a meristematic tissue?
Plant Tissue.comment: Apical meristem is an actively dividing meristematic tissue found at shoot and root tips.

Plant Tissue.question: Meristematic tissues are characterized by:
Plant Tissue.comment: Meristematic cells have dense cytoplasm and lack vacuoles for rapid division.

Plant Tissue.question: Intercalary meristem occurs at:
Plant Tissue.comment: Intercalary meristem is found at nodes/internodes and helps in regrowth of grasses.

Plant Tissue.question: Permanent tissues originate from:
Plant Tissue.comment: Permanent tissues are differentiated from meristematic tissues.

Plant Tissue.question: Which tissue stores food in plants?
Plant Tissue.comment: Parenchyma cells store nutrients, starch, water, and perform basic metabolic functions.

Plant Tissue.question: Which is a simple permanent tissue?
Plant Tissue.comment: Simple tissues are parenchyma, collenchyma, sclerenchyma.

Plant Tissue.question: Chlorenchyma is a specialized form of:
Plant Tissue.comment: Chlorenchyma contains chloroplasts and performs photosynthesis.

Plant Tissue.question: Collenchyma provides:
Plant Tissue.comment: Collenchyma cells have unevenly thickened walls, giving strength + flexibility.

Plant Tissue.question: Which tissue has lignified cell walls?
Plant Tissue.comment: Sclerenchyma has lignin deposition making cells hard and dead at maturity.

Plant Tissue.question: The main water-conducting tissue in plants is:
Plant Tissue.comment: Xylem transports water/minerals upward from root to shoot.

Plant Tissue.question: Which xylem element is living?
Plant Tissue.comment: Only xylem parenchyma is living in xylem tissue.

Plant Tissue.question: Tracheids are mainly found in:
Plant Tissue.comment: Gymnosperms mainly use tracheids for conduction and support.

Plant Tissue.question: Function of phloem is to transport:
Plant Tissue.comment: Phloem conducts food (sucrose) from leaves to all parts.

Plant Tissue.question: Which phloem element is living?
Plant Tissue.comment: Sieve tubes are living but lack nucleus; companion cells help them.

Plant Tissue.question: Companion cells are associated with:
Plant Tissue.comment: Companion cells support sieve tube functions and maintain their metabolism.

Plant Tissue.question: Sclereids are found in:
Plant Tissue.comment: Sclereids (stone cells) give gritty texture to pears and hardness to coconut.

Plant Tissue.question: The tissue responsible for secondary growth is:
Plant Tissue.comment: Lateral meristem (vascular cambium/cork cambium) increases girth.

Plant Tissue.question: Cork cambium produces:
Plant Tissue.comment: Cork cambium forms cork (phellem) toward outside and phelloderm inside.

Plant Tissue.question: Epidermis is a type of:
Plant Tissue.comment: Epidermis is a single layer of protective simple permanent tissue.

Plant Tissue.question: Which tissue has Casparian strips?
Plant Tissue.comment: Endodermis contains Casparian strips made of suberin controlling water movement.

Plant Tissue.question: The ground tissue system includes:
Plant Tissue.comment: Ground tissue consists of simple permanent tissues.

Plant Tissue.question: Which tissue helps in gaseous exchange?
Plant Tissue.comment: Aerenchyma is a parenchyma with air spaces found in aquatic plants.

Plant Tissue.question: Cork cells are filled with:
Plant Tissue.comment: Suberin makes cork waterproof and protective.

Plant Tissue.question: Which meristem causes increase in length?
Plant Tissue.comment: Apical meristem at root/shoot tips causes primary growth.

Plant Tissue.question: The functional unit of phloem conduction is:
Plant Tissue.comment: Sieve tubes transport food by pressure flow.

Plant Tissue.question: The strength of collenchyma is due to:
Plant Tissue.comment: Collenchyma has pectin + cellulose thickening at corners.

Plant Tissue.question: Which xylem element is absent in gymnosperms?
Plant Tissue.comment: Vessels are present mainly in angiosperms.

Plant Tissue.question: Girdling experiment demonstrates function of:
Plant Tissue.comment: Removing phloem stops food transport, causing swelling above ring.

Plant Tissue.question: Which tissue is responsible for healing wounds?
Plant Tissue.comment: Parenchyma retains ability to divide and helps in regeneration.

Plant Tissue.question: Which tissue has dead cells at maturity?
Plant Tissue.comment: Sclerenchyma cells are fully lignified and dead.

Plant Tissue.question: Annular and spiral thickenings occur in:
Plant Tissue.comment: Protoxylem has annular/spiral thickening allowing stretching of young organs.

Plant Tissue.question: Tyloses are found in:
Plant Tissue.comment: Tyloses block old xylem vessels making heartwood.

Plant Tissue.question: The tissue present in the midrib of leaf is:
Plant Tissue.comment: Vascular bundles of leaf contain xylem and phloem.

Plant Tissue.question: Which tissue helps in buoyancy of hydrophytes?
Plant Tissue.comment: Aerenchyma has large air cavities aiding buoyancy.

Plant Tissue.question: The thickening in sclerenchyma is due to:
Plant Tissue.comment: Lignin makes sclerenchyma rigid and durable.

Photosynthesis.question: Photosynthesis primarily occurs in which organelle in plant cells?
Photosynthesis.comment: Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll and are the sites of photosynthesis.

Photosynthesis.question: Which pigment is the principal photosynthetic pigment in higher plants?
Photosynthesis.comment: Chlorophyll a is the primary pigment that participates directly in light reactions.

Photosynthesis.question: Where are the photosynthetic pigments located within chloroplasts?
Photosynthesis.comment: Pigments are embedded in the thylakoid membranes (photosystems) of chloroplasts.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following equations correctly represents overall photosynthesis (simplified)?
Photosynthesis.comment: Balanced simplified photosynthesis: 6CO2 + 6H2O → C6H12O6 + 6O2.

Photosynthesis.question: Which part of chlorophyll molecule is directly involved in light absorption?
Photosynthesis.comment: The porphyrin ring with central Mg2+ absorbs light; phytol tail anchors the molecule in membrane.

Photosynthesis.question: The light reactions of photosynthesis occur in the:
Photosynthesis.comment: Light reactions take place in thylakoid membranes and involve proton pumping into lumen.

Photosynthesis.question: Which photosystem oxidizes water and evolves O2?
Photosynthesis.comment: PSII (P680) oxidizes water via the oxygen-evolving complex, releasing O2.

Photosynthesis.question: Primary electron acceptor in PSII receives electrons from:
Photosynthesis.comment: Excited P680 transfers an electron to primary electron acceptor in PSII.

Photosynthesis.question: Which component transfers electrons from PSII to the cytochrome b6f complex?
Photosynthesis.comment: Plastoquinone (PQ) carries electrons from PSII to the cytochrome b6f complex.

Photosynthesis.question: Plastocyanin is:
Photosynthesis.a: A soluble copper-containing protein that transfers electrons to PSI
Photosynthesis.comment: Plastocyanin (PC) is a small copper protein that transfers electrons to P700 (PSI).

Photosynthesis.question: Which photosystem contains P700 chlorophyll?
Photosynthesis.comment: PSI has reaction center chlorophyll P700 that donates electrons to ferredoxin.

Photosynthesis.question: Ferredoxin primarily transfers electrons to:
Photosynthesis.comment: Ferredoxin transfers electrons to FNR which reduces NADP+ to NADPH.

Photosynthesis.question: Which enzyme catalyzes the final electron transfer to NADP+ during the light reactions?
Photosynthesis.comment: FNR catalyzes the reduction of NADP+ to NADPH using electrons from ferredoxin.

Photosynthesis.question: Photophosphorylation in chloroplasts refers to:
Photosynthesis.comment: Photophosphorylation is ATP formation driven by light via proton gradient across thylakoid membrane.

Photosynthesis.question: Which structure allows protons to flow back into stroma to drive ATP synthesis?
Photosynthesis.comment: CF0-CF1 ATP synthase uses proton motive force to synthesize ATP in stroma.

Photosynthesis.question: Cyclic electron flow around PSI results in:
Photosynthesis.b: Production of ATP but no NADPH
Photosynthesis.comment: Cyclic photophosphorylation generates ATP without NADPH or O2 evolution.

Photosynthesis.question: Which short phrase best describes the 'Z-scheme' of electron flow?
Photosynthesis.a: Linear electron flow from H2O to NADP+ via PSII and PSI
Photosynthesis.b: Electrons flow cyclically around PSII only
Photosynthesis.comment: Z-scheme shows linear electron flow from water (PSII) through cytochrome b6f and PSI to NADP+.

Photosynthesis.question: The Hill reaction demonstrates:
Photosynthesis.b: Photolysis of water and light-driven electron transfer producing O2
Photosynthesis.comment: Hill reaction (isolated chloroplasts) shows light-dependent O2 evolution using artificial electron acceptors.

Photosynthesis.question: Which compound is the first stable product in C3 photosynthesis (Calvin cycle)?
Photosynthesis.comment: CO2 is fixed by Rubisco to RuBP producing two molecules of 3-PGA in C3 plants.

Photosynthesis.question: Rubisco has dual activity. It can act as a carboxylase and as:
Photosynthesis.comment: Rubisco can fix O2 (oxygenase activity) leading to photorespiration.

Photosynthesis.question: The Calvin cycle occurs in the:
Photosynthesis.comment: Dark reactions (Calvin cycle) occur in the chloroplast stroma using ATP and NADPH.

Photosynthesis.question: Which enzyme catalyzes the fixation of CO2 to ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate (RuBP)?
Photosynthesis.comment: Rubisco catalyzes CO2 incorporation into RuBP in Calvin cycle.

Photosynthesis.question: How many CO2 molecules are fixed to produce one molecule of G3P that exits the Calvin cycle?
Photosynthesis.comment: Three CO2 fixed per G3P exported (net gain); net synthesis of one carbohydrate (G3P) requires 3 CO2.

Photosynthesis.question: The primary carbon dioxide acceptor in C4 plants in mesophyll cells is:
Photosynthesis.comment: PEP carboxylase fixes CO2 to PEP forming oxaloacetate in C4 photosynthesis.

Photosynthesis.question: Which enzyme fixes CO2 in C4 photosynthesis initially?
Photosynthesis.comment: PEP carboxylase fixes CO2 to PEP yielding oxaloacetate in mesophyll of C4 plants.

Photosynthesis.question: In C4 plants, the Calvin cycle predominantly takes place in:
Photosynthesis.comment: C4 plants concentrate CO2 in bundle sheath cells where Rubisco operates, reducing photorespiration.

Photosynthesis.question: Which photosynthetic pathway is an adaptation to arid conditions involving temporal separation of CO2 uptake and fixation?
Photosynthesis.comment: CAM plants open stomata at night to fix CO2 into malate and close during day for decarboxylation and Calvin cycle.

Photosynthesis.question: Photorespiration results in the consumption of O2 and release of CO2 and is favored by:
Photosynthesis.c: High O2 and high temperature (low CO2:O2 ratio)
Photosynthesis.comment: High temperatures and high O2 relative to CO2 favor Rubisco oxygenase activity causing photorespiration.

Photosynthesis.question: The Emerson enhancement effect showed that:
Photosynthesis.a: Single wavelength light is optimal for photosynthesis
Photosynthesis.b: Photosynthesis under red light is inhibited
Photosynthesis.c: Simultaneous illumination with wavelengths effective for PSI and PSII increases photosynthesis more than additive effect
Photosynthesis.d: Photosynthesis is independent of light quality
Photosynthesis.comment: Emerson effect demonstrates the need for both PSI and PSII (red + far-red) for maximal rates.

Photosynthesis.question: Which gas is released by plants during the light reactions?
Photosynthesis.comment: Oxygen is evolved during photolysis of water in PSII.

Photosynthesis.question: The compensation point in photosynthesis is:
Photosynthesis.a: Light intensity where rate of photosynthesis equals rate of respiration (net CO2 exchange = 0)
Photosynthesis.b: CO2 concentration where photosynthesis is maximal
Photosynthesis.comment: At compensation point, CO2 uptake by photosynthesis equals CO2 released by respiration.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following is NOT a factor affecting the rate of photosynthesis?
Photosynthesis.comment: Atmospheric N2 (majority) is not directly a limiting factor for photosynthesis; light, CO2, temperature are key.

Photosynthesis.question: Which reaction uses ATP and NADPH produced in the light reactions?
Photosynthesis.comment: Calvin cycle consumes ATP and NADPH to reduce 3-PGA to triose phosphates.

Photosynthesis.question: Which triose phosphate is directly exported from chloroplast as photosynthate for sucrose synthesis?
Photosynthesis.comment: G3P (triose phosphate) is exported to cytosol for sucrose synthesis or used to regenerate RuBP.

Photosynthesis.question: Which transport protein shuttles triose phosphates out of chloroplast in exchange for inorganic phosphate?
Photosynthesis.comment: Triose phosphate/phosphate antiporter exchanges G3P for Pi across chloroplast envelope.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following colors of light is least effective for photosynthesis in green plants?
Photosynthesis.comment: Green light is least absorbed (mostly reflected) due to chlorophyll, making it least effective.

Photosynthesis.question: Which pigment absorbs light in the blue region and gives yellow/orange color?
Photosynthesis.comment: Carotenoids absorb blue light and appear yellow/orange; they also protect against photooxidation.

Photosynthesis.question: Photorespiration consumes O2 and releases CO2 and occurs partly in:
Photosynthesis.comment: Photorespiration involves reactions across chloroplast, peroxisome and mitochondrion.

Photosynthesis.question: Which compound is the primary product exported from chloroplast to cytosol for sucrose synthesis?
Photosynthesis.comment: G3P is exported and used in cytosol for sucrose biosynthesis.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following methods measures oxygen evolution to estimate photosynthetic rate?
Photosynthesis.comment: Oxygen electrodes can measure O2 evolution; IRGA measures CO2 exchange.

Photosynthesis.question: Which technique uses 14CO2 to follow carbon fixation and helped elucidate the Calvin cycle?
Photosynthesis.comment: Melvin Calvin used 14C pulse-chase and chromatography to map intermediates of CO2 fixation.

Photosynthesis.question: Which enzyme regenerates RuBP in the Calvin cycle?
Photosynthesis.comment: Phosphoribulokinase uses ATP to regenerate RuBP from ribulose-5-phosphate.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following best describes 'dark reactions'?
Photosynthesis.b: Do not require light directly but often need ATP and NADPH from light reactions
Photosynthesis.comment: Calvin cycle is light-independent in that it doesn't require light directly but uses ATP/NADPH produced by light reactions.

Photosynthesis.question: Which metal ion is centrally coordinated in chlorophyll?
Photosynthesis.comment: Mg2+ is at the center of chlorophyll porphyrin ring.

Photosynthesis.question: Which plant phylum includes a species used to study alternative photosynthetic pigments, such as phycobilins?
Photosynthesis.comment: Red algae (Rhodophyta) contain phycobilins (phycoerythrin, phycocyanin) as accessory pigments.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following increases efficiency of CO2 fixation in C4 plants?
Photosynthesis.b: Spatial separation of initial CO2 fixation and Calvin cycle (mesophyll and bundle sheath)
Photosynthesis.comment: C4 plants fix CO2 in mesophyll to C4 acids that are transported to bundle sheath where CO2 is released for Rubisco, minimizing photorespiration.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following is true about stomatal opening under light?
Photosynthesis.a: Guard cells lose K+ and water
Photosynthesis.b: Guard cells accumulate K+, lowering water potential and causing water uptake and opening
Photosynthesis.d: Opening is unrelated to ion movement
Photosynthesis.comment: Light stimulates K+ uptake into guard cells, water follows osmotically causing stomatal opening.

Photosynthesis.question: Which compound acts as the CO2 donor in C4 pathway transported to bundle sheath cells?
Photosynthesis.comment: C4 acids (malate/aspartate) transport CO2 to bundle sheath where it is released for Rubisco.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following accurately describes the role of carotenoids in photosynthesis?
Photosynthesis.b: Accessory pigments that absorb blue light and protect against photooxidation
Photosynthesis.comment: Carotenoids absorb excess energy and protect chlorophyll from photooxidative damage; also transfer light to chlorophyll.

Photosynthesis.question: Which molecule provides the reducing power for Calvin cycle?
Photosynthesis.comment: NADPH provides electrons to reduce 3-PGA to G3P in the Calvin cycle.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following is produced during the light reactions and consumed in the Calvin cycle?
Photosynthesis.comment: Light reactions produce ATP and NADPH which drive carbon fixation in the Calvin cycle.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following is a correct statement about RuBisCO?
Photosynthesis.a: It is the fastest enzyme known
Photosynthesis.b: It has both carboxylase and oxygenase activity and is abundant in chloroplasts
Photosynthesis.c: It is located in thylakoid membrane
Photosynthesis.comment: Rubisco is abundant, catalyzes CO2 fixation and can also catalyze oxygenation (photorespiration).

Photosynthesis.question: Which molecule in the light reactions acts as a mobile electron carrier in lumen to stroma transfer?
Photosynthesis.comment: PQ/PQH2 moves electrons and protons between PSII and cytochrome b6f across membrane.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following terms describes plants that utilize C4 photosynthesis?
Photosynthesis.b: Many tropical grasses like maize and sugarcane
Photosynthesis.comment: Many tropical grasses (maize, sugarcane) are C4, reducing photorespiration in hot climates.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following is the effect of increasing CO2 concentration up to a point on photosynthesis rate in C3 plants?
Photosynthesis.c: Increase as Rubisco carboxylation is favored
Photosynthesis.comment: Elevated CO2 increases rate by favoring carboxylation over oxygenation by Rubisco up to saturation.

Photosynthesis.question: Which cellular structure stores starch produced by photosynthesis in many plants?
Photosynthesis.comment: Chloroplasts temporarily store starch; long-term storage occurs in amyloplasts in roots/tubers.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following best explains why leaves are generally broad and flat?
Photosynthesis.b: To maximize surface area for light capture and gas exchange
Photosynthesis.comment: Large lamina increases light interception and CO2 diffusion for photosynthesis.

Photosynthesis.question: Which type of photophosphorylation occurs when electrons follow a linear path from water to NADP+?
Photosynthesis.comment: Linear flow from H2O → PSII → PSI → NADP+ produces ATP and NADPH (non-cyclic).

Photosynthesis.question: Which factor causes stomatal closing to reduce water loss during midday in hot weather?
Photosynthesis.b: Water stress (low leaf water potential) leading to ABA signaling
Photosynthesis.comment: Abscisic acid (ABA) signals stomatal closure during drought to conserve water.

Photosynthesis.question: Which compound is the direct donor of the phosphate group to make ATP in chloroplast ATP synthase?
Photosynthesis.b: Inorganic phosphate (Pi) driven by proton gradient
Photosynthesis.comment: Protons flowing through ATP synthase drive ADP + Pi → ATP; Pi is the phosphate donor.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following correctly pairs a pigment with its absorption peak region?
Photosynthesis.b: Chlorophyll a — blue (around 430 nm) and red (around 662 nm)
Photosynthesis.comment: Chlorophyll a absorbs strongly in blue and red regions; chlorophyll b and carotenoids absorb complementary wavelengths.

Photosynthesis.question: Which reaction or process directly produces molecular oxygen (O2) in photosynthesis?
Photosynthesis.comment: O2 evolves when water is split (photolysis) by the oxygen-evolving complex in PSII.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following is NOT true about CAM plants?
Photosynthesis.a: Open stomata at night to fix CO2 into organic acids
Photosynthesis.b: Perform Calvin cycle during the day using CO2 released from acids
Photosynthesis.c: Common in succulents like cacti and pineapple
Photosynthesis.d: Spatial separation of initial CO2 fixation and the Calvin cycle between mesophyll and bundle sheath
Photosynthesis.comment: CAM uses temporal separation (night/day), not spatial separation which characterizes C4 plants.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following best describes the role of light-harvesting complex (LHC)?
Photosynthesis.b: Capture photons and funnel energy to reaction center chlorophylls
Photosynthesis.comment: LHC contains accessory pigments that absorb light and transfer excitation energy to reaction centers.

Photosynthesis.question: Which substance is commonly used as an artificial electron acceptor in the Hill reaction to demonstrate O2 evolution?
Photosynthesis.comment: DCPIP is reduced in the Hill reaction and used to demonstrate electron flow from PSII.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following correctly orders events in linear electron flow during the light reactions?
Photosynthesis.b: PSII → plastoquinone → cytochrome b6f → plastocyanin → PSI → ferredoxin → NADP+
Photosynthesis.comment: Linear flow: PSII → PQ → cytochrome b6f → PC → PSI → Fd → FNR → NADP+.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following statements regarding light intensity and photosynthesis is correct?
Photosynthesis.a: Photosynthesis rate increases indefinitely with light intensity
Photosynthesis.b: Photosynthesis rate increases with light intensity up to a saturation point beyond which it plateaus
Photosynthesis.d: Photosynthesis always decreases with increasing light
Photosynthesis.comment: Light saturation occurs when other factors (CO2, enzymes) become limiting.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following best describes 'photoinhibition'?
Photosynthesis.a: An increase in photosynthetic rate at low light
Photosynthesis.b: Damage to the photosynthetic apparatus at very high light intensities
Photosynthesis.comment: Excess light can damage PSII reaction centers causing photoinhibition.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following is a direct substrate for Rubisco carboxylase activity?
Photosynthesis.comment: Rubisco catalyzes reaction of RuBP with CO2 to form 3-PGA.

Photosynthesis.question: Which one of the following is a symptom of low light (shade) acclimation in leaves?
Photosynthesis.a: Thicker leaves with more palisade layers
Photosynthesis.c: Thinner leaves with higher chlorophyll content per unit area and lower chlorophyll a:b ratio
Photosynthesis.comment: Shade leaves often are thinner, have more chlorophyll per area and relatively more chlorophyll b aiding light capture.

Photosynthesis.question: Which cellular compartment contains Rubisco in C3 plants?
Photosynthesis.comment: Rubisco is located in the stroma of chloroplasts where the Calvin cycle occurs.

Photosynthesis.question: Which process describes assimilation of inorganic CO2 into organic compounds?
Photosynthesis.comment: Carbon fixation refers to incorporation of CO2 into organic molecules via Calvin cycle or C4/CAM pathways.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following is the immediate acceptor of CO2 in CAM plants at night?
Photosynthesis.comment: PEP carboxylase fixes CO2 to PEP forming oxaloacetate, which is converted to malate at night in CAM plants.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following is a common method plants use to minimize photorespiration?
Photosynthesis.b: C4 pathway concentrating CO2 in bundle sheath cells or CAM temporal separation
Photosynthesis.comment: C4 and CAM pathways reduce photorespiration by concentrating CO2 near Rubisco or temporal separation.

Photosynthesis.question: Which factor would NOT increase the rate of photorespiration?
Photosynthesis.comment: Elevated CO2 reduces photorespiration by favoring carboxylation by Rubisco.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following is a major sink for photosynthate produced in leaves?
Photosynthesis.b: Roots, growing fruits, seeds and growing shoot tips
Photosynthesis.comment: Photosynthates are transported to sinks such as roots, developing fruits, seeds and meristems.

Photosynthesis.question: The P700 reaction center is associated with which major protein complex?
Photosynthesis.comment: P700 is the special pair chlorophyll in PSI reaction center.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following best describes the relationship between stomatal conductance and photosynthetic rate?
Photosynthesis.b: Increased stomatal conductance generally allows greater CO2 uptake increasing photosynthesis until other factors limit it
Photosynthesis.comment: Opening stomata enhances CO2 diffusion into leaf, raising photosynthesis when light and biochemistry permit.

Photosynthesis.question: Which of the following is NOT produced during the Calvin cycle?
Photosynthesis.b: ADP and NADP+ (from ATP and NADPH consumption)
Photosynthesis.comment: O2 is produced in light reactions, not in the Calvin cycle.

Plant Hormones.question: Which of the following is the primary natural auxin in plants?
Plant Hormones.comment: IAA is the principal naturally occurring auxin involved in cell elongation and apical dominance.

Plant Hormones.question: Auxins produced at the shoot apex primarily promote:
Plant Hormones.comment: Auxin from shoot apex suppresses lateral bud growth (apical dominance) and promotes cell elongation.

Plant Hormones.question: Which plant hormone promotes cell division in plant tissue culture when used with auxin?
Plant Hormones.comment: Cytokinins stimulate cell division and with auxin regulate organogenesis in culture.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is primarily associated with stomatal closure and stress responses (drought)?
Plant Hormones.comment: ABA accumulates during water stress and triggers stomatal closure and seed dormancy.

Plant Hormones.question: Ethylene commonly causes which of the following in fruit?
Plant Hormones.comment: Ethylene (a gas) promotes ripening, abscission, and senescence in many fruits and flowers.

Plant Hormones.question: Gibberellins are known to promote:
Plant Hormones.comment: GAs (gibberellins) stimulate stem elongation, breaking seed dormancy and germination in many species.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is commonly applied commercially to delay fruit ripening and extend storage life?
Plant Hormones.comment: 1-MCP binds ethylene receptors and blocks ethylene action, delaying ripening and senescence.

Plant Hormones.question: Apical dominance in plants is primarily maintained by:
Plant Hormones.b: High auxin concentration in the apical bud inhibiting lateral buds
Plant Hormones.comment: Auxin produced by the apical bud suppresses lateral bud outgrowth (apical dominance).

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is directly involved in cell elongation by activating proton pumps and loosening cell walls (acid growth hypothesis)?
Plant Hormones.comment: Auxin stimulates H+-ATPases, acidifying the cell wall and enabling expansins to loosen wall for elongation.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone promotes lateral root formation and adventitious root initiation when applied exogenously?
Plant Hormones.comment: Auxins, particularly IBA and IAA, are widely used to induce rooting in cuttings.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is primarily associated with cell division in shoot apical meristems and delay of senescence?
Plant Hormones.comment: Cytokinins stimulate cell division, promote chloroplast development and can delay leaf senescence.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is synthesized from tryptophan?
Plant Hormones.comment: IAA biosynthesis often proceeds via tryptophan-dependent pathways in plants.

Plant Hormones.question: Ethylene biosynthesis uses which precursor molecule?
Plant Hormones.comment: Ethylene is synthesized from SAM via ACC (1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid) intermediate.

Plant Hormones.question: Abscisic acid levels typically _____ in response to drought stress.
Plant Hormones.comment: ABA accumulates during water deficit and signals stomatal closure and stress responses.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is central to the photoperiodic control of flowering in long-day and short-day plants via florigen signaling?
Plant Hormones.comment: Gibberellins and the mobile FT protein are important in floral induction; photoperiodic sensing involves complex hormonal signaling.

Plant Hormones.question: Which of the following hormones can promote bolting (rapid stem elongation) in rosette plants like Arabidopsis and biennials like sugar beet?
Plant Hormones.comment: Gibberellins stimulate stem elongation and promote bolting/flowering in many rosette plants.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is most directly implicated in leaf abscission and fruit drop (in interaction with auxin and ethylene)?
Plant Hormones.comment: Ethylene promotes abscission; decreased auxin transport from the organ often precedes ethylene sensitivity.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone family includes brassinolide and plays roles in cell expansion, vascular differentiation and stress tolerance?
Plant Hormones.comment: Brassinosteroids (e.g., brassinolide) are steroidal hormones regulating growth and stress responses.

Plant Hormones.question: Which plant hormone is important in systemic acquired resistance and defense signaling against pathogens?
Plant Hormones.comment: Salicylic acid mediates defense responses and systemic acquired resistance to biotrophic pathogens.

Plant Hormones.question: Which group of hormones is mainly associated with wound responses and defense against herbivores (via JA signaling)?
Plant Hormones.comment: Jasmonates regulate wound responses, volatile emission and anti-herbivore defenses.

Plant Hormones.question: The triple response in seedlings (inhibition of root elongation, radial swelling, and horizontal growth) is induced by:
Plant Hormones.comment: Ethylene causes the triple response helping seedlings push through soil obstacles.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone promotes chloroplast development and delays leaf senescence when applied exogenously?
Plant Hormones.comment: Cytokinins promote chloroplast maturation and delay senescence processes.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is mainly responsible for seed dormancy induction and maintenance?
Plant Hormones.comment: ABA enforces seed dormancy and prevents precocious germination under unfavorable conditions.

Plant Hormones.question: Breaking seed dormancy and promoting germination is often achieved by which hormone?
Plant Hormones.comment: Gibberellins promote reserve mobilization (e.g., α-amylase in cereal seeds) and germination.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone interaction is key for apical dominance regulation (inhibition of lateral bud outgrowth)?
Plant Hormones.a: Auxin promotes strigolactone synthesis and suppresses cytokinin
Plant Hormones.comment: Auxin promotes strigolactone and inhibits cytokinin export, collectively suppressing lateral bud growth.

Plant Hormones.question: Strigolactones are plant hormones that primarily regulate:
Plant Hormones.b: Shoot branching (inhibit) and symbiosis with mycorrhizae
Plant Hormones.comment: Strigolactones inhibit shoot branching and act as signaling molecules in rhizosphere interactions.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is gaseous and diffuses rapidly through plant tissues affecting nearby organs?
Plant Hormones.comment: Ethylene is a gaseous hormone that can act locally and systemically due to its diffusion.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone often shows antagonistic interaction with gibberellins during seed dormancy and germination?
Plant Hormones.comment: ABA enforces dormancy while gibberellins promote germination; their balance controls seed behavior.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone family includes strigolactones and affects parasitic plant germination in rhizosphere?
Plant Hormones.comment: Strigolactones stimulate germination of parasitic plants and signal mycorrhizal fungi.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is associated with promoting cambial activity and increasing secondary growth in woody plants?
Plant Hormones.comment: Auxin and cytokinins support cambial activity; auxin from shoots promotes vascular cambium function.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is commonly used in horticulture to promote fruit set parthenocarpically (without fertilization)?
Plant Hormones.a: Auxins and gibberellins (applied singly or combined)
Plant Hormones.comment: Application of auxins or gibberellins can induce parthenocarpy, forming seedless fruits.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is primarily responsible for leaf senescence and chlorophyll degradation when levels increase or sensitivity increases?
Plant Hormones.comment: Ethylene promotes senescence; low cytokinin correlates with accelerated senescence and chlorophyll loss.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is involved in tropic responses such as phototropism and gravitropism by asymmetric distribution?
Plant Hormones.comment: Auxin redistribution to shaded or lower sides causes differential growth leading to tropisms.

Plant Hormones.question: The enzyme ACC synthase is important in the biosynthesis pathway of which hormone?
Plant Hormones.b: Ethylene (ACC synthase converts SAM to ACC)
Plant Hormones.comment: ACC synthase catalyzes formation of ACC, the immediate ethylene precursor from SAM.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone enhances nutrient mobilization and sink strength, promoting fruit growth and seed development?
Plant Hormones.comment: Auxin and cytokinin coordinate source-sink relationships; auxin often promotes sink strength in fruits.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is often used to break apical dominance and encourage bushier growth when applied as pruning alternative?
Plant Hormones.b: Removal of auxin source or application of cytokinin at axillary buds
Plant Hormones.comment: Reducing auxin from apex or applying cytokinin can stimulate lateral bud outgrowth and bushiness.

Plant Hormones.question: Which of the following hormones is known to influence nitrate reductase activity and hence nitrogen assimilation?
Plant Hormones.comment: Cytokinins upregulate nitrate reductase and promote nitrogen assimilation in shoots.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is typically generated in roots and can travel upward to affect shoot architecture and bud outgrowth?
Plant Hormones.comment: Roots produce strigolactones that inhibit branching; cytokinins produced in roots travel via xylem promoting shoot growth.

Plant Hormones.question: Which hormone is often implicated in cold acclimation and freezing tolerance signalling pathways?
Plant Hormones.b: Abscisic acid (ABA) and other cold-responsive hormones
Plant Hormones.comment: ABA participates in cold stress signalling and induction of protective gene expression during acclimation.
